questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital after undergoing an uncomplicated ventral hernia repair with mesh. On post-op day 2 the patient feels short of breath and is having incisional site pain. She has had a bowel movement and is passing gas. She does not have chest pain, nausea, vomiting, urinary urgency or dysuria. Her medical history is significant for a 30 pack-year smoking history, hypertension, and diabetes. Temperature is 100.6°F (38.1°C), blood pressure is 140/82 mmHg, pulse is 98/minute, respiratory rate is 22/minute, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On pulmonary examination, the patient has increased work of breathing, crackles in the lung bases bilaterally and dullness to percussion. There is no significant abdominal tenderness, erythema, edema or purulent drainage around the incision site. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is 2 days out from ventral hernia repair with mesh and presents with difficulty breathing, fever, and crackles in bilateral lung bases, suggestive of atelectasis–a common cause of postoperative fever within the first 2 days following surgery. Risk factors for atelectasis include incisional pain, shallow breathing with poor alveolar recruitment, depressed cough from narcotics, prolonged bed rest, and smoking history.

Postoperative fever is defined as a systemic body temperature that is at or above 38°C or 100.4°F within the postoperative period which gets divided into 4 phases based on the timing of the fever: immediate, acute, subacute, and delayed.

An immediate postoperative fever occurs within 24 hours of the procedure. The most common cause is physiologic, but life-threatening complications such as acute transfusion reactions or adverse drug reactions can also occur. Physiologic fevers are transient, self-limited, and tend to occur following surgeries involving high levels of tissue trauma. Acute transfusion reactions should be suspected in patients who received blood products or have a personal or family history of transfusion reactions. Physical exam findings include flushing, skin rash, angioedema, respiratory distress, or hypotension. An adverse drug reaction can occur if the patient receives anesthetics, antibiotics, or other medications.

The acute phase of postoperative fever occurs between postoperative days 1 to 7. The causes of fever during this time are recalled using the 5 Ws:  

  •  Wind - Atelectasis or Pneumonia 
  •  Water - Urinary Tract Infection 
  •  Wound - Surgical Site Infection - superficial and deep 
  •  Walking - Vascular causes - DVT, phlebitis, central line infection 
  •  Wonder Drugs - Drug Fever

 
Subacute postoperative fever occurs between weeks 1-4 post-procedure. There are 2 important diagnoses that should not be missed during this time: anastomotic leaks and clostridium difficile infection. In an anastomotic leak, patients will present with abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or obstipation after abdominal surgery. Physical exam will reveal abdominal tenderness, distension, and signs of peritonitis (such as rebound, guarding, and decreased bowel sounds). The use of antibiotics increases the risk of Clostridium Difficile infection. Patients will complain of colicky abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, nausea, abdominal tenderness, and distension.

Lastly, the delayed phase of postoperative fever occurs more than 30 days after the procedure. Most fevers that occur at this stage are unrelated to the surgery and caused by community infections such as upper respiratory infections. However, device or prosthesis infections and fistula formation are two complications that should not be missed. A device or prosthesis infection should be considered when there is intraoperative device implantation (such as mesh during hernia repair, ICD) or prosthesis implantation during joint replacement surgery. Patients will present with erythema, edema, and tenderness around the implantation site. Fistulas may occur in patients that have undergone resections requiring anastomosis or postoperative chemoradiation. They often present with erythema, tenderness, foul discharge, or bleeding from a visible fistula site.  

Option Analysis

✅ Atelectasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acute transfusion reaction:
Incorrect: Acute transfusion reactions present within the first 24 hours after surgery with the transfusion of blood products. This patient does not have a history of receiving a blood transfusion and is two days post-op.  
❌ Urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Urinary tract infections usually present between postoperative days 3 to 5, with urinary frequency, urgency, and lower abdominal pain or pressure. This patient has none of these symptoms. Patients with indwelling foley catheters are at increased risk for UTIs.  
❌ Surgical site infection:
Incorrect: Surgical site infections usually present between postoperative days 5 to 7 with incisional pain. Physical exam often demonstrates erythema, edema, purulent drainage, a fluctuant mass, and tenderness to palpation at the incision site.  
❌ Clostridium difficile infection:
Incorrect: Clostridium difficile infections typically present between weeks 1 to 4 post-op. Patients present with abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, nausea, and a history of antibiotic use.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of progressive abdominal distention, pain, nausea, and vomiting for 24 hours. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago. His past medical history includes a motor vehicle accident 2 years ago for which the patient required an exploratory laparotomy. Temperature is 36.8 ℃ (98.2 °F), pulse 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 132/88, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. His abdominal X-ray images are displayed below. Which of the following abdominal examination findings would indicate the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?


Image source Openi
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and X-ray images (showing bowel dilation, air-fluid levels, and paucity of air in the rectum) are consistent with small bowel obstruction (SBO). Adhesions from previous abdominal surgeries are the most common cause of SBO (evidenced by surgical scars on the abdomen). Hernias are another common cause. SBO occurs when a blockage in the small bowel prevents the passage of intraluminal contents (e.g., gas, chyme), which results in distention of the bowel proximal to the obstruction. This condition manifests with pain, abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting.

Adhesions are bands of scar-like tissue that can form between organs or between an organ and the abdominal wall. They often develop after abdominal surgery, particularly open surgery or emergency surgery. Less commonly, adhesions can develop from nonoperative trauma to the abdomen. Small bowel loops can twist around or become kinked by adhesions, resulting in SBO.

Since adhesions are the most common cause of SBO, it is important to elicit any surgical or traumatic history in patients with a suspected SBO. Other general findings in SBO include abdominal distention, tenderness, tympany to percussion, high-pitched and hyperactive bowel sounds early, and decreased bowel sound later in the course.
 

Option Analysis

❌ High-pitched bowel sounds:
Incorrect: High-pitched “tinkling” bowel sounds may be heard in early small bowel obstruction; however, this general finding does not suggest a specific diagnosis and cause of the obstruction.  
✅ Surgical scar:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal distention:
Incorrect: Varying levels of abdominal distention may occur in small bowel obstruction; however, this finding does not point to a specific cause for the obstruction.  
❌ Tympany to percussion:
Incorrect: Tympany to percussion may occur with over-air-filled loops of bowel in small bowel obstruction; however, this finding does not point to a specific cause for the obstruction.  
❌ Hypoactive bowel sounds:
Incorrect: Hypoactive bowel sounds may occur in small bowel obstruction as the bowel becomes progressively distended; however, this finding does not point to a specific cause for the obstruction.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain, distention, obstipation, and vomiting. CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows dilated small bowel with a transition point, and decompressed colon and rectum. The patient is provided with IV fluids, electrolyte replacement, and has a nasogastric tube placed. He is admitted to the hospital for bowel rest and decompression. By day 5, his symptoms have improved, but attempts to discontinue bowel decompression and initiate oral intake result in a recurrence of pain, distention, and vomiting, and placement of a second NG tube. He has not had a bowel movement or passed flatus since admission. Temperature is 36.6 ℃ (97.9 ℉), pulse 77/min, respiratory rate 14/min, blood pressure 120/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. On examination, his abdomen appears distended, is tympanic to percussion, with hyperactive, high-pitched bowel sounds. There is no rebound or guarding. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is hospitalized with simple small bowel obstruction (SBO), as evidenced by abdominal distention, pain, vomiting, obstipation, and associated CT findings. As no concerning findings were found on CT that would require urgent surgical consultation (e.g., bowel ischemia, perforation, malignancy, closed-loop obstruction), he was appropriately treated with conservative measures. This includes nasogastric (NG) tube placement for bowel decompression, bowel rest, IV fluid hydration, and electrolyte replacement.

Additional measures should include serial abdominal examinations (and potential serial X-rays), as well as assessments of the patient’s symptoms and other signs of SBO resolution (e.g., flatus, bowel movements). With evidence of improvement, bowel decompression may be held, and a diet trial may be initiated.

When there is an inadequate response to conservative management after 3–5 days, surgical consultation is warranted and exploratory laparotomy may be needed. Additional factors that should prompt surgical consultation include signs of peritonitis, hemodynamic instability, signs of impending perforation, or imaging signs of bowel ischemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Continue current care:
Incorrect: This patient’s small bowel obstruction has not responded to 5 days of conservative management. After this point, it is recommended to consult surgery.  
❌ Remove the nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: Since the patient’s symptoms worsen when bowel decompression is discontinued, removing the nasogastric tube would likely not improve his condition.  
❌ Administer metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Promotility agents, like metoclopramide, are contraindicated in small bowel obstruction.  
✅ Consult surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer oral magnesium citrate:
Incorrect: Laxatives, such as magnesium citrate, are contraindicated in small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a four-day history of worsening right upper quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the shoulder, fever reaching 38.6°C (101.5°F), and shortness of breath. He has not had jaundice, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy four weeks ago for acute cholecystitis. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 113/73 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.  On physical examination, the patient has tenderness in the right upper quadrant and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with a left shift and an elevated CRP. Which of the following should be ordered next to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast
Ultrasound-guided percutaneous drainage with fluid cultures

questions.solution:
This patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy four days ago and is presenting with RUQ abdominal pain, shoulder pain, fever, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds in the right lung base, and elevated inflammatory markers. These findings are suggestive of a subphrenic abscess caused by recent abdominal surgery. The most appropriate next step in evaluating a suspected subphrenic abscess in this patient is to confirm the diagnosis with a CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast. CT is the best imaging for detecting left-sided subphrenic abscesses and all other intra-abdominal abscesses. Abdominal ultrasound can also be used to diagnose right-sided subphrenic abscesses.

On a CT scan, an intra-abdominal abscess appears as an intra-abdominal fluid collection outside the bowel lumen with possible contrast-enhancing rim, bubbles, or air-fluid levels. Once the diagnosis of intra-abdominal abscess has been made, complicating features on imaging should be assessed to determine the management approach. The presence of one or more of the following features is considered a complicating feature:

  • Percutaneously inaccessible abscess
  • Poorly localized or multifocal abscess
  • High-density fluid indicating hematoma
  • Multi-loculated abscess
  • Presence of anastomotic leak
  • Presence of free hollow organ perforation

If an anastomotic leak or free hollow organ perforation is also seen, the patient will likely have signs of peritonitis and an acute abdomen with diffuse abdominal tenderness, abdominal rigidity, and rebound and guarding. An emergent surgical consult should be called in these cases.
 


Option Analysis

✅ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast:
Correct: See the main explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound-guided percutaneous drainage with fluid cultures:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. Ultrasound-guided percutaneous drainage may be used to treat a subphrenic abscess and to determine the pathologic cause; however, diagnosis with CT should be made first.  
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. A radiograph is not as sensitive as CT for diagnosing subphrenic abscesses, and often the only finding seen on a plain radiograph is an elevated hemidiaphragm. Gas or pleural effusions may also be seen on radiography.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. While obtaining blood cultures is essential in managing a suspected subphrenic abscess, it is not the best initial step for making the diagnosis. Diagnosis should be made with CT of the abdomen and pelvis, blood cultures should be sent, and empiric antibiotics should be started.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Incorrect: ERCP is an important diagnostic and therapeutic tool used for managing biliary tract disorders (e.g., cholangitis, choledocholithiasis, and biliary stricture). However, this patient has had a cholecystectomy and his presentation is more consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. CT of the abdomen and pelvis should be ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following an episode of syncope. The patient’s wife states that he was getting up to do his morning chores when he experienced sudden onset of abdominal pain and loss of consciousness. The patient smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day and does not have any other significant medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 76/60, pulse is 151/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is awake but ill-appearing. On abdominal examination there is a distended abdomen, and a pulsatile mass is felt on direct palpation of the abdomen. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset of abdominal pain, syncope, a pulsatile mass on examination, and hypotension. This presentation is concerning for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. This patient’s hypotension should be first addressed by administering intravenous fluids before other steps are taken. Then an emergent vascular surgery consult should be called.

An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is defined as aortic dilatation that is greater than 3 cm in diameter. Most AAAs are fusiform, which means they’re spindle-shaped and involve the entire circumference of the aortic wall. AAAs can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. While most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging studies, all AAAs are at risk for expansion and rupture. Symptoms of rupture typically include sudden onset abdomen, back, or flank pain with associated syncope.

The acute management of patients presenting with an abdominal aortic aneurysm involves assessment of stability. Patients with evidence of hypotension, airway compromise, or associated vital sign instability should receive corrective measures before further diagnostics are obtained (e.g. intubation for airway compromise).

Once stabilized, patients with a known history of AAA and a presentation consistent with ruptured AAA should have an emergent vascular surgery consultation. Unstable patients, like this patient, without a known history AAA presenting with history and physical exam suggestive of ruptured AAA should be stabilized and then undergo bedside ultrasound to look for dissection or rupture. Also, an emergent surgical consult should be called.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer normal saline bolus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consult vascular surgery:
Incorrect: This patient presents with features suggesting a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. This patient's hypotension should be addressed first, and then vascular surgery should be called.  
❌ Perform bedside abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is best diagnosed via bedside ultrasound; however this patient's hypotension should be addressed first.  
❌ Administer esmolol:
Incorrect: Esmolol is indicated in the management of acute aortic dissection, primarily for blood pressure and heart rate control. It is not used in the management of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation prior to surgical exploration.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department following an episode of syncope. The patient’s wife states that the patient stood up, complained of severe abdominal pain, and suddenly passed out. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history and has not had a healthcare visit in over 10 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 76/56, pulse is 134/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient appears ill with clammy and cool extremities. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass and a diffusely tender abdomen. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis is shown below. IV fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

From Researchgate.net

choices.text: Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair
Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds
Admit to ICU for serial abdominal examinations

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of the acute onset of severe abdominal pain followed by syncope. The patient is hemodynamically unstable and is found to have a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The CT scan demonstrates evidence of a large AAA with contrast extravasation indicating rupture. The best next step in management is emergent vascular surgical consultation for repair.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. While most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging studies, all AAAs are at risk for expansion and rupture.

Patients with a AAA rupture typically are unstable and should be treated with stabilizing measures and emergent surgical consultation for open or endovascular repair. Patients with symptomatic AAA with no evidence of rupture on CT should have a surgical consultation. Symptomatic AAAs have a higher risk of complications like rupture or impingement of nearby vascular structures, so they may need surgical intervention. Smaller AAAs ≤ 5.5 cm that are found incidentally may require long-term monitoring by a vascular surgeon and elective repair if they become larger than 5.5 cm.  

Option Analysis

✅ Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds:
Incorrect: Outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds are indicated for patients with asymptomatic aneurysms that are ≤ 5.5 cm in diameter. This patient has clinical and CT findings of a ruptured AAA and requires emergent surgical repair.  
❌ Administer esmolol:
Incorrect: Esmolol is the medication of choice for impulse control in patients with an aortic dissection. This patient has evidence of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and needs emergent surgical repair.  
❌ Administer heparin:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and should undergo emergent vascular repair. Heparin is not indicated and will likely increase bleeding.  
❌ Admit to ICU for serial abdominal examinations:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and should undergo emergent vascular repair.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for management of a perforated gallbladder and peritonitis. The patient undergoes emergent exploratory laparotomy and requires prolonged and complicated surgery. The patient does well in the immediate postoperative period. On post-op day 4 the patient becomes short of breath and requires 2 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. The patient's past medical history includes a right mainstem endobronchial cancer and resultant recurrent bacterial pneumonia in the right lung, as well as generalized anxiety disorder and osteoarthritis for which the patient takes naproxen daily. Chest radiograph shows left lower lobe atelectasis. Which of the following elements of this patient’s history most likely contributed to his current clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has postoperative atelectasis. Atelectasis refers to partial or complete collapse of a portion of the lung resulting in poor aeration (ventilation) and gas exchange. It is common in hospitalized patients, especially following intra-abdominal or intra-thoracic surgery. Most patients develop atelectasis in small portions of the lung or in a specific lobe. Atelectasis can be separated into obstructive (e.g., mechanical obstruction of the lumen of the airway) or non-obstructive (no intraluminal lesion). Most hospitalized patients with atelectasis develop non-obstructive atelectasis.

History should focus on assessing risk factors for atelectasis. Recent surgery (especially intra-abdominal and intrathoracic) are major risk factors. Patients with chronically impaired ventilation or lung expansion (e.g., lung scarring, paralyzed hemidiaphragm) are also at higher risk. Patients with uncontrolled chronic pain or those on chronic opioid therapy may take shallow breaths due to uncontrolled pain or due to oversedation predisposing them to atelectasis. Multiple prior episodes of bacterial pneumonia or empyema can lead to lung scarring or trapped lung, resulting in atelectasis. Patients with impaired mucus clearance (e.g., cystic fibrosis, muscular dystrophy, severe COPD) can develop obstructive atelectasis from mucus plugging. Patients with known endobronchial malignancies can develop obstructive atelectasis due to the mass obstructing the airway lumen.

Option Analysis

✅ Recent intra-abdominal surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recurrent bacterial pneumonia:
Incorrect: Severe pneumonia with empyema or loculated effusion can lead to chronic lung scarring and lung trapping that may lead to an increased risk for atelectasis. However, this patient’s recurrent pneumonias have occurred in the right lobe secondary to endobronchial cancer in the right mainstem bronchus. Recent surgery is a much more likely contributing factor to this patient’s minor atelectasis in the left lung.
❌ NSAID use:
Incorrect: NSAIDs are not associated with increased risk for atelectasis. Chronic opioid use can impair respiratory drive and increase the risk for developing atelectasis.
❌ Endobronchial cancer:
Incorrect: This patient has endobronchial cancer of the right mainstem bronchus. A mass in the right mainstem bronchus is unlikely to result in minor, likely non-obstructive atelectasis in the left lower lobe.
❌ Generalized anxiety disorder:
Incorrect: While generalized anxiety disorder can cause shallow breathing or shortness of breath, it is not associated with atelectasis.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 3 days. The patient reports that he was treated 10 days ago as an outpatient with antibiotics for acute diverticulitis. The patient states that the pain initially began in the left lower quadrant, however now is felt throughout the entire abdomen. The patient states that encountering bumps in the road en route to the emergency department made the pain worse. Temperature is 39 ºC (102.2 ºF), pulse is 106/min, blood pressure is 133/77 mmHg and respirations are 18/min. The patient appears uncomfortable lying supine on the stretcher. An upright chest radiograph is obtained and is shown below. Which of the following examination findings is most likely to be present?


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Abdominal distention, diffuse tenderness, and rebound pain
Pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings
Arrest of inspiration with deep palpation of the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of pneumoperitoneum on chest radiograph. Given his recent history of acute diverticulitis, colonic perforation from diverticulitis is likely the cause of pneumoperitoneum and signs and symptoms consistent with peritonitis.  

Pneumoperitoneum, or the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, is considered a surgical emergency because it often indicates perforation in the gastrointestinal tract. On the other hand, peritonitis refers to the inflammation of the peritoneum. Depending on the etiology, peritonitis can be divided into primary, secondary, and tertiary causes (intraabdominal fluid, intra abdominal infection from GI tract, and post-operative respectively).  

Patients with signs and symptoms consistent with peritonitis who have first been stabilized should have an upright chest-x ray to evaluate for free air or pneumoperitoneum which is a surgical emergency. If negative, these patients should undergo imaging with a CT of the abdomen and pelvis.  Clinical clues that may point to an underlying etiology include early history of the pain (e.g. right sided pain in a young patient may suggest ruptured appendicitis, or left sided pain in an elderly patient may suggest perforated diverticulitis).

Option Analysis

✅ Abdominal distention, diffuse tenderness, and rebound pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings:
Incorrect: Pain out of proportion to physical exam findings is a common finding associated with ischemic colitis. This patient has evidence of pneumoperitoneum on an upright chest radiograph suggestive of a perforated viscus, pneumoperitoneum, and associated peritonitis.
❌ Arrest of inspiration with deep palpation of the right upper quadrant:
Incorrect: This examination finding describes a positive Murphy sign, which is commonly seen in patients with acute cholecystitis. This patient with recently treated diverticulitis more likely has perforation, pneumoperitoneum, and peritonitis.
❌ Abdominal bulge with Valsalva maneuver:
Incorrect: An abdominal bulge with Valsalva maneuver is suggestive of an abdominal wall hernia. This patient’s findings suggest pneumoperitoneum and peritonitis.
❌ Absent cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: An absent cremasteric reflex is associated with testicular torsion, not with pneumoperitoneum and peritonitis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital on postoperative day 7 for evaluation of drainage from her cesarean section incision site. Her postoperative course was complicated by a superficial surgical site infection treated with antibiotics. She was discharged on postoperative day 4 and her staples were removed on the day of discharge. She has been having pink-tinged drainage from the site of the incision since discharge. She has mild nausea, but no vomiting. She has been passing gas and had a bowel movement today. She has a medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, type 2. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 98/minute, and blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg. On abdominal examination, there is mild erythema around the site of her incision with large amounts of salmon-colored drainage and partial separation of the wound. There is mild tenderness to palpation around the incision and no palpable mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of serosanguinous (‘salmon-colored’) discharge from a recent surgical incision site and partial separation of the incision consistent with wound dehiscence. Her recent abdominal surgery that was complicated by a surgical site infection along with her history of diabetes mellitus puts her at risk for postoperative wound complications.  

Postoperative wound complications can be categorized as wound disruptions, abnormal communications, or wound infections. Wound disruptions are conditions that directly affect the integrity of the incision site and include dehiscence, evisceration, or fluid collections. Abnormal communications refer to fistulas which are direct communications between two epithelial-lined spaces. Lastly, wound infections refer to superficial surgical site infections, deep surgical site infections, organ/space infections, or abscesses. A thorough history and physical examination can help to differentiate between these wound complications.



Patients with wound disruptions may present after straining or lifting weight causing mechanical strain, and they may report a popping sensation. Factors that increase the risk of wound disruptions include smoking, diabetes, malnutrition, and prior radiation. With dehiscence, there is separation of the wound but bowel contents are still contained. In an evisceration, there is separation of the wound with herniation of abdominal contents. It is important to identify dehiscence early on and to intervene before it progresses to evisceration, which is a surgical emergency.

Option Analysis

✅ Fascial (wound) dehiscence:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abdominal wall hematoma:
Incorrect: A hematoma is a blood collection that occurs secondary to bleeding inside the muscle layers. On examination, palpation of a localized, non-pulsatile mass can be appreciated with bloody drainage, whereas this patient has serosanguinous drainage.
❌ Ventral incisional hernia:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with large amounts of drainage of serosanguinous fluid. While she is at risk for developing a hernia, the presentation would reveal findings of a protrusion of the abdominal wall or bulge.
❌ Seroma:
Incorrect: A seroma is an accumulation of serous fluid that can occur following abdominal surgery. Physical examination would reveal a soft, swollen lump with clear drainage.
❌ Surgical site infection:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with serosanguinous discharge from her incisional site. The presence of purulent drainage and surrounding erythema would better support the diagnosis of surgical site infection.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of abdominal pain and fever 5 days after a hemicolectomy that was performed to remove an ascending colonic mass. The fever started on postoperative day 2 and was associated with progressively worsening abdominal pain most pronounced in the right lower quadrant. He rates the abdominal pain as an 8/10. He has nausea but no vomiting and has not had a bowel movement since his surgery. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F), pulse is 107/minute, blood pressure is 118/78, respiratory rate is 18/minute, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. The incision is clean, dry, and intact with no palpable fluctuance or erythema. Decreased bowel sounds are heard and there is tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Labs are significant for a white blood cell count of 16K, elevated ESR, and CRP. Which of the following should be ordered next?

choices.text: CT abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast

questions.solution:
The patient presents with findings consistent with an organ/space surgical site infection. He has fever, tachycardia, and tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without any accompanying skin findings (such as erythema, drainage, or wound breakdown) or signs of peritonitis. Patients with organ/space surgical site infections usually present with fever, malaise, and pain in the region where the surgery was performed. They can also occur as complications of progressive deep incisional surgical site infections, with accompanying skin findings present. Identification of an organ/space surgical site infection is made after imaging confirms the presence of an abscess and wound culture (obtained either percutaneously or surgically) confirms the infection.  

In patients that are presenting with signs and symptoms of an infectious postoperative wound complication, after initial history and physical examination, further evaluation with laboratory tests and imaging should be done. These can include CBC, ESR, CRP, BMP, albumin, wound cultures, and blood cultures. The laboratory evaluation will show findings of leukocytosis, elevated ESR and CRP with positive cultures in a patient who has a deep surgical site or organ/space infection. Further evaluation with ultrasound or CT scan will confirm findings to support a deep surgical site infection or organ/space infection. CT of the abdomen and pelvis is preferred in patients with suspected organ/space infection as it provides a more detailed view of the underlying tissue and organ space. Findings on imaging can include fluid collections, surrounding edema, soft tissue stranding, cobblestoning, or the presence of an abscess.

Option Analysis

✅ CT abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abdominal radiography:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with abdominal pain, fever, and signs of obstruction. Abdominal radiography could show an obstruction; however, in this patient who also has signs of possible organ/space surgical site infection, a CT scan would be more appropriate for further evaluation.
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient has signs and symptoms suggestive of an infection and will likely need antibiotic treatment. However, further investigation to identify the source of the infection should be done in this stable patient without signs of peritonitis prior to initiating treatment with antibiotics.
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of an organ/space surgical site infection. He is stable and is not presenting with an acute abdomen, and therefore imaging can be done to assess the need for surgical intervention.
❌ NG tube placement:
Incorrect: This patient may need an NG tube for the SBO; however, given accompanying signs of organ space infection, further investigation with imaging to further delineate the diagnosis and management should be done before treatment with an NG tube.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset, sharp right lower quadrant abdominal pain that began approximately 3 hours ago, shortly after lifting weights at the gym. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She has no dysuria, hematuria, urinary frequency, or urgency. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears comfortable. On abdominal examination, the abdomen is soft and nondistended with moderate tenderness in the right lower quadrant, without rebound or guarding. There is no costovertebral angle or suprapubic tenderness. Laboratory evaluation, including CBC, CRP, and urinalysis are within normal limits, and a urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset sharp RLQ abdominal pain that began shortly after exercising. In a woman of reproductive age with a negative pregnancy test (ectopic pregnancy less likely), in the absence of fever and elevated inflammatory markers (appendicitis less likely), this clinical presentation is suggestive of a ruptured ovarian cyst. A pelvic ultrasound is recommended for diagnosis and to rule out more serious causes of right lower quadrant pain like ovarian torsion.
 

Periumbilical or lower abdominal pain can stem from various organ systems, making it essential to consider the patient's age, sex, medical history, and associated symptoms when establishing a differential diagnosis. Potential causes of periumbilical or lower abdominal pain from the foregut include infectious gastroenteritis, gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, and pancreatitis. Causes of periumbilical or lower abdominal pain originating from the hindgut include acute appendicitis, acute diverticulitis, inflammatory bowel diseases, irritable bowel syndrome, small bowel obstruction, and acute mesenteric or colonic ischemia. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm can be a life-threatening cause of lower abdominal pain and should be ruled out.

Abdominal wall-related causes of periumbilical or lower abdominal pain include abdominal muscle strain and abdominal wall hernias. Causes stemming from the genitourinary tract include urinary tract infections, nephrolithiasis, ovarian or testicular torsion, ovarian cyst rupture, ectopic pregnancy, and pelvic inflammatory diseases.


Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Observation:
Incorrect: Observation and analgesics are the appropriate initial management of a patient that has been diagnosed with a ruptured ovarian cyst. However, a pelvic ultrasound should be ordered in this patient to confirm the diagnosis and rule out more serious causes of right lower quadrant pain including ovarian torsion, pelvic inflammatory disease, and tubo-ovarian abscess.  
❌ Urine culture:
Incorrect: This patient's description of right lower quadrant pain in the absence of dysuria, frequency, suprapubic pain and tenderness makes the diagnosis of urinary tract infection unlikely. Additionally the urinalysis is negative.  
❌ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is indicated for the evaluation of suspected acute appendicitis which may present with RLQ abdominal pain. However, acute appendicitis is typically associated with more severe abdominal pain, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers. This patient’s findings are more suggestive of a ruptured ovarian cyst.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy is indicated for the evaluation of lower abdominal pain if there is suspicion of inflammatory bowel disease, colonic ischemia, or a colorectal malignancy. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a ruptured ovarian cyst.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful burn to the right hand. The patient was moving a pot of boiling hot water off the stove when he accidentally spilled the water onto his right hand. The patient has no medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 166/73 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a 3 cm circular area of erythema, warmth, blistering, and blanching on the dorsum of the right hand not extending to joints or fingers. Pain is elicited with palpation of the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following correctly describes this patient's injury pattern?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a painful burn injury to the right hand with evidence of redness, warmth, blanching, and blistering. These findings are consistent with a partial-thickness (second-degree burn).

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

The evaluation of a patient presenting with a burn injury begins with understanding the mechanism of exposure. Patients with inhalation injury will typically have prolonged exposure to smoke or heat (e.g. fire in an enclosed space). These patients will typically develop facial burns, wheezing, stridor, and carbonaceous sputum. Alternatively, patients may have a history of direct thermal injury, like the patient in this case. Further characterization of a thermal burn based on the depth of injury is paramount for determining appropriate management.
 

Once the burn has been characterized as a second-, third-, or fourth-degree burn, the TBSA should be calculated using one of the accepted methods to help determine the appropriate treatment. Then a decision should be made if the patient can be treated as an outpatient or inpatient, or should be transferred to a dedicated burn center.  

Option Analysis

✅ Partial thickness burn:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ First-degree burn:
Incorrect: First-degree burns, also known as superficial burns, present with pain and redness, with the injury extending to the epidermis only. Blistering is not typically present in first-degree burns.  
❌ Third-degree burn:
Incorrect: Third-degree burns extend into the subcutaneous fat and typically present with little to no pain. These burns do not blanch with pressure.  
❌ Fourth-degree burn:
Incorrect: Fourth-degree burns extend to the muscle, bone, and tendon. These burn injuries typically present with a fully charred injury, with little to no pain.  
❌ Full-thickness burn:
Incorrect: Full-thickness burns are also known as third-degree burns. They extend into the subcutaneous fat, present with little to no pain, and do not blanch with pressure.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for pyelonephritis and started on intravenous fluids, analgesics, and ceftriaxone. Over the next few days the patient develops worsening abdominal pain, distention, and nausea. The patient’s last bowel movement was prior to admission. Temperature is 37.2 °C (98.9 °F), pulse is 94/min, blood pressure is 111/78 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has a distended abdomen, mild diffuse tenderness to palpation and no guarding or rebound tenderness. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates colonic dilatation without evidence of mechanical obstruction. Fluid hydration and electrolyte replacement are continued. A nasogastric tube is placed for bowel decompression and opioid pain medications are discontinued. Which of the following additional measures should be considered if the condition persists?

choices.text: Call surgical consultation for endoscopic decompression

questions.solution:
This patient’s history, examination, and imaging are consistent with a large bowel obstruction. The CT findings of colonic dilatation without evidence of a mechanical obstruction indicate colonic pseudo-obstruction, a functional (adynamic) form of large bowel obstruction. This is also called Ogilvie syndrome. Risk factors for this condition include advanced age, hospitalization with severe illness, trauma or surgery, electrolyte imbalances, and certain medications (e.g. opioids).
 

In stable patients without evidence of complicated disease (e.g., ischemia, perforation), supportive care is most appropriate. This includes fluid hydration, electrolyte replacement, bowel decompression via nasogastric tube if nausea and vomiting is present, and discontinuation of motility-inhibiting medications (e.g. opioids). Serial abdominal examinations and abdominal radiographs can help to monitor for signs of improvement or worsening. In patients who do not respond to initial therapy, a trial of a cholinesterase inhibitor (e.g. neostigmine) may stimulate bowel motility.

In patients who do not respond to supportive care and a cholinesterase inhibitor, or clinically worsen, surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy is recommended. Additionally, immediate surgical consultation should be obtained for patients who develop hemodynamic instability, signs of peritonitis, or laboratory and imaging concerning for ischemia or perforation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer erythromycin:
Incorrect: Erythromycin to stimulate bowel activity has not been found to be efficacious for colonic pseudo-obstruction. It is more appropriate for gastroparesis or sometimes prior to upper endoscopy in severe active gastric bleeding.  
✅ Administer neostigmine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Call surgical consultation for laparotomy:
Incorrect: Surgical consultation would be indicated for colonic pseudo-obstruction complicated by ischemia or perforation, or if the individual does not improve with supportive care and neostigmine. This patient is hemodynamically stable without peritoneal signs and has not had a full trial of supportive care and neostigmine.  
❌ Call surgical consultation for endoscopic decompression:
Incorrect: Endoscopic decompression can be considered in cases where neostigmine is ineffective or contraindicated. This patient does not have any contraindications for neostigmine so a trial of this medication would be appropriate first.  
❌ Administer atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that can be used as an antispasmodic agent due to its inhibition of GI motility. This would be contraindicated in colonic pseudo-obstruction.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain. The patient had a partial colectomy performed one week ago due to diverticulitis complicated by abscess formation. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and obesity. Temperature is 38.9 °C (102.0 °F), pulse is 120/min, blood pressure is 95/65 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. On physical examination the patient appears uncomfortable and is moaning. Abdominal examination shows abdominal distension, rigidity, guarding and rebound tenderness. The patient is given intravenous fluids and analgesics, and several laboratory studies are obtained and pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Consult general surgery for emergent exploratory laparotomy
Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of postoperative abdominal pain seven days following a partial colectomy.  He has evidence of peritonitis on physical examination. Given the peritonitis and the patient’s ill appearance, the next best step in management is an emergent surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy.

Abdominal pain is commonly reported by patients after surgery. There are many causes, some even life-threatening, but they can be grouped into three categories: disruption of normal healing, infection, or other benign physiologic processes. Abdominal pain can be superficial, or limited to the abdominal wall; or it can be deep, involving organ spaces.

The acute management for patients presenting with postoperative abdominal pain involves the rapid assessment of the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients with evidence of airway compromise or significant vital sign derangements should receive the appropriate stabilizing interventions (e.g. endotracheal intubation) prior to further evaluation. Stable patients should have a full history obtained and a thorough physical examination. Patients should be evaluated for evidence of peritonitis, which includes a severely distended and rigid abdomen, diffuse tenderness, rebound pain and guarding, as well as associated tachycardia and hypotension. Patients with peritonitis, like the one in this case, often have a significant intra-abdominal process like perforation, anastomotic leak, intra-abdominal bleeding or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. These patients require surgical consultation for emergent laparotomy.

Option Analysis

✅ Consult general surgery for emergent exploratory laparotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis and should have emergent surgical consultation prior to CT imaging. This patient will likely require immediate operative intervention.
❌ Order ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect:  This patient has evidence of peritonitis, a transabdominal ultrasound is unlikely to be diagnostic for this patient. Given this presentation, the next best step in management is emergent surgical consultation.
❌ Administer IV piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics should be a component of therapy for this patient who presents with peritonitis; however, vancomycin is probably unnecessary and surgical consultation takes precedence over administering antibiotics.
❌ Place a nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis; while this may be secondary to a bowel obstruction (which would require a nasogastric tube), this patient should have emergent surgical consultation first.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right flank pain. The patient underwent an outpatient percutaneous kidney biopsy two days ago, and the flank pain developed 24 hours after the procedure. The pain has progressively worsened. Medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mmHg. The incision site on the right flank is clean and dry. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a dense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region. Which of the following physical examination findings may be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Tenderness to palpation in the suprapubic region
Arrest of inspiration with palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant
Decreased pulse intensity in the right femoral artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with right flank pain in the setting of a recent right kidney biopsy. Imaging shows a hyperdense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region. Signs, symptoms, history, and imaging are consistent with an iatrogenic right retroperitoneal hematoma.

History is important for determining the cause of a retroperitoneal hematoma which can be traumatic, non-traumatic, or iatrogenic. Patients can present with abdominal, flank, back, and groin pain. Low hemoglobin and hypotension can be seen. Patients with hemodynamic instability should be stabilized first before further evaluation.
 

Several physical examination findings may be seen in the setting of a retroperitoneal hematoma. These include the Grey-Turner, Fox, and Bryant signs. The Grey-Turner sign refers to flank ecchymosis on the side of the retroperitoneal hematoma. The Fox sign refers to inguinal ecchymosis. Finally, the Bryant sign refers to scrotal ecchymosis. Although these signs may be suggestive of a retroperitoneal bleed, they are not always evident as it can takes days for them to appear. In cases of iatrogenic causes, the abdominal examination may reveal the incision sites from percutaneous surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tenderness to palpation in the suprapubic region:
Incorrect: Groin pain and groin ecchymosis can be seen with retroperitoneal hematomas, however suprapubic tenderness, which is typically a sign of acute cystitis, would not be expected. The presence of a hyperdense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region after recent kidney biopsy is consistent with a retroperitoneal hematoma.  
❌ Arrest of inspiration with palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant:
Incorrect: This finding describes a positive Murphy sign, which can be seen with acute cholecystitis. This patient’s recent kidney biopsy and hyperdense fluid collection in the right retroperitoneal region is consistent with a retroperitoneal hematoma.  
❌ Tympanic sounds with abdominal percussion:
Incorrect: In patients with small bowel obstruction, percussion of the abdomen may produce tympanic bowel sounds due to gaseous distention of the small bowel loops. Imaging will typically reveal multiple dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels and a transition point. This patient’s findings are consistent with a right retroperitoneal hematoma.
❌ Decreased pulse intensity in the right femoral artery:
Incorrect: Theoretically, a large retroperitoneal hematoma can displace and compress the intra-abdominal and intrapelvic vasculature, resulting in reduced pulse intensity in the femoral arteries. However, this finding is exceedingly rare and would be less likely than Grey’s sign (flank ecchymosis).  
✅ Ecchymosis over the right flank:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle accident. The patient’s left leg was pinned for more than 2 hours. He is complaining of severe pain in his left lower leg. Temperature is 37.2°C (89.0°F), blood pressure is 95/62 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On examination, his leg is swollen and tense, with decreased sensation and muscle weakness. Passive dorsiflexion of the ankle and toes elicits severe pain in the leg. There are no apparent chest or abdominal injuries, open fractures, or signs of active bleeding, and his pelvis is stable. Initial laboratory results are shown below. IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Radiograph of the left lower extremity is negative for fracture. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result   
Complete Blood Count (CBC)  

Hemoglobin
14.4 g/dL  
White blood cell count  
12,700/mm3   
Serum chemistry   

Sodium  
138 mEq/L  
Potassium
5.3 mEq/L  
Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL  
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)  
20 mg/dL  
Creatine phosphokinase (CPK)  
4,050 U/L  
Lactic acid
2.8 mmol/L

choices.text: Perform left lower extremity Doppler ultrasound
Measure left lower extremity compartment pressure
Obtain an angiogram of the left lower extremity
Administer pain medications and elevate the left lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe pain, a swollen and tense extremity, reduced sensation, motor weakness, and severe pain in the leg with passive dorsiflexion of the ankle and toes. This clinical presentation, along with the history of his left leg being pinned, and elevated creatine kinase and lactate levels, is consistent with the diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome requiring emergent surgical fasciotomy.

Acute compartment syndrome (ACS) is a potentially limb-threatening condition caused by increased pressure within a closed fascial compartment, which compromises the circulation and function of the tissues. The acute management of compartment syndrome in a hemodynamically unstable adult patient necessitates a multidisciplinary approach, prioritizing resuscitation and stabilization while simultaneously addressing the underlying compartment syndrome.
 

Initially, the patient should be stabilized by administering intravenous fluids, blood products, inotropic agents, or vasopressors as required to optimize perfusion and support blood pressure. Once the patient is stabilized and the clinical diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome has been made in this case, management consists of surgical consultation for emergent fasciotomy followed by supportive care. In some cases, a fasciotomy may be required even before full stabilization of the patient, if limb viability is at imminent risk.  

Option Analysis

✅ Consult surgery for emergent fasciotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform left lower extremity Doppler ultrasound:
Incorrect: While a Doppler ultrasound can assess blood flow in the affected extremity, this patient's clinical presentation is highly suggestive of acute compartment syndrome. An emergent fasciotomy should be the priority. Delays caused by obtaining diagnostic imaging may lead to permanent tissue damage and functional loss.  
❌ Measure left lower extremity compartment pressure:
Incorrect: Although measuring compartment pressure can help confirm the diagnosis of compartment syndrome, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with a clinical presentation highly suggestive of acute compartment syndrome. Emergent fasciotomy should be the priority.  
❌ Obtain an angiogram of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: Angiography may be useful for evaluating vascular injuries, but it is not indicated in this case. This patient's clinical findings and history suggest acute compartment syndrome, which requires immediate surgical intervention.  
❌ Administer pain medications and elevate the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: While pain management and elevation may provide some temporary relief, they do not address the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms. Emergent fasciotomy is required to prevent permanent tissue damage and functional loss.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left lower leg. He was in a motorcycle accident 1 day prior, which resulted in a left tibial fracture. The fracture was surgically reduced, and a cast was applied to his leg. The patient mentions that he has had significant pain in the leg over the past 3 hours, accompanied by numbness in the leg. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cast is removed and on examination there is swelling of the leg with normal sensation and a normal motor exam The dorsalis pedis pulse is palpable and strong. Which of the following additional findings would be most indicative of acute compartment syndrome?

choices.text: Pain with passive flexion at the left knee

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe pain and numbness in his left leg 1 day after surgical reduction and casting of a left tibial fracture. The finding of a tense firm or “wood-like” leg would indicate acute compartment syndrome (ACS). Significant pain with passive stretching of the muscles within the affected compartment is also considered a classic finding of acute compartment syndrome. In cases where the classical findings are not present and the clinical picture is inconclusive, the compartment pressure can be measured to confirm the diagnosis of ACS.

Patients with ACS usually present with rapidly progressive severe pain out of proportion to the injury and paresthesias (early sign of nerve ischemia). Extremity swelling, a tense “wood-like” muscle compartment on palpation, pain with passive stretching of the muscles of the involved compartment, and potential motor and sensory deficits are physical exam findings that can be seen in ACS.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pain with passive flexion at the left knee:
Incorrect: This could indicate injury of the left knee, but it would not indicate acute compartment syndrome of the left lower extremity. Pain with passive flexion of the involved compartment (pain with passive flexion of the ankle and toes in this case) can indicate ACS.  
✅ Tense firm left leg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left leg pallor:
Incorrect: Pallor of the affected leg may suggest peripheral vascular disease or arterial insufficiency. The presence of a palpable dorsalis pedis pulse, in this case, indicates that the arterial blood flow is not completely compromised. Of the signs of vascular insufficiency, only pain and paresthesias are commonly seen in ACS. Coolness and pallor are less commonly seen.  
❌ Left leg coolness:
Incorrect: Coolness of the affected leg may suggest peripheral vascular disease or arterial insufficiency. The presence of a palpable dorsalis pedis pulse, in this case, indicates that the arterial blood flow is not completely compromised. Of the signs of vascular insufficiency, only pain and paresthesias are commonly seen in ACS. Coolness and pallor are less commonly seen.  
❌ Left leg calf swelling:
Incorrect: Swelling of the left calf may be indicative of other conditions, such as a deep vein thrombosis, or cellulitis, or it may be from the prior fracture and surgery. Significant swelling in combination with a tense “wood-like” compartment would be more indicative of ACS.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents to their primary care physician for pain and the presence of a palpable mass in their left groin for two weeks. Past medical history is significant for chronic constipation and acute myocardial infarction (MI) treated with cardiac catheterization via the femoral artery and stent placement two months prior. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 128/78 mmHg, pulse is 68/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is significant for a 1 cm, non-tender, non-reducible, non-pulsatile mass in the left groin inferior to the inguinal ligament that becomes more prominent with Valsalva maneuver and coughing. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for urgent surgical repair
Schedule appointment at surgical clinic in two days
Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis
Order ultrasound of the left groin

questions.solution:
This patient is seen for left groin pain and a non-reducible palpable mass. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of an incarcerated femoral hernia. An incarcerated femoral hernia is considered a complicated femoral hernia, and it should be repaired urgently at the time of diagnosis.

Diagnosis of a femoral hernia is made by history and physical examination, and imaging is not necessary to make the diagnosis. Femoral hernias can be asymptomatic or symptomatic, reducible, incarcerated, or strangulated. Patients with asymptomatic femoral hernias may discover a bulge or mass themselves, or it may be discovered incidentally on a physical exam. Because femoral hernias have a high chance of incarceration and strangulation, patients with asymptomatic femoral hernias should see a surgeon to schedule elective repair as soon as possible.

Patients with symptomatic femoral hernias typically present with abdominal or groin pain or discomfort that worsens with activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g. coughing, straining) and a groin mass that is reducible. These patients require elective surgical repair to prevent incarceration and further complications. Repair should be done as soon as possible because of the high risk of associated complications.

Patients with incarcerated femoral hernias, as seen in this patient, typically present with a non-reducible mass or lump in the groin inferior to the inguinal ligament without signs and symptoms related to bowel ischemia. Management consists of urgent surgical repair to prevent bowel ischemia and necrosis.

A strangulated femoral hernia is a surgical emergency associated with bowel ischemia and necrosis. Patients with a strangulated femoral hernia typically present with a non-reducible, tender, and erythematous bulge in the groin inferior to the inguinal ligament. They may also have signs and symptoms of bowel ischemia and constant severe pain in the groin, and signs and symptoms of small bowel obstruction may be present. These patients should be treated immediately with IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, NG tube placement for decompression if SBO is present, and emergent surgical repair to prevent further complications.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admit to the hospital for urgent surgical repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start IV fluids:
Incorrect: Patients with femoral hernias who are hemodynamically unstable should be administered IV fluids. This patient is currently hemodynamically stable.  
❌ Schedule appointment at surgical clinic in two days:
Incorrect: Patients with asymptomatic reducible hernias can be seen soon after diagnosis to schedule elective repair. Repair should be done early to prevent complications. This is not appropriate treatment for non-reducible incarcerated hernias.  
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT or ultrasound can be used to evaluate femoral hernias, but the diagnosis can be made clinically; and patients with incarcerated hernias should have urgent surgical repair to prevent complications.  
❌ Order ultrasound of the left groin:
Incorrect: CT or ultrasound can be used to evaluate femoral hernias, but the diagnosis can be made clinically; and patients with incarcerated hernias should have urgent surgical repair to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine checkup. The patient reports noticing a painless mass in her right groin ever since she started training for a marathon with her partner three weeks ago. The patient has not had abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or change in bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. The patient has not had prior surgeries. BMI is 21 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 131/81 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is significant for a 2 cm, non-tender, non-pulsatile, reducible mass in the right groin inferior to the inguinal ligament and medial to the femoral artery. The mass is more prominent when the patient stands or performs the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Elective surgical repair in one week
Incision and drainage of the mass
CT angiography of the lower extremities

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a painless reducible right groin mass located inferior to the inguinal ligament and medial to the femoral artery, which becomes more prominent when standing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. These findings are consistent with a femoral hernia. Although the patient is asymptomatic, femoral hernias have a high risk of incarceration and strangulation due to the narrow orifice they pass through. Therefore, elective surgical repair is the best next step in management to prevent potentially life-threatening complications.
 

Depending on the risk and clinical presentation of femoral hernias, elective, urgent, or emergent surgical repair should be performed:

  • Elective surgical repair is indicated if the patient is asymptomatic or has minimal symptoms.  
  • Urgent surgical repair is indicated for the management of incarcerated hernias without bowel compromise. 
  • Emergent surgical repair is indicated for the management of strangulated hernias, where blood supply to the herniated bowel segment is compromised, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elective surgical repair in one week:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reassurance and observation:
Incorrect: In contrast to inguinal hernias, asymptomatic femoral hernias carry a high risk of incarceration due to passage through a narrow orifice, and observation is not recommended. Elective surgical repair is indicated to prevent complications, such as incarceration or strangulation.
❌ Incision and drainage of the mass:
Incorrect: Incision and drainage may be indicated for the management of a superficial skin infection complicated by an abscess formation. This patient presents with a 2 cm, non-tender, non-pulsatile, reducible mass in the right groin inferior to the inguinal ligament consistent with a femoral hernia.  
❌ CT angiography of the lower extremities:
Incorrect: CT angiography can be used to diagnose femoral artery aneurysm. This patient presents with a 2 cm non-pulsatile, reducible mass consistent with a femoral hernia.  
❌ Application of a hernia support:
Incorrect: A hernia binder may provide temporary relief of symptoms for patients with symptomatic femoral hernias, but it does not resolve the underlying hernia. Elective surgical repair is indicated to prevent incarceration and provide definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe upper abdominal pain that radiates to his back, as well as nausea and vomiting. The pain began after a large, fatty meal and persisted for several hours. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient drinks alcohol occasionally on weekends. BMI is 31 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.9°C (°F), blood pressure is 103/75 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. On physical examination, the patient appears in distress, and jaundiced, and his abdomen is tender to palpation in the epigastrium. Laboratory results are shown below. CT scan of the abdomen is significant for peripancreatic fat stranding, pancreatic edema, peripancreatic necrosis and common bile duct dilation. The patient is provided with intravenous fluids, analgesia, bowel rest, and broad-spectrum IV antibiotics. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admission for urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
Admission to the intensive care unit for supportive care and observation
Admission to the intensive care unit for supportive care and early enteral feeding

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe upper abdominal pain and CT findings of pancreatic edema, and peripancreatic necrosis consistent with the diagnosis of acute necrotizing pancreatitis. The most likely underlying etiology is gallstone pancreatitis with concurrent cholangitis. In addition to supportive management and IV antibiotics, the most appropriate next step is admission to the hospital for urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).

In cases of mild to moderate acute pancreatitis, the initial management includes aggressive fluid resuscitation, analgesia, and antiemetics. Another crucial aspect of care is early oral feeding as it helps to maintain\the integrity of the gut mucosa and reduces bacterial translocation and infections.

In the case of severe acute pancreatitis, management includes ICU admission for close monitoring and immediate medical support. Aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain control, and antiemetics should be started immediately. Enteral feeding can be attempted after 48 hours of treatment, especially if the patient shows improvement. If oral intake is not possible, a feeding tube can be used. A repeat abdominal CT can be considered after 72 hours, as complications such as necrosis may not be visible on the initial CT scan.

Specific treatments depend on the underlying cause. For example, antibiotics are required for infectious necrosis. In scenarios where a stone in the common bile duct (CBD) is suspected, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) can be performed both as a diagnostic and therapeutic tool. If gallstones are identified, cholecystectomy should be performed during the same hospital stay to prevent recurrence of pancreatitis. Lastly, specific etiologies of pancreatitis, such as toxic, infectious, or medication-related, should be addressed by removing or mitigating the causative agent.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admission for urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admission to the intensive care unit for supportive care and observation:
Incorrect: Admitting the patient to the intensive care unit for supportive management and observation is indicated in the management of severe pancreatitis without evidence of acute cholangitis. Urgent ERCP within 24 hours is indicated in the management of this patient with gallstone pancreatitis and concurrent cholangitis.  
❌ Admission for urgent cholecystectomy:
Incorrect: Cholecystectomy is indicated in the management of gallstone pancreatitis with acute cholangitis; it should, however, be deferred until active inflammation subsides and fluid collections resolve or stabilize.  
❌ Admission for open necrosectomy:
Incorrect: Open necrosectomy is typically reserved for patients with necrosis who have been stable for at least 4 weeks.  
❌ Admission to the intensive care unit for supportive care and early enteral feeding:
Incorrect: While early enteral feeding is indicated in the management of acute pancreatitis, providing supportive care and early enteral feeding without addressing the underlying biliary obstruction would not be sufficient and could worsen this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is on an inpatient medicine unit after undergoing surgery for a left hip fracture 5 days ago. Her postoperative pain has been difficult to manage, and she has required significant amounts of narcotic pain medication. The patient notes that she feels bloated and has not had a solid bowel movement since admission. She states she does not have much of an appetite but she has not had nausea or vomiting and can still pass flatus. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8), blood pressure is 123/77, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, her abdomen is soft but distended, mildly tender to deep palpation, and without rebound tenderness or guarding. On digital rectal examination, a bulky and hard mass of stool is palpated in the rectum. Bedside abdominal X-ray confirms a large colonic stool burden. After performing a successful manual disimpaction, which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Decrease in narcotic pain medication dosage and initiation of a bowel regimen

questions.solution:
This post-surgical patient with abdominal distention and the inability to pass a large mass of stool in the rectum, has a clinical diagnosis of fecal impaction. While fecal impaction is a clinical diagnosis based on signs, symptoms, and the presence of a hard mass of stool on digital rectal examination, an abdominal x-ray may be used to confirm the diagnosis and rule out perforation or other complications. Colonic feces appear heterogeneous with mixed soft tissue and gas densities. Once manual disimpaction is performed, this patient’s narcotic pain medications should be appropriately decreased to a dose that minimizes pain but does not lead to significant constipation, and a bowel regimen should be initiated.

Fecal impaction can occur when there is an anatomic or physiologic disruption in colonic transit leading to the inability to pass stool through peristalsis. Patients may have a history of advanced age, institutionalization or long-term care, hypothyroidism, neuropsychiatric diagnoses, or other medical or anatomical causes leading to difficult or decreased colonic transit. The underlying cause of fecal impaction, which in this patient is likely the use of narcotic medication for postoperative pain control, should be addressed.
 

The mainstays of treatment for fecal impaction include IV fluids, bowel rest and insertion of a nasogastric tube if the patient has abdominal distention and nausea or vomiting, electrolyte repletion, manual disimpaction, addressing the underlying causes of constipation and initiating a bowel regimen. After initiating therapy, the patient can be followed clinically with serial abdominal exams and monitoring for the return of regular bowel movements.

Option Analysis

❌ Nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: Nasogastric tube insertion for gastric decompression would be appropriate if the patient was having nausea, vomiting, or signs of functional or mechanical obstruction. However, this patient has not experienced nausea or vomiting and is still able to pass flatus.
❌ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical history, lack of signs of peritonitis on abdominal examination, and the presence of a bulky mass of stool in the rectum are consistent with a clinical diagnosis of fecal impaction. While a CT scan can be helpful to assess for complications of fecal impaction, such as stercoral colitis or perforation, at this time CT imaging is not indicated.  
❌ Observation:
Incorrect: After performing manual disimpaction a bowel regimen should be initiated and the underlying  causes of fecal impaction should be addressed. Observation alone would not be sufficient.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Utilizing endoscopy as a therapeutic intervention for fecal impaction would only be considered in refractory cases. In this case, the patient was able to undergo a successful manual disimpaction; therefore her opioid medications should be decreased as appropriate and a bowel regimen should be initiated.  
✅ Decrease in narcotic pain medication dosage and initiation of a bowel regimen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for severe tearing chest pain radiating to his back for the past 2 hours and syncope. Past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 93/52 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals weak peripheral pulses, and a 4/6 early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. ECG is significant for sinus tachycardia. IV access is obtained, and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography of the chest and abdomen
Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute tearing chest pain radiating to the back and syncope, along with hypotension, tachycardia, weak peripheral pulses, and a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard at the left lower sternal border indicative of aortic regurgitation. These findings are suggestive of an aortic dissection in an unstable patient which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnostic confirmation with a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).     

An acute aortic dissection in an unstable patient often presents with intense, acute chest pain that feels like a "tear" or "rip" and may radiate to the back. Patients may also experience syncope.
