Physical examination findings can include tachycardia, hypotension, an audible murmur from aortic regurgitation, and signs of cardiac tamponade if the dissection extends proximally. Other symptoms may arise based on the area of the body with insufficient blood supply. This can result in neurological defects, acute limb ischemia, and anuria due to renal artery involvement.    

In an unstable patient, a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is the preferred diagnostic tool, as these patients may not be stable enough for other imaging techniques like a CT angiogram (CTA). A TEE may reveal a double lumen, consisting of the true lumen and a false lumen in the dissected portion, and an intraluminal flap between them. Additional findings can include a thrombus in the false lumen and aortic rupture in severe cases. If the ascending aorta is involved signs of cardiac tamponade may be present.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CT angiography of the chest and abdomen:
Incorrect: Although CT angiography is highly sensitive and specific for aortic dissection, it is not recommended for patients who are hemodynamically unstable due to the time and risk associated with patient transport. TEE is recommended instead.
❌ Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair:
Incorrect: While emergent surgical repair is indicated for the management of Type A aortic dissections, definitive imaging should be obtained to determine the presence and type of aortic dissection before surgery. 
❌ MR angiography of the chest:
Incorrect: MRA of the chest may be indicated in the evaluation of an acute aortic dissection, but it is not recommended when patients are hemodynamically unstable due to the time and risk associated with patient transport. TEE is recommended instead.
❌ Coronary catheterization:
Incorrect:  Coronary catheterization is indicated in the evaluation and management of an acute STEMI. The presence of tearing pain radiating to the back, the diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation, and the absence of ischemic changes on ECG suggest the diagnosis of aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset severe, sharp, chest pain that radiates to the back and dyspnea. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.2°C (°F), blood pressure is 195/140 mmHg in his right arm and 161/105 mmHg the left arm, pulse is 115/min, respirations 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. Pulmonary examination is significant for bilateral basilar rates. Which of the following murmurs is mostly likely to be heard on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border
Continuous murmur over the back between the scapula along with decreased lower extremity pulses
Mid-diastolic rumbling murmur with an opening snap
Holosystolic ejection murmur best heard at the apex
A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe, sharp chest pain that radiates to the back, hypertension, and blood pressure discrepancy between the two arms, which is suggestive of an acute aortic dissection. The presence of dyspnea and bilateral basilar crackles on lung examination indicates that the aortic dissection may have extended to the aortic valve, leading to aortic regurgitation which presents with an early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border.    

Acute aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition characterized by the separation of the layers of the aortic wall. This is typically precipitated by an intimal tear which allows blood to enter the media, resulting in the creation of a false lumen. This leads to the obstruction of the true lumen and possibly compromised arterial blood flow to the brain, kidneys, and bowel. Risk factors include uncontrolled hypertension, pre-existing aneurysm, connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, inflammatory conditions such as giant cell arteritis and Takayasu's arteritis, and lifestyle factors such as smoking, and cocaine use.  

The classic clinical presentation often includes the sudden onset of severe, sharp, and tearing chest pain that radiates to the back or abdomen, which can migrate as the dissection extends along the aorta. On physical examination, patients may present with asymmetric blood pressure in the arms, especially if the dissection involves the aortic arch. A diastolic murmur can also be heard if the aortic valve is involved, leading to aortic insufficiency. Additional findings may be present, depending on which part of the body is experiencing inadequate blood supply.  

Option Analysis

✅ Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Continuous murmur over the back between the scapula along with decreased lower extremity pulses:
Incorrect: This murmur is heard in patients with coarctation of the aorta, which presents earlier in life and with chronic symptoms. The acute onset of severe, sharp, chest pain and the presence of a significant blood pressure discrepancy in the arms is more indicative of an aortic dissection which can lead to aortic regurgitation.
❌ Mid-diastolic rumbling murmur with an opening snap:
Incorrect: This heart murmur indicates mitral stenosis which, worldwide, is most commonly caused by rheumatic fever.
❌ Holosystolic ejection murmur best heard at the apex:
Incorrect: This heart murmur is indicative of a mitral regurgitation, which can cause shortness of breath. However, the presence of acute, severe, sharp, chest pain that radiates to the back and the discrepancy in blood pressures between the arms, is consistent with an acute aortic dissection, which can lead to aortic regurgitation.
❌ A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space:
Incorrect: This heart murmur is indicative of aortic stenosis, which can cause chest pain and dyspnea. This patient’s chest pain radiates to the back and the discrepancy in blood pressure between the arms is consistent with an acute aortic dissection, which can lead to aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to severe chest pain radiating to her back for 1 hour. Past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 36.3°C (°F), blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg in both arms, pulse is 108/min, respirations 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears in pain. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Chest radiograph reveals a widened mediastinum. CT angiogram of the chest demonstrates a double lumen separated by an intraluminal flap in the aorta extending from the left subclavian artery to the abdominal aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents with severe chest pain radiating to the back, severely elevated blood pressure, and a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. This clinical presentation is suggestive of an acute aortic dissection which is confirmed by CT angiography. The presence of an intraluminal dissection flap and double lumen in the descending aorta is consistent with the diagnosis of a type B aortic dissection, which can be managed with intravenous blood pressure control with IV labetalol if there are no complicating features.    

The treatment approach for aortic dissection depends on its classification and the patient's condition. For Stanford type A dissections, which involve the ascending aorta, emergent surgical intervention is necessary due to the high risk of aortic rupture, cardiac tamponade, and severe aortic insufficiency. For Stanford type B dissections, which involve the descending aorta, management is based on the presence or absence of complications. Uncomplicated cases are usually managed medically with aggressive blood pressure control using IV beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers. The aim is to reduce the strain on the aortic wall and prevent further expansion of the dissection. If complications arise such as persistent pain, rapid aortic expansion, impending rupture, or signs of end-organ ischemia, urgent surgical consultation should be called to assess the need for open repair or endovascular repair with graft placement to minimize the risk of rupture.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intravenous labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair:
Incorrect: Emergent surgical repair is required for type A aortic dissections, which involve the ascending aorta. This patient has a type B dissection, which can initially be managed medically with aggressive blood pressure control if there are no complications.
❌ Oral diltiazem:
Incorrect: Oral antihypertensives such as diltiazem, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, can be used for blood pressure control in stable chronic hypertension. In acute settings, intravenous antihypertensives like labetalol are preferred.
❌  Intravenous nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin can be used to control blood pressure; however, it can cause reflex tachycardia which may worsen an aortic dissection. It should be avoided in cases of suspected aortic dissection.
❌  Intravenous heparin:
Incorrect:  IV heparin is an anticoagulant indicated in the management of acute coronary syndromes and pulmonary embolisms. It is contraindicated in the management of acute aortic dissection due to the risk of bleeding and extension of the dissection.

questions.text:
After a high-speed motor vehicle collision, a 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department. The vehicle sustained significant front-end damage with airbag deployment according to emergency medical services. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the secondary survey is notable for multiple abrasions over the left knee, deformity of the left knee, absence of a “dimple sign,” and diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses of the left lower extremity. Which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: CT-angiogram of the left lower extremity
Surgical exploration in the operating room

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with suspected posterior knee dislocation and potential vascular injury given diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on physical examination. A closed reduction, before radiographs, should be attempted immediately to prevent further vascular injury to the extremity. Serial vascular exams should then be performed. If pulses are absent following reduction, the patient should undergo immediate surgical exploration.

Posterior knee dislocations are a potential limb-threatening injury, and the majority of cases occur due to high energy trauma such as falls from heights and motor vehicle collisions with dashboard injuries. Clinically, patients will often have an obvious knee deformity with the tibia and fibula displaced posteriorly. However, it is essential to note that approximately half of posterior knee dislocations will spontaneously reduce before evaluation.

Posterior knee dislocations result from high-energy injuries and thus have a high prevalence of concomitant injury to surrounding structures, including the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments, fibular nerve, and patellar ligaments. In evaluating posterior knee dislocations, specific attention to signs of vascular injury should take precedence due to the high prevalence of concomitant injury to the popliteal artery. Hard signs of vascular injury include absent/weak distal pulses, expanding hematoma, a cool or mottled foot, paresthesias, paralysis, or active popliteal hemorrhage. Patients with hard signs of vascular injury after immediate closed reduction should be taken to the operating room for surgical exploration. In contrast, those with asymmetric pulses should undergo further testing which may include measuring ankle-brachial index (ABI), duplex ultrasonography, and CT-angiogram of the lower extremity to evaluate the vascular injury.  

Option Analysis

✅ Closed reduction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Open reduction:
Incorrect: Cases of posterior knee dislocations with evidence of vascular injury should be treated with emergent closed reduction. If they cannot be reduced, then open reduction would be required. Generally, posterolateral dislocations (which are suggested by an anteromedial skin furrow or “dimple sign” at the medial joint line) are irreducible by closed reduction and require an open reduction in the operating room.  
❌ CT-angiogram of the left lower extremity:
Incorrect: CT-angiogram of the left lower extremity may be performed after closed reduction to assess for injury to the popliteal artery.  
❌ Surgical exploration in the operating room:
Incorrect: Patients with hard signs of vascular injury after reduction should be taken to the operating room for surgical exploration with or without CT-imaging of the lower extremity.  
❌ Measure ankle-brachial index:
Incorrect: Measurement of ankle-brachial indices should occur after reduction if pulses are present and normal, and there are no hard signs of vascular injury. If the measurement is less than 0.9, the patient should be taken for imaging to evaluate for damage to the popliteal artery.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an injury to the left knee. The patient was running during a football game when he was suddenly tackled and struck in the lateral side of the left knee. The patient heard a “pop” and then felt pain at the medial aspect of his left knee. He was able to walk following the incident but noticed his left knee felt “wobbly”. On physical examination the left knee is swollen and there is medial joint line tenderness. The patient subsequently undergoes an MRI of the left knee, and the findings are shown below. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to support this patient’s diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department following an injury that involved a valgus force to the lateral aspect of the knee. Knee MRI demonstrates evidence of injury to the medial collateral ligament. When a valgus stress test is used and valgus force is applied at the knee medial gapping and pain would indicate a positive test in the case of a medial collateral ligament injury.

Medial collateral ligament (MCL) and lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injuries are common injuries in athletes. These injuries often occur in isolation--without the involvement of concomitant ligamentous injuries. Injury to the medial collateral ligament most often is caused by a valgus force applied to the knee from forceful turning or twisting or from a direct blow to the lateral aspect of the knee. In contrast, lateral collateral ligament injuries occur due to a varus force to the knee from forceful twisting or turning or from a direct blow to the medial aspect of the knee.

Diagnosis of either injury is often clinical. In MCL injuries, patients will have increased gapping and pain at the medial knee when valgus force is applied. In LCL injuries, patients will have increased gapping and pain at the lateral aspect of the knee when varus force is applied. MRI is the definitive diagnosis and will demonstrate increased signal intensity at the ligaments with partial tears or visible full-thickness tears.  

Option Analysis

✅ Valgus stress test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Varus stress test:
Incorrect: Varus force applied at the knee joint would demonstrate increased gapping in the setting of a lateral collateral ligament injury. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with a medial collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Lachman test:
Incorrect: Lachman test is used to assess for anterior-cruciate ligament injury. It is not used to evaluate for medial collateral ligament injury. This patient’s medial knee pain and mechanism of injury are more consistent with a medial collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: Thessaly test is used to assess for meniscus injury. However, the MRI does not show evidence of meniscal injury.  
❌ Posterior drawer test:
Incorrect: The posterior drawer test identifies injury to the posterior cruciate ligament which usually occurs from an anterior force applied to a bent knee, not a lateral blow as seen in this case. The posterior drawer test is not used to evaluate for medial collateral ligament injury which this patient likely has.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with emergency medical services after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was the front-seat passenger of a vehicle that rear-ended another car while traveling at 45 miles per hour. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the secondary survey is notable for left knee swelling and ecchymoses. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the left knee demonstrates a large joint effusion and ecchymoses. A “soft” end-feel and increased posterior translation of the left tibia is noted when the examiner applies a posterior force anteriorly to the upper tibia. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury resulting in this patient's clinical condition?

choices.text: Force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee
Valgus force applied to the knee
Varus force applied to the knee
Valgus force applied to the knee

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with evidence of trauma to the left knee and a positive posterior drawer test. These findings are consistent with a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. The most common mechanism of injury in PCL injuries involves a posteriorly directed force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee.

Of all the ligaments in the knee, the PCL is injured least often since it is the knee's largest and strongest intra-articular ligament. Most injuries to the PCL occur via high force trauma, such as when a passenger slams their knee on the dashboard in a motor vehicle crash. PCL injuries rarely occur in isolation and often involve concomitant injury to the other intra-articular ligaments of the knee. Clinically,  the patient will experience instability of the knee, pain, and will have a knee effusion and a positive posterior drawer test.

Definitive diagnostic testing involves magnetic resonance imaging. PCL tears are more commonly partial rather than complete. In the sagittal plane, partially torn PCLs often demonstrate a “stretched” appearance with thickening and intrasubstance signal changes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Valgus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Medial collateral ligament tears are often a result of a valgus force applied to the knee, such as when a football player is tackled from the side. This patient’s physical exam indicates a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury and cause is typically and posteriorly directed  force applied to the anterior aspect of a bent knee.  
❌ Varus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Lateral collateral ligament tears occur due to varus forces applied to the knee. This patient has a positive posterior drawer test which indicates PCL injury.  
❌ Twisting force at the knee:
Incorrect: Meniscal tears are often produced by a twisting mechanism applied to the knee, such as when an individual is turning rapidly or landing from a large jump. This patient had a dashboard injury and has a positive posterior drawer test indicating a PCL injury.  
❌ Valgus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: When a knee injury involves a valgus force applied to the knee, medial meniscal injury can result, as can a triad injury involving the medial meniscus, the anterior cruciate ligament, and the medial collateral ligament.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the clinic to be evaluated for right knee pain. The patient was playing basketball three weeks ago when he suddenly pivoted while running and dribbling to the basket and felt pain in the right knee. Since then, he has experienced pain that worsens with running. In addition, he feels like his knee is “catching” and “giving out”. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the bilateral knees does not demonstrate effusions or deformities When the examiner grasps the patient's thigh and pulls the tibia forward with the knee at 20° of flexion, there is no anterior translation of the tibia or “soft” end-feel. When the examiner attempts to translate the lower leg posteriorly, there is no “soft” end-feel or excessive posterior translation.. There is tenderness to palpation over the medial right joint line. No pain is elicited when the examiner flexes the right knee to maximal flexion beyond 90° and then extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and a varus stress. When the examiner returns the knee to maximal flexion and extends the knee with external rotation of the tibia and a valgus stress  pain and clicking are noted. Radiograph of the knee shows no fracture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after sustaining an injury involving a twisting force applied to the knee. Physical examination demonstrates a positive McMurray test with external rotation of the right knee and valgus stress applied. These findings are consistent with a medial meniscus injury.

Meniscal injuries are a common injury in athletes. This injury often arises from a twisting force applied to the knee while the foot is planted. Patients experience varying degrees of pain following the injury, with some patients seeking care immediately while others seek care weeks to months after the inciting event. Patients often recall a sensation of the knee “popping,” “clicking,” and a feeling that the knee “gives way” with specific movements. Additionally, movements that involve twisting, such as pivoting while running, often exacerbate the pain.  

Clinically, patients may have joint line tenderness, inability to squat or kneel, loss of smooth passive knee motion, and joint effusion if presenting soon after the injury. In addition, patients may have a positive McMurray test. This test is performed when the examiner flexes the knee to maximal flexion beyond 90° and then extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and a varus stress, then returns the knee to maximal flexion and extends the knee with external rotation of the tibia and a valgus stress. Pain or catching/locking with internal rotation and varus stress indicates a lateral meniscal tear, whereas pain or catching/locking with external rotation and valgus stress as seen in this patient indicates a medial meniscus tear. An additional physical examination maneuver to test for meniscal tears is the Thessaly test. The patient stands on the affected leg with the knee flexed at 5° and then 20° while the patient actively rotates the knee and the whole body externally and internally using the knee as the pivot point. Joint line pain or discomfort or clicking indicates a positive test.  

Option Analysis

✅ Medial meniscus injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral meniscus injury:
Incorrect: A lateral meniscus injury would be suspected if the McMurray test reproduces pain or clicking with internal rotation of the right knee and varus stress not external rotation and valgus stress as seen in this patient.  
❌ Anterior cruciate ligament injury:
Incorrect: This patient has a negative Lachman test making it unlikely that he has an underlying anterior cruciate ligament injury. He has a positive McMurray test which indicates a meniscal injury.  
❌ Posterior cruciate ligament injury:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament injuries are an uncommon injury overall as it is the largest ligament of the knee. The posterior cruciate ligament is more commonly injured in the setting of high-speed motor vehicle collisions and this patient has a negative posterior drawer test making it unlikely.  
❌ Tibial plateau fracture:
Incorrect: This patient’s knee radiograph shows no evidence of a tibial plateau fracture.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman who has been in her usual state of health presents to the clinic for evaluation of a mass she noticed in her right breast two months ago. The mass is not painful or tender, and she feels it is more prominent right before she menstruates. She has had no recent trauma or injury to the breast. She has a family history of breast cancer in her mother at the age of 68. Her menstrual cycle is regular. She denies nipple discharge, skin changes, and systemic symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she is not taking any medications. BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, a well-circumscribed, non-tender, rubbery mobile 2 cm mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. Ultrasound shows a round lesion that is well-circumscribed with uniform hypoechogenicity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 25-year-old patient presents with a well-circumscribed, non-tender, rubbery, mobile, 2 cm mass located in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast that fluctuates in size with her menstrual cycle. Given the absence of red flags for breast cancer such as systemic symptoms, nipple discharge, and skin changes; and the ultrasound findings this clinical presentation is suggestive of a fibroadenoma.    

Fibroadenomas refer to benign breast tumors that are most commonly found in women between the ages of 15 and 35 that arise from hormone-sensitive stromal and epithelial connective tissue. They typically present as unilateral, firm, non-tender masses that are palpable in the breast tissue. These tumors are well-circumscribed, rubbery, freely mobile, and are most commonly located in the upper outer quadrant. Their size may increase during pregnancy and decrease after menopause, reflecting hormonal sensitivity. Ultrasound or mammogram should be performed as initial tests in the diagnostic workup of breast masses.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fibroadenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Breast cancer:
Incorrect: Although this patient has a family history of breast cancer, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with a diagnosis of fibroadenoma. Breast cancer typically presents with a firm, immobile mass with irregular borders that may be associated with skin dimpling or nipple retraction.  
❌ Fat necrosis of the breast:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis occurs when a lump forms in an area of fatty breast tissue after injury or trauma to the breast tissue. This patient has no recent history of trauma to the breast tissue.  
❌ Breast abscess:
Incorrect: A breast abscess is a localized collection of inflammatory exudates in the breast tissue typically caused by the progression of lactational mastitis. It typically presents as a palpable, tender, well-defined fluctuant area of the breast along with systemic signs and symptoms of infection, none of which are present in this patient.  
❌ Galactocele:
Incorrect: A galactocele is a cystic collection of fluid caused by an obstructed milk duct. It typically presents as a non-tender, soft cystic breast mass in a breastfeeding patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with Klinefelter syndrome comes to the office to evaluate a painless left breast mass he first noticed while bathing last night. The mass is not associated with pain, discharge, or erythema. The patient feels well and does not have any chronic medical conditions. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination 4 cm subareolar left breast mass and enlarged left axillary lymph nodes. Mammography demonstrates irregular microcalcifications. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is performed and is suggestive of infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Which of the following best differentiates breast cancer in men and women?

choices.text: Breast cancer typically presents at an earlier age in men.
Breast cancer typically presents in more advanced stages in men.
Lobular histology is less common in women.
Inherited breast cancers due to BRCA1 mutations present more commonly in men.
There are higher rates of hormone receptor expression in women.

questions.solution:
Breast cancer primarily affects biological females and is the most commonly diagnosed malignancy in women in the United States; however, up to 1.5% of cases occur in biological males. Breast cancer in males differs from breast cancer in females in the following aspects:  

  • Presents in more advanced stages with retro areolar location and chest wall involvement 
  • Higher rates of hormone receptor expression 
  • BRCA2 > BRCA1  
  • Lobular histology is less common

Unfortunately, breast cancer in men frequently goes undetected until metastatic symptoms present.

In males, breast cancer usually metastasizes to the axillary lymph nodes in addition to the bone, pleura, lung, liver, and skin. Breast cancer infiltrates the pectoral fascia, pectoralis major muscle, and apical lymph nodes in the axilla. 

Option Analysis

❌ Breast cancer typically presents at an earlier age in men.:
Incorrect: As with women, the incidence of breast cancer in men rises with age. Men tend to be 5 to 10 years older than women at the diagnosis.  
✅ Breast cancer typically presents in more advanced stages in men.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lobular histology is less common in women.  :
Incorrect: Most women's histologic subtypes of breast cancer are also present in men. Lobular carcinomas are rare in men (not women).  
❌ Inherited breast cancers due to BRCA1 mutations present more commonly in men.:
Incorrect: Most inherited breast cancers in women are due to BRCA1 mutations, which rarely present in men.  
❌ There are higher rates of hormone receptor expression in women.:
Incorrect: This is true for breast cancer in men, not women. Excessive estrogen stimulation may occur due to hormonal therapies (e.g., estrogen-containing compounds or testosterone), hepatic dysfunction, obesity, thyroid disease, or an inherited condition, such as Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a left breast mass. She has no associated symptoms. Her last menstrual period was one year ago, and she does not have any significant medical history. Family history is essential for breast cancer in the patient’s mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the breast shows a 2-cm firm, irregular round mass over the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Mammography demonstrates a spiculated soft tissue mass with microcalcifications. If left untreated, this patient’s tumor is most likely to spread to the following locations first?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer usually spreads via lymphatic vessels, especially to the axillary lymph nodes (the most common site of metastasis). This patient presents with an irregular, palpable breast mass. This, in combination with her mammographic findings, is concerning for underlying breast cancer.  

Most lymph, especially from the superolateral quadrant and center of the breast, drains into the axillary lymph nodes, emptying into the subclavian lymphatic trunk. On the right, the lymphatic trunk drains into the venous system via the right lymphatic duct, whereas lymph from the left breast returns to the venous system via the thoracic duct.  

Breast cancer may spread to the vertebral bodies and central nervous system. Breast cancer cells can also spread from the breast via the venous system. The posterior intercostal veins drain into the azygos/hemi-azygos system of veins, which subsequently communicate with the internal vertebral venous plexus surrounding the spinal cord.



Option Analysis

❌ Azygos/Hemi-azygos veins:
Incorrect: Cancerous cells can spread from the breast through venous routes. For example, the posterior intercostal veins drain into the azygos system of veins; however, the axillary lymph nodes are the most common site of metastasis for breast cancer cells.  
✅ Axillary lymph nodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pectoral fascia:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can invade the pectoral fascia; however, axillary lymph nodes remain the most common spread site for metastatic breast cancer.  
❌ Retromammary space:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can invade the retro mammary space; however, axillary lymph nodes remain the most common spread site for metastatic breast cancer.  
❌ Brain:
Incorrect: Breast cancer cells can spread from the breast via the azygos/hemi-azygos system of veins to the brain. Axillary lymph nodes remain the most common initial site of metastasis for breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal distension. The patient has had abdominal pain, nausea, and decreased appetite associated with progressive abdominal distension for the past three days. His last bowel movement was five days ago. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for chronic constipation, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient had an open cholecystectomy several years ago. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a distended and tympanitic abdomen with diffuse tenderness to palpation, but no rigidity, rebound tenderness, or guarding. A supine abdominal x-ray is shown below. Which pathophysiological process most likely contributed to this patient’s condition?  



Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane
Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery
Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus
Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine
Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall

questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation is typical of intestinal obstruction (e.g., abdominal distention, abdominal pain, nausea, and constipation). This, together with a history of chronic constipation, is suggestive of sigmoid volvulus.   

Sigmoid volvulus occurs when an air-filled loop of the sigmoid colon twists about its mesentery, forming a closed-loop obstruction. The symptoms of volvulus are those of acute bowel obstruction. Patients present with progressive abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting (secondary to continuous gas production by the intraluminal bacteria). This can rapidly progress to generalized abdominal pain and tenderness.    

Factors that can precipitate the development of sigmoid volvulus include: 
  •  Long redundant sigmoid colon with a narrow mesenteric attachment 
  •  Chronic constipation 
  •  Hirschsprung disease 
  •  Colonic hypomotility (e.g., neurogenic bowel in neurogenic diseases and diabetic enteropathy) 
  Sigmoid volvulus produces a characteristic bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance, with the convexity of the loop lying in the right upper quadrant (opposite the site of obstruction) on plain abdominal x-ray. The coffee bean appearance of the colon is created when the sigmoid colon distends with gas and the medial walls of the dilated bowel loop oppose one another and form the cleft of the coffee bean or an inverted U shape.  



Option Analysis

❌ Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane:
Incorrect: Sliding hiatal hernias occur due to the laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane leading to the herniation of the gastroesophageal junction and proximal stomach into the thoracic cavity. Patients usually present with reflux symptoms (e.g., heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain). This patient’s presentation is suggestive of intestinal obstruction.  
✅ Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus:
Incorrect: Paralytic ileus results when there is a nonmechanical decrease in flow of intestinal contents. It can lead to intestinal obstruction which is seen on abdominal x-ray as generalized distension of small and large bowel. A coffee-bean sign as seen on this patient’s plain radiograph suggests sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine:
Incorrect: Intussusception (telescoping of the proximal intestine into the distal intestine) can cause intermittent, colicky abdominal pain and currant jelly stools. It typically occurs in infants aged 6-36 months. Plain abdominal radiographs may show a “target sign”, not the coffee bean sign seen in this patient.  
❌ Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis (inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall) can present with left lower quadrant pain. It usually does not cause mechanical intestinal obstruction or a coffee bean sign on x-ray.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is currently postoperative on day two following a cervical lymph node dissection. The patient reports feeling well but states his shoulder seems “droopy.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a laterally displaced scapula and weakness with shoulder abduction. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) provides motor function to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles of the neck and upper back. Injury to this nerve often manifests with pain and weakness about the shoulder. Specifically, patients have an asymmetric neckline, drooping shoulder, laterally displaced scapula, and weakness with overhead abduction of the shoulder.

The most common mechanism of injury involves iatrogenic injury via radical neck dissections, cervical lymph node biopsies, and posterior and lateral cervical triangle surgeries. Additional injury causes include blunt or penetrating trauma; however, these are significantly less common.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spinal accessory nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Isolated superior laryngeal nerve injury produces vocal fatigue and subtle voice quality, pitch, and projection changes. This patient presents with evidence of trapezius dysfunction.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx.  
❌ Long thoracic nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the long thoracic nerve more commonly occurs following chest wall surgeries. Clinical manifestations include a “winged scapula” due to the serratus anterior muscle weakness.  
❌ Supraclavicular nerve:
Incorrect: The supraclavicular nerve is a superficial sensory nerve originating from the superficial cervical plexus's C3 and C4 nerve roots. This patient presents with evidence of motor deficits.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is currently undergoing an adenotonsillectomy secondary to sleep-disordered breathing and recurrent tonsillitis. Intraoperatively, brisk bleeding is noted from the lateral pharyngeal wall after removing the right palatine tonsil. Attempts at cauterization and hemostasis are unsuccessful with continued pulsatile bleeding. The patient’s current vital signs are temperature is 37 C° (98.6 F°), respirations are 18/minute, pulse is 116/minute, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Removal of the tonsils is a common procedure performed secondary to recurrent tonsillitis or sleep-disordered breathing. When the palatine tonsils alone are removed, the procedure is referred to as a tonsillectomy; when both the palatine tonsils and the pharyngeal tonsils (adenoids) are removed, it is referred to as an adenotonsillectomy. Typically, some surrounding connective tissue is also removed during these procedures.

During this procedure, several structures are at risk of injury, including the internal carotid artery, glossopharyngeal nerve, and tonsillar artery. The internal carotid artery lies posterior-lateral to the palatine tonsils and is a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding when injured intraoperatively. The superior constrictor muscle lies lateral to the palatine tonsil and immediately deep to these muscles. Damage to this nerve can result in referred otalgia and temporary or rarely permanent alteration in taste.  

Option Analysis

✅ Internal carotid artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. It is more commonly injured during procedures involving the anterior neck due to its more inferior position in the neck.  
❌ External carotid artery:
Incorrect: The external carotid artery branches from the common carotid artery at the fourth or fifth cervical vertebrae level. This structure is not at risk of injury during a tonsillectomy or adenotonsillectomy.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The common carotid artery is not at risk of injury during this procedure, given its inferior location in the neck relative to the pharyngeal and palatine tonsils.  
❌ Internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The Internal jugular vein is a potential source of injury during this procedure; however, it lies lateral to the internal carotid artery. Moreover, this patient presents with evidence of brisk bleeding consistent with an arterial source.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his ear, nose, and throat surgeon for follow-up after having a parotidectomy due to an invasive mucoepidermoid tumor. The patient reports feeling well, but he has noticed intermittent redness and pain over the area of surgery. In addition, the patient says the site “sweats profusely” every time he becomes hungry or is preparing to eat. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the finding demonstrated below. Damage to which of the following nerves is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease process?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of Frey syndrome, a rare neurologic disorder that most commonly occurs following parotid gland surgery. This disease is due to damage and improper regeneration of the auriculotemporal nerve--a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3).

The auriculotemporal nerve contains secretomotor, somatosensory, and vasomotor fibers. The superior component of the nerve provides sensation to the tragus and helix of the ear, the external portion of the tympanic membrane, the posterior temporomandibular joint, and the temple. The inferior component provides autonomic parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland.

During parotid gland surgery, the auriculotemporal nerve can become damaged with subsequent aberrant reinnervation of postganglionic parasympathetic neurons of denervated sweat glands and cutaneous blood vessels. When this occurs, flushing and sweating can occur in response to mastication and salivation, resulting in Frey syndrome. Pain, numbness, or anesthesia may also occur in the distribution of the auriculotemporal nerve.  

Option Analysis

✅ Auriculotemporal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.  
❌ Superior alveolar nerve:
Incorrect: The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve, provides sensory information to the maxillary teeth, gums, and sinus. This patient does not have evidence of a sensory deficit.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient does not have evidence of facial motor deficits.  
❌ Frontal nerve:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp may occur with injury to the frontal nerve or its branches. This is likely to occur with a supraorbital rim fracture.

questions.text: A group of pharmacists compares inhaled anesthetic agents in a series of experiments. The graph below shows a comparison between agents A and B. The x-axis represents the blood-gas partition coefficient, and the y-axis represents the minimum alveolar concentration (MAC). Which of the following best describes the property of anesthetic agent A when compared to agent B?

choices.text: Greater decrease in cerebral blood flow

questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic that prevents movement in 50% of patients responding to a noxious stimulus, such as a surgical incision. An anesthetic’s potency is inversely correlated with its MAC. This relationship is represented mathematically as potency = 1/MAC. MAC is influenced by several factors, including the following:
 
  •  Age – MAC decreases as the patient gets older 
  •  Pregnancy – MAC decreases during pregnancy 
  •  Temperature – MAC decreases as body temperature falls 
  •  Other drugs – MAC decreases if the patient is receiving opioids, other anesthetics, or psychotropic  agents 

Option Analysis

✅ Higher potency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Faster induction:
Incorrect: Anesthetic agents with a high blood-gas partition coefficient have greater solubility in the blood. If an agent has a high coefficient, then a more significant amount of the anesthetic will need to be absorbed by the blood before being passed on to the brain's fatty tissue. As a result, these anesthetics will have a slower induction time.  
❌ Faster equilibration with the brain:
Incorrect: The uptake of an anesthetic depends upon its solubility in the blood. If an agent is highly soluble in blood, then a greater amount of the anesthetic remains in the blood, resulting in delayed saturation of the brain. As a result, it will take longer for the concentration of agent A in the bloodstream to equilibrate with that in the brain.  
❌ Lower blood solubility:
Incorrect: Anesthetic A has a high blood-alveolar coefficient, which is a measure of the solubility of an  inhaled anesthetic in blood. Therefore, agent A has higher blood solubility when compared to agent B.  
❌ Greater decrease in cerebral blood flow:
Incorrect: Inhaled anesthetics, apart from nitrous oxide, increase cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressures. Nitric oxide has a blood-gas partition coefficient of 0.47, whereas agent A has a coefficient exceeding 100. As a result, it is unlikely that agent A is nitric oxide.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting for the past 12-hours. The abdominal pain was initially dull and diffuse but subsequently progressed to a sharp pain in the right lower abdomen. Medical history is significant for epilepsy and asthma. Temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg. Physical examination reveals right lower quadrant abdominal tenderness. Bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with a leftwards shift. An abdominal CT scan is notable for a distended and edematous appendix with surrounding soft tissue stranding. Emergent surgery under general anesthesia is scheduled. Which one of the following anesthetic agents is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute appendicitis, and an emergency appendectomy is planned under general anesthesia. Enflurane is contraindicated in this patient, given her history of epilepsy.

Inhaled anesthetics include nitrous oxide, which acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist, and halogenated anesthetics (e.g., halothane, enflurane, methoxyflurane, desflurane), that act as NMDA receptor antagonists and GABA receptor agonists.

Inhaled anesthetics can cause vasodilation, cardiovascular depression,  respiratory depression, increased cerebral blood flow, and increased intracranial pressure. They also blunt the sympathetic response to hypoxia, so monitoring arterial oxygen saturation after administering these medications is essential. Other side effects include hepatotoxicity (halothane), nephrotoxicity (methoxyflurane), lowered seizure threshold (enflurane), and expansion of trapped gas within body cavities (nitric oxide).

All halogenated anesthetics can cause a life-threatening condition called malignant hyperthermia. The anesthetic agents cause an increased release of calcium stored in muscle cells, resulting in relentless muscle contractions and heat generation. Symptoms of malignant hyperthermia include muscle rigidity, rhabdomyolysis, hyperthermia, metabolic acidosis, and tachycardia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is a parenteral anesthetic that potentiates the effects of GABAA on its receptors. It can cause vasodilation, cardiovascular depression, and propofol infusion syndrome. However, this patient has no contraindications to propofol administration.  
❌ Methoxyflurane:
Incorrect: Methoxyflurane is known to cause nephrotoxicity in susceptible individuals. It is not contraindicated in patients with epilepsy or asthma.  
✅ Enflurane:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Halothane:
Incorrect: Halothane is an anesthetic. Halothane dilates the airways so that it can be used in patients with asthma. However, it is no longer used in developed countries since it can cause severe and potentially fatal hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Ketamine:
Incorrect: Ketamine is a parenteral anesthetic that blocks NMDA receptors. It is known to stimulate the sympathetic nervous system and cause dissociative amnesia. However, it can be safely used in patients with epilepsy and asthma.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate right shoulder pain. The patient was standing on a ladder painting the exterior wall of his house. He lost balance and subsequently fell onto his right shoulder. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg, and pulse is 105/min. Plain radiography reveals a dislocated right shoulder. A closed reduction under an intravenous anesthetic agent is performed. A single bolus of propofol is administered, which provides adequate sedation for the procedure. This medication increases the patient’s risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic that can cause vasodilation and cardiovascular depression, resulting in hypotension.

Common parenteral anesthetics (e.g., thiopental, midazolam, propofol, etomidate) have similar properties and mechanisms of action. They work by either stimulating GABA receptors or increasing their sensitivity to GABA molecules. These anesthetics have rapid onset (20-30 seconds) and a short duration of action. They are commonly used for induction of anesthesia and maintenance in short procedures such as tracheal intubation.

Ketamine, on the other hand, blocks NMDA receptors. Ketamine also has a rapid onset but a longer duration of action.

The side effects of different intravenous anesthetics and their mechanisms of action are summarized below:  

Option Analysis

❌ Bronchoconstriction:
Incorrect: Thiopental is an intravenous anesthetic that can cause mast cells in the airways to release histamine and result in bronchoconstriction. As a result, the medication is not typically administered to patients with a history of asthma.  
❌ Anterograde amnesia:
Incorrect: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine with a slower onset than the other intravenous anesthetics. The medication can lead to anterograde amnesia, unable to form new memories.  
❌ Adrenal suppression:
Incorrect: Etomidate is a common parenteral anesthetic that potentiates the effect of GABAA. It can cause adrenal suppression but is unlikely to cause cardiovascular depression. It is preferred for patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, cerebral vascular disease, or hypovolemia since they are at greater risk for hypotension and its associated complications.  
✅ Cardiovascular depression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Methemoglobinemia:
Incorrect: Select agents (e.g., lidocaine, prilocaine, benzocaine) can cause methemoglobinemia, especially in infants younger than 12 months of age with additional risk factors (e.g., G6PD deficiency, concurrent administration of other methemoglobin-inducing medication). However, propofol is not associated with methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of progressive headaches and vomiting. The patient slipped from the stage during cheerleading practice, two meters (6.6 feet) high. She fell and hit her head on the tile floor. Afterward, she felt confused, vomited twice, and developed a severe headache. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg. During the physical examination, the patient becomes somnolent, does not respond when her name is called, but responds to painful stimuli. A non-contrast head CT reveals an epidural hematoma. The patient is admitted for emergent craniotomy. Which of the following anesthetic agents should be avoided during this patient’s surgery?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive headaches and vomiting after a fall. Imaging reveals an epidural hematoma. These findings are concerning for elevated intracranial pressure.

Ketamine acts by blocking NMDA receptors. It has a rapid onset but a longer duration of action than other intravenous anesthetics. Ketamine increases cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure (ICP). Therefore, patients with elevated ICP (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage, tumor) should avoid the medication.  

Option Analysis

❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic that potentiates the effects of GABAA on its receptors. It can be administered to patients with traumatic brain injury and elevated intracranial pressures. Cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial pressures (ICP) are reduced with induction doses of propofol.  
✅ Ketamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Midazolam:
Incorrect: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that can cause anterograde amnesia, hypotension, and respiratory depression. The medication decreases intracranial pressure and is not contraindicated in individuals with intracranial hemorrhage.  
❌ Methohexital:
Incorrect: Methohexital is a barbiturate that causes a dose-dependent reduction in cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial pressures (ICP). In addition, methohexital does not affect cerebral autoregulation of blood flow in response to carbon dioxide levels. As a result, the medication can be safely given to patients with elevated intracranial pressure.  
❌ Etomidate:
Incorrect: Etomidate is an induction agent that decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial pressures (ICP). As a result, the medication can be safely administered to individuals with elevated intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by local paramedics after a motor vehicle accident. The patient is conscious and can provide a history. Medical history is significant for major depressive disorder and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include sertraline and metformin. She does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg. Radiography reveals a displaced fracture of the left femur. The patient undergoes surgical repair with general anesthesia. Fifteen minutes after the surgery begins, the patient’s temperature is 39.0°C (102°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg. Generalized muscle rigidity is noted in all four extremities. Which of the following best characterizes the pharmacological agent used to manage this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with muscle rigidity, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and tachypnea shortly after administration of anesthesia and initiation of surgery. These findings are most suggestive of malignant hyperthermia (MH).

MH is a rare but life-threatening condition that often arises secondary to mutations in voltage-sensitive ryanodine receptors (RYR1 gene) that result in the release of Ca2+ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum on exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. The sudden release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum removes the inhibition of troponin and causes sustained muscle contractions. The sustained muscle contractions lead to increased adenosine triphosphatase activity, resulting in an uncontrolled hypermetabolic state characterized by significantly increased oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production, severe lactic acidosis, hyperthermia, and sometimes rhabdomyolysis.

Treatment involves discontinuation of the causative agent and immediate administration of intravenous dantrolene. Dantrolene is a hydantoin derivative that directly interferes with muscle contraction by blockading ryanodine receptors and inhibiting Ca2+ ion release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

MH susceptible individuals should not have anesthesia with triggering agents and are advised to avoid exercise in excessive heat or humidity, as these environmental factors may trigger an episode.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ryanodine receptor antagonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ α2-receptor agonist:
Incorrect: Tizanidine, an α2-receptor agonist, is effective in managing muscle spasticity associated with multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and cerebral palsy. In contrast, this patient’s muscle rigidity is most likely due to malignant hyperthermia. Tizanidine is not used in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ GABAB receptor agonist:
Incorrect: Baclofen, a GABAB receptor agonist, is effective in managing muscle spasticity and dystonia. However, this patient’s combination of diffuse muscle rigidity, fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea suggests malignant hyperthermia. Baclofen is not used to treat malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ 5-HT2 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine is a 5-HT2 receptor antagonist used to treat serotonin syndrome, which may occur as a complication of antidepressant use. While serotonin syndrome may also present with hyperthermia and muscle rigidity, it usually occurs after a recent increase in the dose/frequency of antidepressants or coadministration of another serotonergic drug. The absence of other typical features of serotonin syndrome, such as clonus or mydriasis, suggests an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Muscarinic receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Benztropine is a muscarinic antagonist used to treat Parkinsonian and extrapyramidal symptoms. It can also be used in the setting of a mild neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which is a rare but serious complication of antipsychotic use and classically presents with mental status changes, muscular rigidity, and autonomic instability. However, this patient is not on antipsychotic drugs, thus making neuroleptic malignant syndrome unlikely.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the local paramedics after a motor vehicle collision. He was wearing a seat belt while driving, and his car was hit by a truck from the left side. The patient reports severe abdominal pain radiating to the left shoulder, nausea, and dizziness. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows an area of ecchymosis over the left lower chest wall, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and dullness to percussion over the left upper quadrant. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) reveals intraperitoneal free fluid. CT scan with contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is performed, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient suffered a blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) during a motor vehicle accident, has diffuse abdominal tenderness, left shoulder pain (Kehr’s sign), and signs of shock (hypotension, tachycardia). This together with free intraperitoneal fluid on Focused assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST), left lower chest ecchymosis, and left upper quadrant dullness to percussion is consistent with splenic laceration.   

The spleen lies within the intraperitoneal cavity in close proximity to the stomach (intraperitoneal), colon (transverse: intraperitoneal, descending: retroperitoneal), left kidney, and pancreas (both retroperitoneal). It is one of the most commonly injured intra-abdominal organs following blunt trauma. In most adults, the spleen does not extend inferiorly past the rib cage, unless it is otherwise enlarged. The spectrum of its injury can range from contusion or subcapsular hematoma to laceration and intraperitoneal bleeding (due to high vascularity).  

Patients can present with abdominal pain, tenderness in the epigastrium, pain in the left flank, and sharp left shoulder pain in cases of minor injury. Whereas, a ruptured spleen may result in massive intra-abdominal bleeding and should therefore be treated as a medical emergency.  

Option Analysis

❌ Duodenal hematoma:
Incorrect: Rapid compression of the abdomen against the vertebral column can crush the duodenum, potentially causing duodenal hematoma. It does not cause free intraperitoneal fluid as the bleeding remains confined to the duodenal wall. Moreover, this patient suffered trauma from the left side of his vehicle.  
❌ Abdominal aortic rupture:
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic rupture is frequently fatal due to the profuse bleeding that results from the rupture, and many patients die of examination before reaching the hospital. The minority of the patients who survive is most likely due to the containment of the blood in the retroperitoneal space. Moreover, a blunt trauma from the left side is less likely to cause aortic rupture.  
❌ Liver laceration:
Incorrect: Blunt force mechanisms such as motor vehicle accidents are a common cause of liver laceration, and FAST may show free intraperitoneal fluid. Tenderness, however, is located over the right upper quadrant (rather than LUQ as seen in this patient).  
❌ Diaphragmatic injury:
Incorrect: Diaphragmatic injury can occur after blunt trauma due to a sudden increase in intra abdominal pressure. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Free intraperitoneal fluid on FAST in this patient is suggestive of splenic laceration.
✅ Splenic laceration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient complains of pain on the left side of the chest that gets worse on deep breathing. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising and tenderness over the left posterior chest wall. The spinal range of motion is normal, and there is no midline tenderness. The gross motor and neurological examination is within normal limits. Plain chest radiograph reveals a left-sided 12th rib fracture. This patient is at increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient with a left 12th rib fracture is at risk of left kidney laceration.   

The chest comprises 12 rib bones on each side of the body. Each rib attaches to the spine at the back of the body and then travels around to the front of the chest. The top 7 ribs attach to the sternum, the 8th to 10th ribs attach to the ribs above via cartilage, and the 11th and 12th ribs are known as ‘floating’ ribs as they are unattached at the front of the chest.   

Rib fractures are the most common injury sustained in blunt thoracic trauma. Fractures may cause localized pain, crepitus, pain with inspiration, dyspnea, and may even cause pneumothorax or hemothorax. The left 12th rib overlies the parietal pleura medially and the left kidney laterally. Therefore, the distal tip of the left rib can displace into the retroperitoneum and lacerate the left kidney.   

Option Analysis

❌ Brachial plexus:
Incorrect: The brachial plexus extends from the spinal cord, through the cervicoaxillary canal in the neck, over the first rib, and into the armpit. It is susceptible to injury in cases of 1st-3rd rib fractures.  
❌ Subclavian artery:
Incorrect: The subclavian artery travels laterally, passing between anterior and middle scalene muscles, with the anterior scalene on its anterior side and the middle scalene on its posterior. As the subclavian artery crosses the lateral border of the first rib, it becomes the axillary artery. It would not be affected by 12th rib fractures.  
✅ Left kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pancreas:
Incorrect: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that stretches from behind the stomach to the left upper abdomen near the spleen. It overlies the body of the second lumbar vertebrae. It is most susceptible to injury with a crushing abdominal trauma.   
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: The spleen is underneath the left part of the diaphragm and the ninth, tenth, and eleventh ribs on the left side. It is less likely to be injured in 12th rib fracture.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he slipped and fell from a 14-foot ladder onto his right lower extremity. Radiographs reveal a right-sided complete transverse fracture of the distal tibia and fibula diaphysis. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has a 25-pack-year smoking history. The patient is subsequently managed with external fixation and discharged home. The patient returns to the clinic seven months later for evaluation of persistent pain and a clicking sensation at the level of the fracture. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a visible deformity of the right lower extremity. Sensation is intact bilaterally. A current x-ray of the right lower extremity is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced by Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of persistent pain at the fracture site and x-ray findings of callus formation around the fracture margins and anterior and internal angulation is suggestive of fracture nonunion.  Fracture nonunion manifests with x-ray findings that demonstrate persistent radiolucent lines at the fracture site, with or without callus formation. Complications of malunion included degenerative joint disease, persistent pain, as well as deformity.  

The tibia, particularly its distal third, is more prone to delayed union or nonunion due to lower blood supply and muscle coverage. In addition, compartment syndrome is a frequent concern in tibia fractures and can occur in crush injuries without fractures and in open fractures. The hallmark of compartment syndrome is severe pain out of proportion to the injury.  

Option Analysis

❌ Complex regional pain syndrome:
Incorrect: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is a rare chronic pain complication of unknown cause following trauma. CRPS is characterized by pain out of proportion to the original injury with swelling, pain, and vasomotor disturbances as the hallmarks of this syndrome. X-ray often shows patchy demineralization of bone.  
✅ Fracture nonunion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Common peroneal nerve compression:
Incorrect: The common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury as it courses laterally around the neck of the fibula. Injury at this location presents with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion as well as sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin and between first and second toes. This patient’s injury occured in the distal tibia/fibula.   
❌ Skin and soft tissue infection:
Incorrect: Skin and soft tissue infections usually present with erythema, swelling and pain, often associated with fever, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammatory markers. It would not explain this patient’s prominent callus formation surrounding the tibial non union.  
❌ Myositis ossificans:
Incorrect: Myositis ossificans occur when calcifications develop within muscle tissue. It can occur as a complication of fractures, especially supracondylar fractures of the humerus. It would not explain this patient’s prominent callus formation surrounding the tibial non union.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of right ankle pain. The patient was playing football when she was struck by an opposing player causing her ankle to evert. She immediately felt an intense, sharp pain about the ankle and heard a “snap.” The patient was unable to ambulate off the field. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling around the right ankle and tenderness over the medial malleolus. Sensory examination is within normal limits. Peripheral pulses are equal bilaterally. A right ankle x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of ankle pain following an eversion injury, in combination with radiographic evidence of a right distal fibula and medial malleolus fracture is consistent with a bimalleolar fracture (Pott’s fracture).  

Ankle fractures most often result from a twisting mechanism of injury to the ankle. Inversion injuries typically result in distraction (stretching) of the lateral ankle structures with compression of the medial structures. In contrast, eversion injuries result in medial distraction with lateral compression. The structures that are distracted during the injury tend to fracture or tear before the compressed structures.    

A Pott’s fracture is a bimalleolar fracture (injury to both the medial and the lateral malleolus) that results from a combined abduction external rotation from an eversion force. A Pott's fracture often occurs in combination with a dislocation of the ankle or other fractures of the foot, ankle, or lower leg.  

Another type of fracture, called a trimalleolar fracture, occurs when a bimalleolar fracture occurs in conjunction with a fracture of the posterior malleolus. They have a higher risk of complications than bimalleolar fractures and more result from high energy mechanisms of injury. Both bimalleolar and trimalleolar fractures are considered unstable and require operative fixation.  


Trimalleolar fracture 
Reproduced from Radiopedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior talofibular ligament tear:
Incorrect: Ankle sprains can have a similar clinical presentation to that of an ankle fracture such as swelling and pain about the ankle. Plain radiographs in these patients are typically normal.   
❌ Fifth metatarsal fracture:
Incorrect: Pain, swelling, and tenderness over the lateral border of the forefoot is consistent with a fifth metatarsal fracture. This patient has medial malleolar tenderness and swelling.   
✅ Bimalleolar fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute compartment syndrome:
Incorrect: Compartment syndrome is an orthopedic emergency that results from increased pressure within an enclosed fascial space. Patients present with severe pain that worsens with passive stretching of the affected muscles, paresthesias, as well as sensory and motor deficits. This patient’s medial malleolar tenderness and x-ray findings is suggestive of a bimalleolar fracture.  
❌ Achilles tendon rupture:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius and the soleus tendon combine to form the Achilles tendon. Its rupture can occur during strenuous physical activities that involve sudden pivots or rapid acceleration. Tenderness and ecchymosis of the Achilles tendon is noted in affected patients.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the hospital for a right inguinal hernia repair. His past medical history is notable for hypertension and major depressive disorder, for which he takes lisinopril and fluoxetine. The patient has not had any prior surgeries. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 138/81 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. In the operating room, the patient is given succinylcholine and isoflurane. Shortly after that, the patient develops a temperature of 39.7°C (103°F) and pulse of 110/min. Physical examination reveals diffuse muscle rigidity. No clonus or hyperreflexia is present. The patient is started on medication for the treatment of his symptoms. Which of the following best describes this medication’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Inhibition of acetylcholine breakdown within neuronal synapses
Blockade of ryanodine receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Activation of GABA receptors within the spinal cord

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, tachycardia, and diffuse muscle rigidity after receiving succinylcholine and isoflurane. He likely has malignant hyperthermia, which can be treated by discontinuing the triggering agent(s) and initiating dantrolene therapy.

Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that acts on the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscle cells.  Calcium is stored in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells and induces muscle contraction when released to the cytoplasm. Dantrolene inhibits ryanodine receptor channels, which prevents the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. As a result, the medication can reduce muscle contractions and associated muscle spasms.

Dantrolene is primarily used to treat malignant hyperthermia, wherein massive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum leads to fever and excessive muscle rigidity. The condition is usually triggered by inhaled anesthetics (e.g., halothane, isoflurane) and succinylcholine in susceptible patients. Furthermore, dantrolene can treat the neuroleptic malignant syndrome, a potentially fatal side effect of antipsychotic medications, and similarly presents with fever, muscle rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic dysfunction.

Dantrolene is generally well tolerated and has only minor side effects such as excessive muscle weakness, dizziness, and nausea/vomiting.

Option Analysis

❌ Antagonism of histamine-1 receptors:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine acts as an antagonist at histamine-1 receptors. The medication can treat serotonin syndrome, which presents with fever, altered mental status, and clonus. In contrast, this patient developed diffuse muscle rigidity after receiving succinylcholine and isoflurane, more consistent with malignant hyperthermia. Cyproheptadine is not used to treat malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ Inhibition of acetylcholine breakdown within neuronal synapses:
Incorrect: Physostigmine inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine and increasing acetylcholine levels within neuronal synapses. The medication can treat anticholinergic toxicity, which can manifest with hyperthermia, tachycardia, altered mental status, flushed skin, and dry mouth. However, anticholinergic toxicity would not account for the diffuse muscle rigidity present in this patient.  
✅ Blockade of ryanodine receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Activation of GABA receptors within the spinal cord:
Incorrect: Baclofen is a muscle relaxant that binds and activates GABA receptors within the spinal cord. Baclofen can be used to treat muscle spasticity secondary to conditions such as cerebral palsy or multiple sclerosis. However, baclofen would be ineffective in treating malignant hyperthermia.  
❌ Activation of α2-receptors:
Incorrect: Tizanidine is a muscle relaxant that can treat muscle spasticity arising from cerebral palsy and multiple sclerosis. In contrast, this patient presents with hyperthermia, tachycardia, and diffuse muscle rigidity after receiving succinylcholine and isoflurane, which is more consistent with malignant hyperthermia. Tizanidine is ineffective for treating malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for left shoulder pain after a fall. The patient was skiing when he was accidentally hit from the right side and fell on his left shoulder and outstretched left hand. The patient did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a man supporting his left arm with his right hand. There is tenderness and swelling at the proximal humerus. An x-ray of the left shoulder is shown below. Axillary nerve injury is suspected. Which of the following actions will be impaired due to this nerve injury?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia:

choices.text: Abduction and adduction of the fingers

questions.solution:
This patient’s left arm x-ray is consistent with a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, which is an injury pattern that occurs below the greater tubercle and lesser tubercle, and above the deltoid tuberosity.  

The surgical neck is fractured much more frequently than the anatomical neck of the humerus and commonly results from a fall on the outstretched hand. It is a fracture seen in older patients particularly those with osteoporosis. Symptoms include pain over the proximal shoulder that radiates the arm's length and swelling. The axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery are at the structures that are at most risk of injury with this fracture pattern.    

The axillary nerve carries fibers from the C5-C6 branch of the brachial plexus, where it courses deep to the axilla below the shoulder joint and the surgical neck of the posterior humerus. Patients with injury to this nerve present with loss of sensation over the lateral upper arm and weakness with shoulder abduction (due to denervation of the deltoid muscle). Damage to the posterior circumflex humeral artery can lead to avascular necrosis of the humeral head.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elbow, wrist, and finger extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions of the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can be injured with midshaft fractures of the humerus. This patient has a fracture of the neck of the humerus.
