❌ Abduction and adduction of the fingers :
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve is susceptible to injury in patients with fractures of the hook of hamate of the hand which can be seen in athletes. Ulnar nerve injury can cause inability to abduct the index and little fingers and inability to adduct the thumb. This patient’s presentation and radiograph are consistent with a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus.   
❌ Wrist flexion and thumb opposition:
Incorrect: Proximal median nerve injury can result from supracondylar fractures of the distal humerus at the elbow and can lead to the inability to flex the wrist and oppose the thumb. This patient has a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus.  
✅ Arm abduction at the shoulder :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Forearm flexion and supination :
Incorrect: Upper nerve trunk compression can injure the musculocutaneous nerve. Patients typically present with loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (>15 degrees) and loss of sensation over the lateral arm. Compression of the musculocutaneous nerve lower in the arm at the coracobrachialis muscle, can lead to weakness with forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation following a fall and associated right arm pain. The patient was rock climbing when he lost grip and fell approximately 3 m (6.5 ft) onto boulders below. The patient landed on his right arm and heard a snapping sound upon impact. He did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates swelling and bruising of the right upper arm and inability to extend the right wrist and the fingers of the right hand, and sensory loss over the posterior forearm and dorsolateral hand. Nerve injury at which of the following locations is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with radial nerve injury, likely due to a midshaft fracture of the humerus.  

Midshaft humerus fractures in young patients commonly result from a direct blow or a bending force applied to the humerus. Older patients can experience this type of injury with a fall onto an outstretched hand. Patients typically present with severe pain in the mid-arm but may also have referred pain to the shoulder or elbow. Swelling and ecchymosis are often apparent shortly after the injury. The radial nerve and deep brachial artery are two structures that can be injured with this injury pattern.  

The radial nerve carries fibers from C5-T1 and serves as a terminal branch of the brachial plexus. It provides motor innervation to the forearm extensors at the elbow and most hand extensors at the wrist. Sensory innervation includes the posterior forearm and most of the back of the hand, except for the back of the little finger and the adjacent half of the ring finger (innervated by the ulnar nerve).Injury to the radial nerve results in weakness of wrist, finger, and thumb extension and elbow supination . A wrist drop can often be seen with this type of injury.  



Option Analysis

❌ Carpal tunnel :
Incorrect: Repetitive hand and wrist use can lead to compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel. This typically results in pain and paraesthesias of the first 3½ digits of the affected hand. This patient neurologic deficit is suggestive of radial nerve injury.   
✅ Mid-shaft of the humerus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical neck of the humerus:
Incorrect:  Fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus typically result from a fall on an outstretched hand. This fracture pattern is most likely to damage the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery rather than the radial nerve. Axillary nerve injury leads to loss of sensation and abduction at the shoulder.  
❌ Hook of hamate :
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve can be injured at the hook of hamate from a fracture there. The ulnar nerve enters the wrist via Guyon’s canal bordered by the hook of the hamate. Patients typically present with sensory loss over the medial 1½ digits, hypothenar eminence, and weakness with wrist flexion/adduction, finger adduction/abduction, and flexion of fourth/fifth digits.  
❌ Coracobrachialis muscle:
Incorrect: The coracobrachialis muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. The nerve pierces the coracobrachialis muscle and can be injured by a compression injury of this muscle (e.g., from weight lifting). Injury to this nerve results in weakness with forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting for one day.  He has not had a bowel movement or passed gas for 24 hours. He has an incisional hernia at the site of a previous cholecystectomy. He states that the hernia typically reduces on its own, but he feels it has been “stuck” in place today. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and blood pressure is 162/88 mmHg. On exam, he is in significant distress due to the pain. Examination of the abdominal wall reveals a tender bulging mass in the right upper quadrant at the site of the scar. The overlying skin appears dusky with surrounding erythema. During the assessment, the patient has an episode of bilious emesis. A nasogastric tube is placed. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of oral ciprofloxacin and observation
Administration of IV piperacillin-tazobactam and observation

questions.solution:
This patient’s tender, bulging abdominal mass with overlying skin changes in the area of a prior surgical incision is indicative of a strangulated incisional hernia. Moreover, this patient has evidence of vomiting and lack of gas and stool passage indicating an acute bowel obstruction.  Emergent surgical consultation is indicated, along with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and IV fluids.

When a loop of bowel becomes trapped in an incisional hernia, blood supply to the bowel wall becomes compromised resulting in a strangulated hernia, which is a surgical emergency. Strangulated hernias are typically visible and palpable in the wall of the abdomen, and the overlying skin may appear dusky and erythematous. When clinical and physical exam findings suggest a strangulated hernia, caution should be taken during the abdominal exam, and manual reduction of the herniais contraindicated since the introduction of necrotic bowel into the abdominal cavity can lead to life-threatening abdominal sepsis. Symptoms of associated bowel obstruction including nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, and lack of flatus may be present.

A strangulated hernia is an emergent condition that requires prompt surgical consultation, as well as medical management and supportive care.  This includes stabilization of the patient, IV fluid resuscitation as needed, followed by initiation of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and placement of a nasogastric tube for decompression if an acute bowel obstruction is present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Manual reduction of the hernia:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a strangulated hernia which may contain necrotic bowel tissue, therefore manual reduction is contraindicated since necrotic bowel contents can be released into the abdominal cavity.  
❌ CT of the abdomen/pelvis:
Incorrect: With clinical evidence of a strangulated hernia, surgery should be consulted immediately.  A CT of the abdomen and pelvis may be incorporated into the pre-surgical management, but should not delay the emergent consultation.  
❌ Administration of oral ciprofloxacin and observation:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of an acute bowel obstruction, and oral administration of medication is contraindicated. Broad-spectrum empiric IV antibiotics should be given in addition to calling an emergent surgery consultation.  
❌ Administration of IV piperacillin-tazobactam and observation:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a strangulated hernia. Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics are appropriate, but emergent surgical consultation is required for definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a painful abdominal lump for the last six months. He states the lump becomes painful when he lifts heavy objects. He has not had fevers, nausea, or vomiting, and his bowel movements are regular. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes and his last HbA1c was 9.1%. He travels for work and often forgets to bring his medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. Exam reveals a 3.1 cm soft, non-tender hernia over the lower midline of the abdominal wall which cannot be reduced. There are no skin changes over the affected area. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Elective surgical repair following hyperglycemic control
Elective surgical repair within one week
Referral to the emergency department for surgical consultation
Watchful waiting and surgical repair only if signs of strangulation occur

questions.solution:
This patient presents with six months of symptoms and a non-reducible bulge in the abdominal wall, consistent with a chronically incarcerated ventral hernia.  Elective surgical repair is appropriate once medical optimization of modifiable risk factors (i.e. poorly controlled diabetes) has been achieved.

Most ventral hernias require surgical repair due to the high lifetime risk of complications when left untreated.  Elective repair is appropriate for symptomatic reducible hernias and for hernias that have been chronically incarcerated over weeks, months, or years.  Due to the elective nature of these repairs, modifiable risk factors such as smoking, poorly controlled diabetes, alcohol use, severe obesity, and CHF should be optimized prior to surgery to reduce the risk of complications.

Small, asymptomatic hernias may be managed with watchful waiting in patients who wish to avoid surgery.  It is reasonable to attempt to reduce an acutely incarcerated hernia which has been present for only a few hours; however, the likelihood of success is low and given the risk of strangulation, urgent surgical consultation should be pursued if reduction fails. Emergent surgical consultation is essential when a strangulated hernia is suspected, as patients with necrotic bowel may become septic.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elective surgical repair following hyperglycemic control:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elective surgical repair within one week:
Incorrect: This patient should be medically optimized prior to elective surgery given the chronic nature of the hernia and absence of strangulation. Undergoing surgery while his diabetes is poorly controlled would place him at an increased risk for surgical complications, therefore time and care should be taken to get his diabetes under control.  
❌ Urgent surgical repair within 12 hours:
Incorrect: Given the chronic nature of the hernia and the fact that there are no signs or symptoms of strangulation, an elective repair is appropriate after medical optimization.  
❌ Referral to the emergency department for surgical consultation:
Incorrect: Emergency department evaluation with same-day surgical consultation would be indicated for an acute incarcerated hernia or if signs of strangulation were present.  This patient has reported mild symptoms for six months and signs of strangulation are absent. Elective repair following medical optimization is appropriate.  
❌ Watchful waiting and surgical repair only if signs of strangulation occur:
Incorrect:  An incarcerated hernia requires surgical repair.  This patient’s hyperglycemia can be treated which will place him at a lower surgical risk.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old is undergoing anesthetic induction for a coronary artery bypass operation. The patient is given inhaled anesthetic gas, intubated, sedated with propofol, and placed on the ventilator. While the surgeon is preparing for thoracotomy, the anesthesia team initiates placement of a triple lumen catheter in the right internal jugular vein. The patient receives an injection of bupivacaine between the heads of the sternocleidomastoid for analgesia, and needle aspiration is performed under ultrasound guidance to confirm placement in the internal jugular vein. During cannulation, the patient is noted to become progressively cyanotic. The patient's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 132/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 84% on 100% FIO2. Physical examination demonstrates pale, gray skin, lips, and nail beds. Cardiopulmonary exam demonstrates bilateral breath sounds and normal S1, S2 without murmurs, rubs or gallops. A stat electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus tachycardia and an image of the patient's blood gas sample is demonstrated below.   Which of the following best describes the most likely precipitant of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Oxidation of iron in heme from Ferrous (Fe2+) to ferric (Fe3+) state
Thromboembolism originating in the deep femoral vein
Inhibition of voltage gated Na+ channels and cardiac conduction blockade
Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air spaces
Mediastinal shift and impairment of venous outflow

questions.solution:
This patient rapidly develops cyanosis, tachycardia, and hypoxemia despite adequate ventilation. An arterial blood gas sample demonstrates the classic chocolate colored blood, indicative of methemoglobinemia, a known side effect of local anesthetics.   

Local anesthetics, while generally safe, do carry a range of side effects that carry significant morbidity and mortality. These medications are commonly used for nerve blocks, minor skin procedures, or prior to placement of indwelling catheters due to their ability to reversibly block voltage gated sodium channels, thereby impeding conduction in pain fibers.  

Side effects of local anesthetics include both central nervous system and cardiovascular toxicity. In particular, the medication bupivacaine is well known for inducing CNS depression at low doses and CNS excitotoxicity such as tremor, convulsions or seizures at higher doses. The cardiovascular side effect profile results from the ability of local anesthetics to bind fast Na+ channels in cardiac myocytes--resulting in reduction of cardiac contractility and arrhythmia generation. The one exception to this cardiac side effect profile is cocaine, which actually stimulates myocytes and increases contractility. Lastly, all local anesthetics (especially benzocaine) are known to induce methemoglobinemia when injected or applied topically. Exposure to the anesthetic agent results in the oxidation of iron found in heme from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state. The ferric form of heme cannot bind oxygen, resulting in profound cyanosis, and an inability to oxygenate despite adequate ventilation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Oxidation of iron in heme from Ferrous (Fe2+) to ferric (Fe3+) state:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thromboembolism originating in the deep femoral vein:
Incorrect: A massive pulmonary embolism presents with hypotension, tachycardia and failure to oxygenate despite adequate ventilation. This patient is without unilateral lower extremity swelling making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, the change in color of blood to chocolate brown is indicative of methemoglobinemia.   
❌ Inhibition of voltage gated Na+ channels and cardiac conduction blockade:
Incorrect: Local anesthetics have been known to induce cardiac arrhythmias via fast sodium channel blockade and induction of subsequent cardiac arrhythmia. This patient’s telemetry strip demonstrates sinus tachycardia.    
❌ Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air spaces:
Incorrect: ARDS or acute respiratory distress syndrome is characterized by leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air space. This disease is characterized by bilateral, interstitial, non-cardiogenic edema following an acute insult and a PaO2/FIO2 <300.  
❌ Mediastinal shift and impairment of venous outflow:
Incorrect: A tension pneumothorax can result in mediastinal shift and subsequent impairment of venous outflow. Tension pneumothorax presents with diminished breath sounds, jugular venous distension, hypotension, hypoxia, and tachycardia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of trauma to his right thumb. The patient was playing with his brother when he accidentally slammed the door on the patient’s thumb. Physical exam shows the patient has an avulsion injury of the right thumbnail. In order to repair the injury without significant pain, the emergency physician performs a digital block via injection of xylocaine at the base of the right thumb. Which of the following types of nerve fibers anesthetized during this procedure are most susceptible to blockade by the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient undergoes a peripheral nerve block with xylocaine for repair of a nail avulsion injury to the right thumb. When considering the type of nerve fibers best anesthetized by local anesthetics, the size factor predominates over myelination such that small myelinated fibers are most sensitive to these medications.      

Local anesthetics inlude medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Local anesthetics are most effective at blocking fast firing nerves--e.g. smaller fibers. Myelinated fibers are blocked more easily than unmyelinated fibers. In the setting of two fibers with equal degrees of myelination, the smaller fiber will be more sensitive to local anesthesia.      

In accordance with this pattern, the degree of sensation loss after administration of local anesthetics includes pain first, followed by temperature, touch, and finally pressure. In addition, pain firing fibers tend to be located more superficially in tissues, such that fibers located in the periphery of a thick nerve bundle are blocked faster than those in the core because they are exposed to higher concentrations of anesthetic.  

Option Analysis

✅  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  2 µm  ++++ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Diameter  Degree of Myelination  15 µm ++++ :
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A alpha nerve fibers, which conduct proprioception and motor movements. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall low sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  8 µm  ++++ :
Incorrect:  These measurements are indicative of Type A beta nerve fibers, which conduct the sensation of touch and pressure. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  6 µm +++:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A gamma nerve fibers, which innervate muscle spindles. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  .5 µm-:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type C dorsal root ganglion fibers, which conduct pain. This type of pain fiber is small and unmyelinated, and has a high sensitivity to blockade via administration of local anesthetics. However, given the anatomic location of the aforementioned procedure, these fibers would not be blocked.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for evaluation of a boil on his upper back. The patient initially had a small comeodone that he scratched, and it subsequently progressed to become larger and more painful over the past week. The patient has a history of multiple sclerosis and takes baclofen daily for treatment of muscle spasms. The patient has an allergy to tetracaine, and broke out in hives when having a laceration repaired several years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm x 2 cm fluctuant abscess over the thoracic spine. The patient is subsequently injected with bupivacaine subcutaneously, directly over the area of highest fluctuance in preparation for incision and drainage. A stab incision is made over the anesthetized area; however, the patient reports significant pain despite administration of bupivacaine. Which of the following best describes the etiology of the phenomenon described above?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of an upper back abscess and has a local amide anesthetic injected prior to incision and drainage. Unfortunately, this provider did not adequately assess for post-injection analgesia – which was poorly controlled in this patient, likely due to injection into acidic tissue.    

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials.   

These medications are inherently weak organic bases that are composed of charged and uncharged forms when in solution–only the uncharged forms are able to exert effects on sodium channels. In acidic solutions (such as in infected tissue), lower pH reduces the proportion of anesthetic in the uncharged form according to Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, resulting in decreased ability for the anesthetic to penetrate the neuronal membrane. Ultimately, this results in more anesthetic required to anesthetize this type of tissue. 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased acidity of injected tissue :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Localized allergic reaction :
Incorrect: While this patient has an allergy to ester anesthetics, he is provided with an amide anesthetic, bupivacaine. This patient's clinical presentation is not consistent with an allergy reaction.  
❌ Medication interaction :
Incorrect: Baclofen does not interact with administration of local anesthetics.   
❌ Poor injection technique :
Incorrect: The provider described in this vignette used adequate technique for local anesthesia--the issue was likely injecting an insufficient amount of anesthetic.   
❌ Degradation of injected medication :
Incorrect: Local anesthetics are not degraded when injected into acidic tissue--they can degrade over time if left out, especially in sunlight environments.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for one month of worsening left breast pain, itching, and swelling. She is also experiencing new back pain but has not had fevers, chills, or night sweats. She is not pregnant or breastfeeding. Family history includes breast cancer in her mother at age 42. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. Chaperoned exam of the left breast reveals a 12 cm area of erythema, warmth, and tenderness laterally, without fluctuance. Edema with dimpling of the skin is noted, and the nipple is flattened compared to the right side. There is left axillary lymphadenopathy. Labs reveal a white blood cell count of 5.1 × 109/L and an alkaline phosphatase level of 161 U/L. There is no fluid collection seen on ultrasound.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with breast pain, itching, and swelling, with associated erythema, warmth, edema, peau d’orange, and nipple retraction. These findings are suspicious for inflammatory breast cancer. Additionally, new back pain in the presence of an elevated alkaline phosphatase level is concerning for metastatic disease. Additionally, a specific genetic mutation associated with inflammatory breast cancer has not been identified; however, patients often have a family history of breast cancer, as seen in this case.

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a highly aggressive form of cancer that usually presents with erythema, warmth, tenderness, and edema over at least one-third of the breast and progresses rapidly over several months. Patients with inflammatory breast cancer may experience itching, pain, swelling, or firmness in the breast with or without local lymphadenopathy. The classic skin finding of peau d’orange is caused by edema with dimpling of the skin that resembles the peel of an orange and is highly suggestive of IBC. Nipple changes such as flattening or retraction can occur, and a palpable mass may or may not be present. Fever can occur as well. It is not uncommon for a patient with inflammatory breast cancer to have been initially diagnosed as having mastitis; therefore, any failure of treatment of a breast infection should prompt consideration of IBC.

Laboratory findings in inflammatory breast cancer are nonspecific but may include elevated alkaline phosphatase, especially if bone metastases are present, and elevated LFTs if liver metastases occur. Leukocyte count is typically within normal limits or it may be slightly elevated.

Option Analysis

✅ Inflammatory breast cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Breast abscess:
Incorrect: Patients with breast abscesses typically have systemic symptoms including fever, leukocytosis, and a fluid collection seen on ultrasound. In addition, the presence of peau d’orange and the elevated alkaline phosphatase level are highly suggestive of inflammatory breast cancer with metastatic disease.  
❌ Intraductal papilloma:
Incorrect: An intraductal papilloma is a benign breast tumor within the milk ducts typically located behind the nipple. It can present as a palpable breast mass with nipple discharge but does not typically cause overlying skin changes. This patient has signs of inflammatory breast cancer including erythema, warmth, edema, peau d’orange, and nipple flattening.  
❌ Cutaneous lupus erythematosus:
Incorrect: Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (CLE) presents with red, circular, or “coin-like,” scaly lesions on the skin which may be painful or itchy. This patient’s area of confluent erythema and warmth, with the presence of peau d’orange, is characteristic of inflammatory breast cancer.  
❌ Sezary syndrome:
Incorrect: Sezary syndrome (cutaneous T cell lymphoma) can cause erythroderma. The rash typically covers a large area of the body. This patient’s focal symptoms over the breast, with the presence of peau d’Orange, are characteristic of inflammatory breast cancer.

questions.text:
A 42-year old woman presents to the primary care office after being treated in urgent care for breast pain one week ago. She is on day seven of antibiotics for presumed mastitis and has not had improvement in the redness or swelling of her right breast. She has not had fevers, chills, or night sweats. Family history includes breast cancer in her mother at age 46. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg. Chaperoned exam reveals edema, warmth, and tenderness over the medial and inferior portions of the right breast. The area is firm to palpation without fluctuance. Skin changes can be seen in the image below. Ultrasound shows thickening and edema of the skin without an underlying fluid collection or mass.  Which of the following tests will confirm the underlying diagnosis?
 

Image by Levine PH, Zolfaghari L, Young H, Hafi M, Cannon T, Ganesan C, Veneroso C, Brem R, Sherman M - Cancers (2010), cropped from original, is licensed under CC BY 3.0 DEED.  Reproduced from Open-i.

choices.text: Core needle biopsy with skin punch biopsy

questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of erythema, edema, warmth, tenderness, and peau d’orange of the breast that has not responded to antibiotics; therefore she likely has inflammatory breast cancer.  Core needle biopsy with at least two skin punch biopsies is the best test to provide a definitive diagnosis.  Ultrasound and mammographic imaging can be performed to assist in the evaluation.

The presentation of inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) has considerable overlap with that of acute mastitis, and it can be difficult to distinguish between the two conditions.  When presumed mastitis is not improving with antibiotics, further investigation is warranted with breast imaging and tissue biopsy.  Diagnostic mammography (and screening mammography of the unaffected breast) and ultrasound are the initial imaging studies.  A discrete mass or the presence of calcifications is highly concerning for IBC.  Non-specific changes including skin thickening, increased breast density, or evidence of edema or trabeculation may also be seen, but both infection and breast cancer may cause these findings.  Non-specific findings or normal results on imaging should not deter a biopsy when inflammatory breast cancer is suspected clinically.

Laboratory evaluation with a CBC, CMP, LFTs, and alkaline phosphatase level should be part of the workup of suspected IBC.  Significant leukocytosis on laboratory examination is more suggestive of acute mastitis, while the finding of significant elevation of alkaline phosphatase or abnormal LFTs is more consistent with inflammatory breast cancer. Imaging tests and blood work alone are not sufficient to make a definitive diagnosis given the overlap of similar findings in both conditions.  Core needle biopsy, with at least two skin punch biopsies, is indicated when inflammatory breast cancer is suspected.  

Option Analysis

✅ Core needle biopsy with skin punch biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ White blood cell count:
Incorrect:  Significant leukocytosis is more common in acute mastitis than in inflammatory breast cancer, but an elevated white blood cell count can occur in either condition and therefore is not specific to either diagnosis.  
❌ Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration:
Incorrect: Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration can be used diagnostically and therapeutically in the management of a breast abscess. It can also be used to collect cells for diagnosis of suspected breast cancer.  This patient’s breast ultrasound did not show a fluid collection or discrete mass, and core biopsy has better sensitivity and specificity than FNA for diagnosing cancer.  
❌ MRI of the breast:
Incorrect: MRI of the breast is used in the workup of breast cancer when initial imaging is equivocal and there is not a clear role for biopsy, or once diagnosis is made when further detail is needed for staging and treatment planning.  An MRI cannot provide a definitive diagnosis of cancer and this patient has a clear indication for biopsy.  
❌ Alkaline phosphatase level:
Incorrect: Alkaline phosphatase level may be elevated in a number of conditions including systemic infection and breast cancer.  It should be included in the workup of suspected inflammatory breast cancer, but it is non-specific and would not provide a definitive diagnosis in this patient.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the primary care office with pain and redness on her right breast for four days. She is currently breast-feeding and missed several milk-pumping sessions last week due to travel. She is feeling fatigued and has malaise. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 91/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. Exam reveals an area of erythema and edema over the lateral portion of the right breast. There is central fluctuance and warmth. Ultrasound shows a 4 cm subcutaneous fluid collection. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Warm compresses and follow up in 2 days

questions.solution:
This patient who is currently lactating presents with pain, warmth, erythema, and fluctuance of the right breast, and a 4 cm fluid collection seen on ultrasound indicating a breast abscess. Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration is the preferred method of drainage when a breast abscess is less than 5 cm and tissue necrosis is absent, as seen in this patient. Patients should be encouraged to empty the breast regularly and continue breastfeeding. The choice of antibiotics should consider safety during lactation.

Management of a breast abscess consists of empiric antibiotic therapy followed by either needle aspiration or incision and drainage based on the size of the abscess. Ultrasound is used to evaluate for an abscess and determine the size of the fluid collection. When an abscess is <5 cm and signs of overlying tissue necrosis are absent, ultrasound-guided needle aspiration is indicated. Patients should be re-evaluated in two to three days as a repeat aspiration may be needed. Incision and drainage is the preferred method of drainage when an abscess is > 5 cm, tissue necrosis or ischemia is present, or prior needle aspirations have failed. A sample of the drained fluid should be sent for culture and sensitivities, and medications for pain management should be offered as needed. When bacterial infection of the skin is present, but ultrasound does not show a fluid collection, appropriate treatment is empiric antibiotics, warm compresses, and pain medication. When a suspected infection of the breast does not respond to treatment as anticipated, a workup for inflammatory breast cancer is warranted.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cephalexin and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Warm compresses and follow up in 2 days:
Incorrect: Warm compresses and observation are appropriate management for a plugged milk duct without signs of infection. This patient has evidence of abscess formation. Drainage and antibiotics are indicated.  
❌ Dicloxacillin and warm compresses:
Incorrect: Antibiotics and warm compresses is appropriate treatment for uncomplicated mastitis without abscess. This patient has evidence of a fluid collection on ultrasound and should be treated with antibiotics and drainage of the fluid.  
❌ Cefazolin and morphine:
Incorrect: Antibiotics and analgesia should be considered for cases of mastitis without abscess formation. This patient has evidence of a fluid collection on ultrasound, therefore management should include drainage of the abscess.  
❌ Cephalexin and incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Incision and drainage are indicated for a breast abscess that is greater than 5 cm in size, if the previous needle drainage failed, or if skin necrosis is present. This patient’s abscess is less than 5 cm in size; therefore ultrasound-guided needle aspiration should be performed.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man on the surgical floor has new-onset abdominal discomfort and bloating 48 hours postoperatively following a right hemicolectomy. His surgery was uncomplicated. He has been unable to pass flatus and stool since the procedure. Heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 100/56 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0 °F). On examination, bowel sounds are diminished. The abdomen is mildly tender, distended, and tympanic to percussion. A peripheral IV is placed with administration of IV fluids. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms (e.g., abdominal discomfort, bloating, inability to pass flatus and stool) and signs (e.g., abdominal distension, mild tenderness, tympany, decreased bowel sounds) of postoperative ileus following abdominal surgery.  When evaluating a postoperative patient with abdominal discomfort, it is important to examine the surgical wounds as wound infection, herniation, perforation and peritonitis could all be causes of abdominal pain in a patient after abdominal surgery.

Ileus refers to a functional obstruction of the intestines that may arise due to reduced or absent peristalsis without an underlying mechanical blockage. This is a common postoperative complication, particularly following abdominal surgeries. The condition is likely secondary to inflammation and a neurohumoral response to bowel manipulation. Nonsurgical causes of ileus include medications that slow peristalsis (e.g. opiates) and systemic conditions (e.g. sepsis).

When assessing a patient with suspected postoperative ileus, an ABCDE evaluation and stabilization of the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation takes priority. Vital sign monitoring, obtaining IV access, and starting IV fluid hydration are part of the management. Additionally, an examination of the surgical wounds should be performed to rule out other causes of abdominal pain or mechanical obstruction before obtaining additional diagnostic studies or starting therapeutic interventions for suspected ileus.  

Option Analysis

✅ Examine the surgical wounds:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain an abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: An abdominal X-ray can show dilated bowel loops suggestive of ileus, and should be done to help rule out mechanical obstruction; however, it is imperative to first check the surgical wounds of any post-operative patient with new-onset abdominal pain.  
❌ Start broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient has likely developed a postoperative ileus. There is no indication for antibiotic therapy at this time.  
❌ Insert a nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: Nasogastric decompression can provide symptomatic relief for patients with ileus. However, while evaluating this post-operative patient, assessment of surgical wounds takes precedence.  
❌ Administer prokinetic agents:
Incorrect: Prokinetic agents can be useful for stimulating bowel motility. However, they're not the first step in addressing post-operative abdominal pain.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain and distension over the past 3 days. He has not had a bowel movement over this period of time.  He had a severe lumbar sprain 2 weeks ago and was prescribed medications for pain control. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 82/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the abdomen is distended and tympanic to percussion with decreased bowel sounds on auscultation. The scout CT image is displayed below. Which of the following would be most consistent with the suspected diagnosis?
 

Image courtesy of Radiopaedia

choices.text: Positive Murphy's sign on abdominal examination

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, inability to pass stool) and signs (e.g., abdominal distention, tympany, decreased bowel sounds) of ileus in the setting of recent analgesia use. His X-ray demonstrates diffuse dilation of the intestines without a clear transition point, consistent with ileus. Recent use of opiate analgesics is most likely to have caused this condition.

Ileus refers to a functional obstruction of the intestines that may arise due to reduced or absent peristalsis without an underlying mechanical blockage. This is a common postoperative complication, particularly following abdominal surgeries. Non-postoperative causes of ileus include medications that slow peristalsis (e.g., opiates, anticholinergics), systemic conditions (e.g., metabolic abnormalities, sepsis), intra-abdominal pathology (e.g., diverticulitis, appendicitis), and radiation. For a nonsurgical ileus, the etiology can usually be elucidated by taking a careful patient history.

Patients presenting with ileus will often have signs and symptoms similar to small bowel obstruction. This can include abdominal pain, bloating, obstipation, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination may demonstrate abdominal distention, tenderness to palpation, tympany to percussion, and diminished or absent bowel sounds. Abdominal imaging, such as an X-ray or CT, can help differentiate ileus from small bowel obstruction. Radiographic findings of ileus include small bowel dilation without evidence of a transition point.  

Option Analysis

✅ Use of opioid analgesics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recent traumatic abdominal injury:
Incorrect: Traumatic abdominal injury, such as blunt force trauma, can cause intra-abdominal adhesions and mechanical small bowel obstruction. This patient’s X-ray and likely opioid use are more consistent with ileus.  
❌ History of chronic constipation:
Incorrect: Chronic constipation can cause abdominal distension and discomfort, but it would not likely precipitate the acute presentation seen in this patient and findings of ileus on X-ray.  
❌ Positive Murphy's sign on abdominal examination:
Incorrect: A positive Murphy's sign (pain upon deep inspiration while the examiner's fingers are placed under the right costal margin) suggests acute cholecystitis or inflammation of the gallbladder and not ileus.  
❌ Heavy alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: A history of heavy alcohol consumption combined would not typically be associated with causing generalized abdominal distension, lack of bowel movements, and ileus.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman had an uneventful laparotomy for appendicitis 3 days ago. On postoperative day 3, she had abdominal bloating and vomiting. She has not passed flatus or had a bowel movement since her surgery. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the surgical wounds are clean and dry without significant erythema. The abdomen is distended, mildly tender to palpation without rebound or guarding and tympanic to percussion. Bowel sounds are infrequent. An abdominal X-ray shows dilated loops of small bowel without a transition point. She is started on IV hydration. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of postoperative ileus, which is consistent with her X-ray findings. The most appropriate next step is nasogastric tube decompression to help alleviate her bowel distention and symptoms.

Ileus refers to a functional obstruction of the intestines that may arise due to reduced or absent peristalsis without an underlying mechanical blockage. The most common cause is recent abdominal surgery. Monitoring a patient’s abdominal examination and ability to pass flatus and stool is critical in the postoperative period.

Management of postoperative ileus includes supportive care with bowel rest, nasogastric tube decompression, IV fluid hydration, and electrolyte monitoring/replacement. Patients are encouraged to ambulate and avoid medications that can inhibit peristalsis (e.g., opiates) Monitoring involves serial abdominal exams and abdominal X-rays to gauge response to therapy. Once improvement is seen, patients should have a trial of oral intake. If patients do not respond appropriately, develop signs of sepsis, or worsen clinically, a CT of the abdomen and pelvis should be ordered to look for complications.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nasogastric tube decompression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Administering a prokinetic agent, such as metoclopramide, is not the first-line management for ileus. These medications can enhance gut motility, but their efficacy in treating postoperative ileus remains uncertain.  
❌ Parenteral nutrition:
Incorrect: Initiating parenteral nutrition is premature at this point. This therapy is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate enteral feeds or those with a contraindication to oral or enteral intake.  
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: An exploratory laparotomy is an invasive procedure. It would not be the next step for treating a patient without evidence of a surgical complication or acute pathology causing the ileus.  
❌ Close monitoring:
Incorrect: Close monitoring without active intervention could potentially prolong the patient's discomfort and distention. Given the clinical picture, an intervention is necessary to relieve the patient's symptoms and promote bowel function recovery.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of vomiting, watery diarrhea, and fever for the past 24 hours. Over the past day, the patient states she has had 10-12 episodes of forceful vomiting with clear emesis; however, for the last two hours, she has noticed bright red blood in the vomitus. She reports crampy abdominal pain. The patient’s medical history is significant for hypertension, hiatal hernia, and knee osteoarthritis. She takes lisinopril, omeprazole, and occasionally naproxen. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She works at a daycare. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 105/min, blood pressure is 100/58 mmHg, and respirations are 18/min. Her conjunctiva are pale. Cardiopulmonary exam is significant for tachycardia and normal heart sounds. Abdominal examination shows mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Rectal examination shows normal tone with heme-negative watery stool. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on upper endoscopy?

choices.text: Multiple superficial erosions of the gastric mucosa

questions.solution:
This patient has had several episodes of hematemesis after vomiting multiple times over several hours in addition to fever, crampy abdominal pain, and watery diarrhea. She most likely has viral gastroenteritis (likely transmitted in the daycare where she works) complicated by Mallory-Weiss syndrome. Mallory-Weiss syndrome can be diagnosed with upper endoscopy that shows a superficial longitudinal mucosal tear at or near the gastroesophageal junction.    

Mallory-Weiss syndrome, also known as a Mallory-Weiss tear, is characterized by superficial lacerations in the mucosa of the distal esophagus or proximal stomach. The condition typically presents as acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding after repeated retching or vomiting. The most commonly associated cause is heavy alcohol use, but Mallory-Weiss syndrome can be caused by retching/vomiting from any cause, including gastrointestinal infection as is seen in this patient. The tear can cause severe bleeding if there are other comorbidities, such as portal hypertension, esophageal varices, regular use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDS), or anticoagulant use.   

Option Analysis

✅ Longitudinal mucosal tear :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ulceration of the gastric mucosa:
Incorrect: Patients who use nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs regularly are at risk for peptic ulcer disease and gastritis and can present with abdominal pain, especially if the ulcer is erosive and bleeding. However, hematemesis associated with peptic ulcer disease usually starts at the beginning of vomiting, not after several hours as is seen in this patient who likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear from vomiting and retching secondary to viral gastroenteritis.
❌ Tortuous small blood vessels:
Incorrect: Angiodysplasia is abnormal dilated and tortuous small blood vessels in the mucosal and submucosal layers of the gastrointestinal tract that can cause gastrointestinal bleeding. Angiodysplasia usually manifests as iron deficiency anemia and rarely causes hematemesis. 
❌ Multiple superficial erosions of the gastric mucosa:
Incorrect: Multiple superficial erosions of the gastric mucosa can be caused by stress-induced ulcers. This type of ulcer can be seen in severely ill patients in the intensive care unit, especially those with coagulopathy or in patients who have been intubated for more than 48 hours. This patient is unlikely to have stress-induced ulcers.
❌ Distended esophageal veins:
Incorrect: Esophageal varices are seen as distended esophageal veins on endoscopy and are most commonly found in patients with end-stage liver disease. This patient does not have a history of alcohol use or liver disease and has no signs of end stage liver disease, such as splenomegaly, ascites, and spider angioma.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset severe chest pain that started six hours ago. The pain is sharp, radiating to the back, and exacerbated by swallowing. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and eosinophilic esophagitis for which he takes oral corticosteroids. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient’s neck veins appear distended with subcutaneous emphysema over the neck. Contrast esophagram shows a large amount of extraluminal contrast extravasation adjacent to the esophagus and extending into the mediastinum. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and emergent surgical consult
IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and hospital admission for observation
Oral pain medications, oral proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and outpatient follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of esophagitis presents with sharp chest pain, findings consistent with subcutaneous emphysema, and contrast esophagram confirming the diagnosis of esophageal perforation. Contrast esophagram shows a large amount of extraluminal contrast extravasation indicating a large non-contained esophageal perforation. Appropriate treatment includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, including antifungals; IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI); and emergent surgical consultation for definitive management.

Esophageal perforation is a life-threatening condition that requires rapid diagnosis and intervention. The management of esophageal perforation depends on the size of the perforation and the patient's time of presentation to the hospital. In instances where a small, contained perforation is identified and the patient has presented < 24 hours after the perforation, a conservative approach is appropriate. This approach involves close monitoring of vital signs, NPO status, nutritional support via total parenteral nutrition (TPN), pain management, administration of broad spectrum antibiotics and IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI), and surgical consultation for possible intervention.

Patients with extensive leakage into the mediastinum or delayed hospital presentation require emergent surgical intervention. Non-contained perforations are associated with a higher risk of complications, like sepsis and shock, and require medical management and emergent surgical consultation for definitive intervention.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and emergent surgical consult  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and hospital admission for observation:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate treatment for a patient with a small contained perforation who presented early. This patient with a large non-contained leak requires emergent surgical intervention.  
❌ Emergent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Incorrect: This patient has an esophageal perforation with leakage into the mediastinum. EGD would not be necessary at this time and could make the perforation and leak worse.  
❌ CT of the chest  :
Incorrect: CT can be used to diagnose esophageal perforation; however, it is not necessary in this patient with diagnosis made by contrast esophagram.  
❌ Oral pain medications, oral proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: This patient has an esophageal perforation with large leakage into the mediastinum. Outpatient management is inappropriate. This patient requires an emergent surgical consult due to the high risk of complications and associated mortality.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for two weeks of bloody drainage from the right nipple. The patient has not had trauma to the breast and it is not painful. Past medical history includes an unprovoked deep vein thrombosis two years ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 134/84 mmHg. Chaperoned examination of the right breast reveals no masses, tenderness, or skin changes. Bloody drainage can be expressed from the nipple with applying gentle pressure. No axillary lymphadenopathy is present. Ultrasound and mammography are performed and show an intraductal mass. Core biopsy of the mass shows papilloma with atypical ductal hyperplasia. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical excision with sentinel lymph node biopsy
Close observation with follow-up imaging in 6 months
Surgical excision followed by radiation therapy

questions.solution:
This patient’s breast papilloma needs to be surgically excised given the atypical ductal hyperplasia found on biopsy. Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERM), such as tamoxifen, can be used for prevention after surgery in patients with atypical ductal hyperplasia. However, this patient’s age and history of an unprovoked DVT increase the risk of a thromboembolic event with use of a SERM. Post-treatment surveillance and age and risk factor-based breast cancer screening are indicated in all patients after surgical excision of a papilloma.  

Most patients with a breast papilloma should have surgical excision of the mass. When atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) is present on biopsy, surgical excision is the standard of care. It is not uncommon for atypical or malignant cells to be found in an excised papilloma that were not detected on core biopsy. Symptoms such as bloody nipple discharge raise additional concern for malignancy. Due to the increased risk of malignancy associated with ADH, initiation of a SERM, such as tamoxifen, should be considered on a case-by-case basis.  

When malignancy is detected within a papilloma, management is guided by the stage of disease. Ductal carcinoma in situ is managed similarly to ADH with excision and initiation of a SERM if hormone receptor positive and surveillance. Genetic testing should also be considered. Invasive malignancy requires TNM staging, which may involve axillary node sampling and more extensive testing prior to surgical excision.

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical excision followed by surveillance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical excision with sentinel lymph node biopsy:
Incorrect: Lymph node biopsy in addition to surgical excision is indicated when malignancy is present or when concerning clinical features are present, such as axillary adenopathy. This patient’s biopsy results show atypia, which increases the potential for malignancy but is considered a benign finding.
❌ Close observation with follow-up imaging in 6 months:
Incorrect: Observation and serial imaging could be considered in an asymptomatic benign-appearing breast lesion without definitive diagnosis. This patient is confirmed to have a papilloma, most of which are surgically excised as it is not uncommon for them to contain atypical or malignant cells that may have been missed on the biopsy. 
❌ Surgical excision followed by radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Radiation therapy is typically done after surgical excision in breast cancer. Although an unexpected cancer could be found in a papilloma at the time of surgical excision, this patient’s biopsy did not show evidence of malignant cells.
❌ Medical treatment with tamoxifen:
Incorrect: Medical treatment with tamoxifen could be considered post-operatively, but surgical excision is the standard of care when atypical ductal hyperplasia is found within a papilloma. Further, this patient has had a prior unprovoked DVT; therefore, use of tamoxifen would have to be carefully considered in a risk-benefit analysis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after colliding with a car while riding his bicycle. He was struck from the right side by the vehicle and thrown from his bike. His Glasgow Coma Scale is 15, and he is reporting severe pelvic pain. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 118/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. There is diffuse ecchymosis across the right lateral and anterior pelvis. The abdomen is distended and there is suprapubic tenderness. Compression over the iliac crests produces pain and reveals vertical instability on the right side.  Blood is present at the urethral meatus. IV access is obtained. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This trauma patient presents with ecchymosis, abdominal distention, suprapubic tenderness, pelvic instability and blood at the urethral meatus suggestive of bladder and urethral injuries in the setting of a pelvic fracture. The patient’s injuries are likely causing significant internal bleeding given the findings of hypotension and tachycardia. Application of a pelvic binder can assist in tamponade of ongoing hemorrhage, while additional workup is pursued.    

Bladder injury in the setting of blunt pelvic trauma is often accompanied by concurrent injuries such as pelvic fracture and urethral injury. A bladder injury alone does not typically cause hemodynamic instability. Signs such as hypotension and tachycardia should raise suspicion of internal bleeding from a pelvic fracture. For trauma patients, the first priority is always stabilization with ABCDE assessment. Once the airway is secure and IV access established, a GCS should be calculated, and the cervical spine should be stabilized. Placement of a urinary catheter is the next step in a suspected bladder injury. A transurethral catheter is the standard approach, except for cases of suspected urethral injury. Signs suggestive of urethral injury include blood at the urethral meatus, bruising along the penis or perineum, high-riding prostate, and inability to pass urine. In these instances, the catheter should be placed suprapubically. 

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic binder placement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transurethral catheter insertion:
Incorrect: A transurethral catheter should not be used when a urethral injury is suspected. This patient has evidence of blood at the urethral meatus which is a sign of urethral injury; therefore, the catheter should be placed suprapubically. 
❌ CT of the pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT of the pelvis is indicated for patients with suspected bladder injury; however, this patient has signs of hemodynamic instability suggestive of ongoing bleeding and signs of pelvic fracture. Placement of a pelvic binder takes precedence as it may slow bleeding.
❌ Antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are indicated in the management of a suspected bladder injury; however, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of pelvic fracture, and placement of a pelvic binder takes precedence.
❌ Retrograde urethrogram:
Incorrect: A retrograde urethrogram is indicated for patients with a suspected urethral injury; however, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of pelvic fracture, necessitating placement of a pelvic binder.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after a high-speed motor vehicle accident. He was the restrained driver of a vehicle when he was struck from the driver’s side by another car traveling at 55 mph. The patient has pelvic pain and lower abdominal pain. The patient's Glasgow Coma Scale is 15. He has severe pelvic pain. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 154/88 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Examination of the abdomen reveals a distended abdomen with suprapubic tenderness and ecchymosis across the pelvis. Examination of the pelvis demonstrates diffuse tenderness to palpation with associated crepitus and laxity. A high-riding prostate is noted on digital rectal examination. Pulses are 2+ and symmetric in the lower extremities. Neurologic exam is grossly intact. Which of the following best explains the prostatic examination findings in this patient?

choices.text: Injury of the posterior wall of the bladder

questions.solution:
This trauma patient has a likely bladder injury and a high-riding prostate due to a posterior urethral injury caused by a pelvic fracture. The secondary survey in a patient with pelvic fractures includes assessment of the anterior and posterior urethra. In a patient who is biologically male, the posterior urethra can be assessed by palpating for a high-riding prostate gland on digital rectal examination.  

Blunt force trauma, penetrating trauma, and iatrogenic injuries are the most common causes of bladder injury which can lead to concurrent pelvic fractures and urethral injuries. The secondary survey is done after the initial stabilization and acute management to assess the location and extent of the injuries. Following the primary survey, the secondary survey includes a detailed physical examination, laboratory evaluation, and Focused Assessment With Sonography in Trauma (FAST).    

Patients with a bladder injury may report symptoms of suprapubic pain, dysuria, hematuria, and difficulty voiding. Physical examination can reveal suprapubic tenderness or mass, with ecchymosis across the anterior pelvis or perineum. Gross hematuria and perineal swelling may occur. Signs of urethral injury include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus, penile swelling or ecchymosis, and a high-riding prostate. Laboratory evaluation may reveal low hemoglobin and hematocrit if there is internal bleeding from a pelvic fracture, along with microscopic or gross hematuria. The FAST exam helps distinguish between an intraperitoneal vs. extraperitoneal bladder injury. Free fluid within the peritoneal cavity suggests the rupture occurred at the bladder dome whereas a lack of free fluid suggests the injury occurred in an area of the bladder below the peritoneal reflection with leaking urine into the perivesical space.  

Option Analysis

✅ Posterior urethral injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Penile fracture:
Incorrect: A penile fracture can be associated with an injury to the anterior urethra. This patient’s high-riding prostate indicates damage to the posterior portion of the urethra.
❌ Injury of the bladder dome:
Incorrect: Injury of the bladder dome may cause urine to leak into the peritoneum. This injury pattern would not affect the positioning of the prostate gland.
❌ Injury of the posterior wall of the bladder:
Incorrect: Injury to the posterior wall of the bladder will cause urine to leak into the perivesical space. It would not cause a high-riding prostate unless the posterior urethra was also injured.
❌ Prostatic hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Bleeding within the prostate gland is typically detected on imaging and would not result in a high-riding prostate.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 10-hour history of abdominal pain and a five-day history of constipation. He reports prior episodes of constipation that resolved with increasing his fluid and fiber intake. He does not have hematochezia or unintentional weight loss. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia which is well-controlled with atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 123/82 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals a distended tympanic abdomen with diffuse rebound tenderness with guarding and hyperactive bowel sounds. No obstructing masses are detected on the digital rectal exam. Based on this patient’s presentation and findings, colonic volvulus is strongly suspected. Which of the following findings would support a diagnosis of cecal volvulus as opposed to sigmoid volvulus?

choices.text: Single air-fluid level on abdominal x-ray

questions.solution:
In this patient presenting with abdominal pain and constipation and prior episodes of constipation, who is found to have a distended tender tympanic abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds and rebound tenderness, colonic volvulus is suspected. Patients with cecal volvulus can have variable presentations from insidious abdominal pain to acute severe abdominal pain. In patients with a cecal volvulus, abdominal x-rays will typically show a single air-fluid level in the left upper quadrant. Additionally, a massively dilated cecum with small bowel dilation corresponding to bowel obstruction can be seen.

CT scan and contrast studies (barium or water-soluble) in both cecal and sigmoid volvulus can show the characteristic bird’s beak sign (seen in the image below). CT scan can also show a whirl sign in both sigmoid and cecal volvulus. Abdominal x-ray in combination with CT scan is typically used to make the diagnosis. A rare type of cecal volvulus where the cecum folds anteriorly instead of twisting around its axis (cecal bascule) can also occur and should be suspected if the cecum appears as a dilated loop of bowel in the center of the abdomen.

Once a diagnosis of cecal volvulus is made, urgent surgical consultation for a right hemicolectomy is necessary, as detorsion alone without hemicolectomy is associated with a failure rate of up to 75%. Stable patients can have the segment detorsed at the time of surgery prior to resection.
 

 Image courtesy of StatDX
Frontal radiograph after a water-soluble contrast enema shows narrowing of the ascending colon, which ends proximally in a twist, leading to upstream dilation in this cecal volvulus.  

Option Analysis

✅ Single air-fluid level on abdominal x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Whirl sign on CT scan:
Incorrect: A whirl sign on CT scan can be seen in both cecal and sigmoid volvulus and results from twisting of the colon and the mesentery along the axis of the volvulus.  
❌ Leukocytosis:
Incorrect: An elevated white blood cell count can be seen with both cecal and sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: Metabolic acidosis can be seen in both cecal and sigmoid volvulus due to elevated lactate levels.  
❌ Pneumoperitoneum:
Incorrect: Pneumoperitoneum, or air under the diaphragm, is an ominous finding that indicates bowel perforation, which is a surgical emergency. Pneumoperitoneum can be a complication of both cecal and sigmoid volvulus.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with rectal bleeding and anal pain with bowel movements for the past two months. He has regular soft bowel movements. The patient has a history of HIV infection and is not taking HAART. He reports a 40-pack-year history of cigarette smoking. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is a palpable hard distal anal mass. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis
Positron emission tomography (PET) scan with fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)
Anoscopy and biopsy of the mass
Surgical excision of the anal mass

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of rectal pain and bleeding with a palpable anal mass on exam are concerning for anal cancer.  His history of HIV infection and cigarette smoking increases the likelihood of malignancy.  The first step in the workup of suspected anal cancer is anoscopy with a tissue biopsy of the mass. Additionally, fine needle aspiration (FNA) should be performed for any suspicious lymph nodes in the region.

Anoscopy allows better visualization of the mass to determine its size and location. It can identify lesions that are distal to the squamous mucocutaneous junction and those in the hair-bearing or perianal skin. These types of lesions are most likely to be squamous cell carcinomas (SCC), which is the most common type of anal cancer. The other type of anal cancer that occurs less commonly is adenocarcinoma. Treatment will vary based on the type of malignancy.

Once diagnosis is confirmed, the next step is to stage the cancer using the TNM system. This stands for Tumor size and location, lymph Node involvement, and presence of distant Metastasis. To do this, a CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, an MRI of the pelvis, and a PET scan should be obtained. Additionally, for biological females, a gynecologic exam with cervical cancer screening should be performed because of the close association of cervical and anal cancer and HPV infection.  

Option Analysis

❌ CT scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect:  CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is done to assess the extent of disease and detect metastasis after the diagnosis of anal cancer is made.  However, this patient does not yet have a definitive diagnosis. The most immediate concern is to establish a tissue diagnosis to guide further management.  
❌ Positron emission tomography (PET) scan with fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG):
Incorrect:  A PET scan is a sensitive imaging tool commonly used in cancer diagnosis and staging. For this patient, the primary concern is to establish a definitive diagnosis before moving on to advanced imaging studies  
❌ MRI of the pelvis:
Incorrect: An MRI of the pelvis can be performed to assess the extent of disease and to detect metastasis in patients diagnosed with anal cancer. However, given the patient's presentation, the most immediate concern is to establish a tissue diagnosis to guide further management.  
✅ Anoscopy and biopsy of the mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surgical excision of the anal mass:
Incorrect: Before proceeding with surgical excision, it is essential to establish a definitive diagnosis. Biopsy of a suspicious lesion and fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of enlarged lymph nodes should be done first to obtain tissue samples, allowing for a precise diagnosis of the anal mass.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of five days of pain and tenderness in his upper back. He is not able to see the area well, but any time something touches it, he feels pain. He regularly has his chest and back waxed but has never had infections of the skin before.  He does not have any chronic medical conditions.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Examination of the upper back reveals a single tender, fluctuant, pustular lesion surrounding a hair follicle. There is erythema directly over the lesion but none surrounding it.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient who regularly waxes his back has developed an infection of a hair follicle.  Because the infection has caused a fluctuant pocket of pus to form in the subcutaneous tissue, it can be diagnosed as a furuncle and treated with incision and drainage.   

Management of hair follicle infections including folliculitis, furuncles, and carbuncles is guided by the extent of the infection. Cases of simple folliculitis will often resolve spontaneously or with a short course of topical antibiotics. Cessation of hair removal should be encouraged if the patient was previously shaving or waxing the affected area. Furuncles are typically managed initially with incision and drainage. If they do not resolve with incision and drainage or are associated with surrounding cellulitis, they may require oral antibiotics. A culture of the purulent material should be performed to help guide appropriate antibiotic therapy if a repeat incision and drainage is needed. Carbuncles represent deeper, more extensive infections and should be treated initially with incision and drainage; cultures and systemic antibiotics may be warranted at the onset of treatment, especially if there is a large area of abscess, surrounding cellulitis, or systemic symptoms; or if the patient is immunocompromised or has an indwelling medical device such as a prosthetic joint or pacemaker.

Option Analysis

✅ Incision and drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Topical antibiotics:
Incorrect: Topical antibiotics are a reasonable treatment for folliculitis; however, this patient has formed a furuncle that needs to be drained.
❌ Systemic antibiotics:
Incorrect: Systemic antibiotics may be warranted in the management of a furuncle that has not responded to incision and drainage, or when overlying cellulitis or systemic symptoms are present.  This patient has not had drainage of the lesion yet and does not have other complicating factors, making incision and drainage the best option at this time.
❌ Benzoyl peroxide wash daily:
Incorrect: Benzoyl peroxide wash can be used in the management of superficial folliculitis or to reduce the number of bacterial colonies present on the skin in cases of recurrent furuncles or carbuncles. This patient has a furuncle, which requires incision and drainage for management, and it is his first infection, therefore benzoyl peroxide washes are not warranted at this time.
❌ Observation with reassessment in 48 hours:
Incorrect: Simple cases of folliculitis will often resolve spontaneously, making observation a reasonable option if the infection has remained in the superficial dermis; however, this patient has formed a furuncle in the subcutaneous space, which needs to be drained.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral breast tenderness and lumpiness, particularly in the upper outer quadrants, that she has noticed for the past six months. The symptoms seem to peak just before her menstruation. On examination, there are areas of tender nodularity in both breasts. No nipple discharge, skin changes, or axillary lymphadenopathy is noted. Both ultrasound and mammogram demonstrate heterogenous, distorted parenchyma without discrete masses. Which of the following is recommended for managing this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms consistent with fibrocystic breast changes. Wearing a well-fitted, supportive bra can help alleviate breast pain and tenderness by providing physical support and comfort.  

The goal of the management of fibrocystic breast changes is to alleviate symptoms of the disorder, such as mastalgia. Conservative measures should be attempted first, which include wearing a well-fitted, supportive bra, warm or cool compresses for pain and swelling, avoidance of nicotine and coffee, and pain relievers (e.g., ibuprofen, and acetaminophen). If the patient’s symptoms are not controlled with these measures, oral contraceptives, danazol, or tamoxifen may be considered. Rarely, cyst aspiration or surgical excision may be required for large, symptomatic cysts.

Option Analysis

✅ Wearing a well-fitted bra:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Regular caffeine intake:
Incorrect: Avoiding coffee is encouraged in patients with fibrocystic breast changes. The methylxanthines in coffee, and not the caffeine, appear to cause worsening symptoms in patients with fibrocystic breast changes.
❌ Following a high-fat diet:
Incorrect: There is no evidence to suggest that a high-fat diet would alleviate symptoms of fibrocystic breast changes. In fact, a balanced and healthy diet is generally recommended for overall health.
❌ Oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: While oral contraceptives can help regulate the menstrual cycle and reduce symptoms in some women, they are not universally recommended for fibrocystic breast changes due to potential side effects and risks associated with hormone therapy. They may be considered when conservative measures fail to control symptoms.
❌ Tamoxifen:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used in the treatment of breast cancer. It may also be considered for severe symptoms of fibrocystic breast changes when other therapies have failed. It is not an initial treatment.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is 4 weeks postpartum and exclusively breastfeeding presents to the clinic with a five-day history of pain and swelling in her right breast. She was prescribed a course of dicloxacillin by her primary care physician three days ago for suspected puerperal mastitis; however, the pain and swelling have not improved, and she now has fevers and chills. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Physical examination reveals a tender, erythematous, indurated area in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast, with associated warmth. There is no evidence of fluctuance or nipple discharge. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Continue dicloxacillin and reassess in 48 hours
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the breast

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with puerperal mastitis likely complicated by abscess formation. Puerperal mastitis is a common condition occurring in the postpartum period, particularly within the first six weeks of breastfeeding, as seen in this patient. Mastitis is typically responsive to antibiotics. This patient’s lack of improvement on appropriate antibiotics raises concerns for a complication like an abscess. A breast ultrasound is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide further treatment.  

Puerperal mastitis is common in breastfeeding women, and patients present with breast tenderness, erythema, and edema, often with systemic symptoms like fever. Ultrasound findings may include increased parenchymal echogenicity, indicating inflammation, and anechoic or hypoechoic areas, suggesting abscesses.    

Non-puerperal mastitis occurs in patients who are not pregnant or lactating and is often due to underlying pathologies such as duct ectasia or periductal mastitis. Non-puerperal mastitis presents similarly to puerperal mastitis but requires further evaluation with mammography and ultrasound. Mammography can show ductal dilation or periductal inflammation, while ultrasound may reveal complex fluid collections, abscesses, and tracts for fistulas.  

Granulomatous mastitis is a rare inflammatory condition.  Patients present with recurrent episodes of breast erythema and tenderness that may be treated as mastitis with antibiotics. Despite antibiotics, the symptoms will recur. Findings include localized erythema and induration with a breast mass or masses with or without skin changes. Mammogram and core needle biopsy are needed to rule out malignancy.

Option Analysis

✅ Breast ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Continue dicloxacillin and reassess in 48 hours:
Incorrect: While continuation of antibiotics is essential in mastitis treatment, this patient has not improved on the prescribed antibiotics and therefore needs additional evaluation with ultrasound to rule out abscess.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the breast:
Incorrect: This patient likely has puerperal mastitis complicated by abscess formation. While an MRI can detect breast abscesses, it is not the first-line imaging modality. Ultrasound is more cost-effective and can guide potential interventions.
❌ Biopsy of the breast tissue:
