Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 118/73 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a palpable, solitary, immobile anterior neck mass. Which of the following additional findings, if present, would suggest malignancy in this patient?

choices.text: Neck mass that is cystic and smaller than 1 cm on ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of voice hoarseness, dysphagia, and a palpable immobile anterior neck mass strongly suggests thyroid carcinoma. Thyroid carcinoma can present with new-onset voice hoarseness, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), and a palpable painless neck mass. Patients with thyroid carcinoma are often asymptomatic with an incidentally found thyroid mass seen on imaging or palpated during physical examination. If a mass is found that is suggestive of thyroid cancer, then TSH should be ordered. A normal or elevated thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) is consistent with thyroid cancer.

When evaluating a patient for suspected thyroid cancer, assessment of thyroid function with thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) should be done initially. In cases where TSH is below the reference range, the patient is considered to have hyperthyroidism and an alternative diagnosis like primary hyperthyroidism or subclinical hyperthyroidism should be considered. However, in cases where TSH is normal or above the reference range (euthyroid or hypothyroid), malignancy should be suspected and a thyroid ultrasound with FNA or core needle biopsy should be performed.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Normal thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tender neck mass:
Incorrect: Malignant thyroid nodules are typically painless. Patients with subacute thyroiditis can present with painful thyroid glands.  
❌ Heat intolerance and palpitations:
Incorrect: Heat intolerance and palpitations may be present in patients with hyperthyroidism. With thyroid cancer, a normal thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) or an elevated TSH, indicating hypothyroidism, is typically seen.  
❌ History of cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: Although cigarette smoking is associated with a variety of cancers, it is surprisingly associated with a decreased risk of thyroid cancer.  
❌ Neck mass that is cystic and smaller than 1 cm on ultrasound:
Incorrect: An ultrasound showing a cystic lesion smaller than 1 cm in diameter is not consistent with thyroid malignancy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoes hemorrhoidectomy under spinal anesthesia. The next day, he begins experiencing worsening lower abdominal discomfort. The patient has not urinated since the procedure. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a palpable bladder 4 cm above the symphysis pubis. Urinary catheterization drains 900 mL of urine from the bladder. The patient is treated with a drug that directly increases detrusor muscle tone. This medication acts by binding to which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative urinary retention.

Medications that directly act on muscarinic or nicotinic receptors are called direct cholinomimetics. These medications exert their effect by mimicking acetylcholine, which is the neurotransmitter that normally binds to nicotinic and muscarinic receptors. Examples of such medications include bethanechol, carbachol, methacholine, and pilocarpine.

The effects of each medication in this class differ depending on which muscarinic receptor subtypes it interacts with. The receptor subtypes and their characteristics are detailed in the following table:
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors:
Incorrect: This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative or postpartum urinary retention. Bethnecol does not act on nicotinic receptors.  
✅ Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alpha-1 receptors:
Incorrect: Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists help relieve the mechanical obstruction associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia. It achieves this function by relaxing the smooth muscle at the bladder neck and prostatic capsule. It does not act on the detrusor muscle.  
❌ Beta-3 receptors:
Incorrect: Sympathomimetics (e.g., mirabegron) act on the beta-3 receptor, causing relaxation of the detrusor smooth muscle and leading to increased bladder capacity. These medications are used in the management of urinary incontinence, not retention.  
❌ Histamine-2 receptors:
Incorrect: H-2 receptor blockers (e.g. cimetidine) reduce gastric acid secretion and can alleviate gastroesophageal reflux. These medications do not act on the detrusor muscle.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the primary care office for follow-up of bloodwork and imaging that was recently performed. Bloodwork results are shown below. CT imaging with pancreatic protocol demonstrates a well-defined 2 cm solid mass in the head of the pancreas that is hypervascular during the arterial phase and is not associated with biliary ductal dilation. Which of the following patients is most likely to have these laboratory and imaging findings?  

Laboratory Test
Results
Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL
Complete metabolic panel  
Within normal limits
Lipase
42 U/L (0-160 U/L)
CEA
0.3 ng/mL (0-2.9 ng/mL)
CA 19-9  
12 U/mL (0-37 U/mL)
Fecal occult blood  
Positive

choices.text: A 54-year-old man who presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and refractory gastroesophageal reflux symptoms despite maximal proton pump-inhibitor therapy
A 48-year-old man with alcohol use disorder and an episode of acute pancreatitis six weeks ago who-presents with abdominal pain
A 75-year-old woman with a 30-pack-year smoking history who presents with weight loss and jaundice
A 33-year-old woman with no past medical history who recently underwent cross-sectional imaging following a motor vehicle accident
A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus who presents with increased insulin requirements, diarrhea, and an erythematous rash

questions.solution:
This patient has normal transaminases, normal CEA and CA 19-9, and a well-defined solid pancreatic mass in the head of the pancreas that is hypervascular on the arterial phase, which is consistent with a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET). Two types of PNETs are typically found in the pancreatic head: gastrinoma and somatostatinoma. This patient also has blood work showing anemia and positive fecal occult blood which could be consistent with a peptic ulcer. The patient described in (A) also has diarrhea and resistant GERD.  Diarrhea and severe acid-related peptic disease can be seen with Zollinger-Ellison (ZES) syndrome, which is associated with gastrinoma.

A thorough history and physical are essential when assessing a patient with a pancreatic lesion, as the presentations of different pancreatic lesions can vary significantly. In a patient with a solid pancreatic lesion on cross-sectional imaging, the differential diagnosis includes pancreatic adenocarcinoma, pancreatic adenoma, and PNET. Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is often associated with weight loss. If it is located in the pancreatic head, it can obstruct the common bile duct, resulting in biliary ductal dilation with jaundice and elevated transaminases. Pancreatic adenomas are typically asymptomatic unless they are large enough to cause mass effect. PNETs can be either functional or nonfunctional, and when they are functional they cause symptoms due to the hormones they secrete.

The most common type of PNET is insulinoma, characterized by the Whipple Triad (symptoms of hypoglycemia which resolve with glucose administration, and plasma glucose ≤55 mg/dL during symptomatic episodes). The second most common PNET is gastrinoma, which can cause Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Other rare PNETs include VIPomas, which can cause watery diarrhea, hypoglycemia, and achlorhydria; glucagonomas, which can cause new-onset diabetes mellitus; and somatostatinomas, which can cause gallstones.  

Option Analysis

✅ A 54-year-old man who presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and refractory gastroesophageal reflux symptoms despite maximal proton pump-inhibitor therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ A 48-year-old man with alcohol use disorder and an episode of acute pancreatitis six weeks ago who-presents with abdominal pain:
Incorrect: This presentation is most consistent with a pancreatic pseudocyst which would not cause anemia and would not appear as a solid lesion on cross-sectional imaging. A pancreatic pseudocyst would instead appear as a well-encapsulated cystic mass adjacent to the pancreas.  
❌ A 75-year-old woman with a 30-pack-year smoking history who presents with weight loss and jaundice:
Incorrect: This presentation is most consistent with pancreatic adenocarcinoma, which is accompanied by elevated transaminases and elevated tumor markers (i.e. CA 19-9, CEA). Cross-sectional imaging would demonstrate an ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas with associated biliary ductal dilation.  
❌ A 33-year-old woman with no past medical history who recently underwent cross-sectional imaging following a motor vehicle accident  :
Incorrect: A young healthy patient with an asymptomatic, incidentally identified pancreatic lesion likely has either a pancreatic adenoma or a non-neoplastic pancreatic cyst. Although a pancreatic adenoma could appear as a well-defined mass in the head of the pancreas, it would not cause anemia and melena.  
❌ A 67-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus who presents with increased insulin requirements, diarrhea, and an erythematous rash:
Incorrect: This presentation is most consistent with glucagonoma. These tumors are typically located in the tail of the pancreas, not the head, and are not associated with anemia or melena.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presents to the trauma bay after being stabbed in the back with a knife. Primary survey is notable for absent breath sounds over the right lung. Temperature is 36 °C (96.8 °F), heart rate is 104/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 16/min. FAST exam is negative. Secondary survey reveals a 1.5 cm puncture wound in the right posterior chest, just inferior to the scapula with associated subcutaneous emphysema. Labs show a blood alcohol level of 126 mg/dL. Chest x-ray is obtained and is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?


Image Courtesy of Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol intoxication is stable with a penetrating chest injury. A secondary survey reveals a stab wound to the right posterior chest, and a chest x-ray shows a large right pneumothorax. Even though this patient is stable on room air, a tube thoracostomy is indicated given the size of the pneumothorax.      

Pneumothorax is the most common serious injury associated with penetrating thoracic/chest trauma. The severity of clinical findings is variable and does not necessarily correlate with the size of the pneumothorax.      

The "35-millimeter" rule can be used to determine if conservative management is appropriate for a patient with a traumatic pneumothorax. Observation is considered safe and appropriate if the radial distance between the parietal and visceral pleura or mediastinum in a line perpendicular to the chest wall on axial CT imaging or chest x-ray of the largest air pocket is less than 35 mm. If the distance is ≥ 35 mm, then tube thoracostomy should be performed without other interventions, and it is typically sufficient in most cases. Patients who are treated with conservative management should have a repeat chest x-ray performed after 6 hours to make sure that the pneumothorax is not increasing in size.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bronchoscopy :
Incorrect: A bronchoscopy is used to evaluate for tracheobronchial injuries in patients who have persistent air leaks following chest tube placement or extensive subcutaneous emphysema without pneumothorax. This patient has a right pneumothorax, therefore tube thoracostomy should be performed next. 
❌ Contrast esophagram :
Incorrect: In patients with a presumed esophageal injury, a contrast esophagram is the gold standard for diagnosis. While a stab wound can result in esophageal injury, the lack of pleural effusion or pneumomediastinum on chest x-ray makes an esophageal injury less likely. This patient has a right pneumothorax on chest x-ray, therefore, a tube thoracostomy should be performed next. 
✅ Tube thoracostomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Supplemental oxygen and observation:
Incorrect: This patient has a large pneumothorax that will not expand without intervention. In stable patients who have a small pneumothorax (< 3-3.5cm from apex to cupula), observation and supplemental oxygen are appropriate, but for this patient with a large pneumothorax, a tube thoracostomy should be performed next. 
❌ Intubation :
Incorrect: Intubation is not appropriate in this scenario, as the patient is stable on room air. A pneumothorax alone is not an indication for intubation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the trauma bay following a high-speed motor vehicle collision at 55 mph. Emergency medical services (EMS) report that the airbags deployed. There was not a prolonged extrication. The patient appears confused, but it is unclear if he struck his head. A cervical collar was placed in the field. Upon arrival at the hospital, the patient is confused but can speak a few words. Temperature 36 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 124/min, blood pressure is 88/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 24 with an SpO2 of 85% on nasal cannula. The patient is unresponsive. The primary survey demonstrates that the patient has tracheal deviation to the right side, absent breath sounds over the left chest, and ecchymoses overlying the left anterior chest wall without signs of a flail chest. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Draw blood work and order a chest x-ray

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle crash with signs of left chest wall trauma (i.e. ecchymoses overlying the left chest wall), tracheal deviation to the right, and absent breath sounds on the left side. Additionally, he is unstable with hypoxia and hypotension consistent with a tension pneumothorax. While this patient’s airway will need to be secured with endotracheal intubation, the tension pneumothorax is an immediate life-threatening injury that should be addressed first with left-sided needle thoracostomy.     

The first step in any trauma evaluation is to perform a primary survey via an ABCDE assessment. First, secure the Airway while stabilizing the cervical spine. If patients can speak clearly, their airway is secured. Once you have secured the airway, ensure adequate Breathing or ventilation by assessing oxygenation, ventilation, and chest wall injuries and by providing supplemental oxygen or other necessary measures (ie thoracostomy for tension pneumothorax). Next, assess Circulation and obtain 2 large bore IVs or IO access while continuously monitoring vital signs, such as heart rate and blood pressure. Then, assess Disability and neurologic status by calculating the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) and examining the pupils, spine, and assessing for sensory and motor deficits. Make sure to ensure spinal immobilization until spinal injury has been ruled out. Finally, Expose the patient, remove all clothing to assess for associated injuries, and cover the patient with warm blankets to prevent hypothermia.  

During the primary survey when assessing “Airway”, patients who are in respiratory distress, hemodynamic unstable, or have sustained severe injuries should be intubated, preferably with rapid sequence intubation. However, in patients with respiratory distress following chest trauma, “breathing” may take priority over “airway”. If respiratory distress is due to a tension pneumothorax, it should be treated first before performing endotracheal intubation because positive-pressure ventilation following intubation can worsen the pneumothorax.   

Other life-threatening injuries from blunt chest trauma that should be evaluated and treated immediately when they are suspected include cardiac tamponade from myocardial injury, aortic injury, hemothorax with severe active bleeding, and tracheobronchial disruption.  

Option Analysis

❌ Calculate Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) :
Incorrect: Calculating a GCS is part of the “Disability” component of the primary survey. This patient is unstable with a likely tension pneumothorax; therefore, the primary survey should stop, and the team should address “Breathing” immediately before continuing the assessment.
❌ Perform a FAST exam:
Incorrect: A focused assessment with sonography for trauma, (FAST), examines for free fluid in the pericardial, intra-abdominal, and pelvic spaces. A FAST examination is usually performed along with the secondary survey on patients who have had high-energy blunt trauma with rapid deceleration and are therefore at risk for severe injury. This unstable patient requires intervention at the “Breathing” step of the primary survey before finishing the primary survey and moving on to the secondary survey and FAST exam.
✅ Left chest needle thoracostomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Expose the patient fully:
Incorrect: “Exposure” is the final step of the primary survey. It is crucial to fully expose the patient when evaluating for any additional blunt or penetrating trauma, in addition to any burns a patient might have sustained. However, this patient’s primary survey must stop at “breathing” to address the underlying tension pneumothorax before proceeding to the next step. 
❌ Draw blood work and order a chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Blood work and a chest x-ray are important adjunct measures to perform during the secondary exam for all patients who have had high-energy blunt trauma with rapid deceleration. However, this patient requires intervention during the primary survey before proceeding with studies.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to a rural hospital after a motor vehicle crash. According to emergency medical services, the car was traveling at 30 mph when the vehicle abruptly struck a tree and airbags deployed. A cervical collar was placed in the field. Primary survey is intact. The patient does not have significant past medical or surgical history. The patient complains of pain overlying the anterior right chest. Temperature is 36 °C (98 °F), heart rate is 112/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. GCS is 14 for mild confusion. Secondary survey reveals moderate tenderness to palpation along the right anterior chest without abnormal chest wall movement or overlying ecchymoses. FAST examination is negative. Chest x-ray is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents following a motor vehicle crash with blunt chest injury. Primary survey is intact, but secondary survey reveals right anterior chest wall tenderness. The primary survey is intact, therefore breath sounds can be heard bilaterally, and vital signs are determined to be stable. Based on primary and secondary surveys, the chest wall pain and tenderness is likely secondary to right rib fractures. Radiography can be used to confirm the diagnosis.    

Rib fractures are a common injury that can occur after low-impact trauma like a fall from standing or high-impact mechanisms like motor vehicle collisions. Patients typically report localized chest pain that worsens with inspiration, and chest wall tenderness with palpation on exam. Chest x-ray will often demonstrate fracture lines overlying the affected ribs, but CT of the chest has a higher diagnostic accuracy.      

It is crucial when assessing patients with blunt-force chest trauma to exclude life-threatening injuries during the primary survey. These include tension pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade from myocardial injury, aortic injury, hemothorax with severe active bleeding, and tracheobronchial disruption. Stable patients should be further evaluated with physical exam and history during the secondary survey. Further testing should be ordered based on the mechanism of injury and patient complaints and findings. Other less serious injuries associated with blunt chest trauma include rib fractures, pulmonary contusion, and diaphragmatic injury.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pneumothorax :
Incorrect: This patient is saturating well on room air and the primary survey is intact, meaning that breath sounds are audible bilaterally and there is no evidence of respiratory distress. Pneumothorax is less likely given these findings.
❌ Tension pneumothorax:
Incorrect: A tension pneumothorax occurs when a pleural injury results in air trapping that compresses tracheal and/or cardiac structures, resulting in hypotension and obstructive shock. This patient is stable on room air with an intact primary survey, meaning that breath sounds are audible bilaterally and there is no evidence of respiratory distress; therefore, a tension pneumothorax is unlikely. 
✅ Right rib fractures:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Flail chest:
Incorrect: Flail chest occurs when 3 adjacent ribs are fractured in two places. This results in paradoxical chest wall motion, where the flail segment moves inward during expiration and expands during expiration. This patient does not demonstrate a paradoxical chest wall motion suggestive of flail chest. Right rib fractures are more likely in this patient.
❌ Myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Myocardial infarction would be unlikely in this young patient who has no significant past medical history, no complaints of typical chest pain, and an intact primary survey. Right rib fractures are more likely in this patient.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office for evaluation of a new skin lesion on the face. The patient first noticed some redness on her left cheek three months ago, but it did not bother her at the time. She was out to lunch with a friend this past week who encouraged the patient to have the lesion evaluated. The patient has been experiencing burning pain around the lesion. She spends half the year at the beach and the other half gardening at her primary residence. Past medical history is notable for hypercholesterolemia, for which she takes atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam reveals a fleshy, granulomatous papule with central ulceration as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the office with a concerning skin lesion on her cheek in the setting of significant sun exposure and new onset neuralgia. Physical exam reveals a granulomatous papule with central ulceration, which is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma.

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is a malignant tumor arising from epidermal keratinocytes. In individuals with lightly pigmented skin, it typically develops in areas of photodamaged skin and can present as papules, plaques, or nodules that can be smooth, hyperkeratotic, or ulcerated. Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma lesions may be scaly and they may bleed. A skin biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis. Pathology will reveal atypical squamous cells infiltrating the dermis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Basal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Lesions of basal cell carcinoma are typically pink or flesh-colored papules with a pearly or translucent quality, and telangiectatic vessels. The papules are often described as having  rolled borders. This lesion is more consistent with squamous cell carcinoma.  
❌ Melanoma:
Incorrect: Melanomas are lesions that typically meet the ABCDE criteria: asymmetry, border irregularity, color variegation, diameter >6 mm, evolution over time. This lesion is more consistent with squamous cell carcinoma.  
✅ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Skin tag:
Incorrect: Skin tags (Acrochordons or fibroepithelial polyps), are benign lesions that typically appear as pink, red, or white pedunculated lesions on a narrow stalk. This lesion is more consistent with squamous cell carcinoma.  
❌ Common warts:
Incorrect: Common warts (verruca vulgaris) are benign lesions caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection of keratinocytes. They typically appear as small cauliflower-like papules with a rough, papillomatous and hyperkeratotic surface. They typically appear on the hands and feet of children and young adults.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a self-palpated mass in the left breast. The patient typically performs bi-monthly self-assessments of the breasts, and this month she felt a firm lump in the upper outer part of the left breast. There is no tenderness associated with the mass, and no nipple discharge or overlying skin changes. The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia, for which she takes a statin. She has no past surgical history. There is no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Vital signs are unremarkable. Physical examination confirms the finding of a painless firm mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. She is sent for a diagnostic mammogram, which reveals an irregular cluster of calcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Which of the following factors, if present, would be most associated with an increased risk of malignancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a non-tender firm mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast without associated nipple discharge or overlying skin changes. Diagnostic mammography shows irregular calcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the affected breast, which are concerning for invasive ductal carcinoma. A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Nulliparity would increase this patient's risk of invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast.    

Breast cancer is the most frequently diagnosed malignancy worldwide and the leading cause of cancer death in women. In the United States, it is the second most common cause of cancer death in women after lung cancer. Approximately half of breast cancers can be explained by known risk factors, like reproductive factors and history of proliferative breast lesions. An additional 10 percent are associated with family history and genetics.  

Known risk factors for invasive ductal carcinoma are increased age, obesity, and increased breast density. Reproductive factors, such as nulliparity, increased age at first full-term pregnancy, which leads to more exposure to estrogen also increases the risk. A personal or family history of breast cancer, and genetic breast-ovarian cancer syndromes related to genetic mutations also increase the risk. Finally, alcohol and smoking have a significant impact on the risk of breast cancer.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nulliparity :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Late menarche:
Incorrect: Early age at menarche, and not late menarche, is associated with increased risk for breast cancer.
❌ Marijuana use:
Incorrect: Both alcohol use and smoking tobacco increase the risk of breast cancer in women; however no association with marijuana use has been found.
❌ History of breast cyst:
Incorrect: Nonproliferative epithelial lesions (e.g., breast cysts) are not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Other nonproliferative lesions include galactoceles, papillary apocrine change, and mild hyperplasia.
❌ Low-fat diet:
Incorrect: The low-fat eating pattern involves dietary moderation and is similar to the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension diet, but with somewhat more emphasis on reducing fat intake. This type of diet has been associated with reduced mortality following breast cancer diagnosis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a pre-employment medical assessment. The patient has no symptoms and is excited to start her new job. She has a history of diabetes, hypertension, Hashimoto thyroiditis, and atrial fibrillation. Her medications include metformin, candesartan, L-thyroxin, diltiazem, and apixaban. The patient consumes alcohol socially and is a former smoker (10-pack-year history). Her family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother and sister. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 70 bpm regular, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 135/84 mmHg. General examination is unremarkable, breast exam reveals a mass in the lateral lower quadrant of the right breast without palpable lymphadenopathy. Lab work is pending. Diagnostic mammography reveals a 1.2 cm spiculated irregular mass with microcalcifications in the lateral lower quadrant of the right breast. Core needle biopsy confirms the diagnosis of ER+/PR+/HER2- invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient is not concerned with how her breasts will look after surgery. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Lumpectomy (partial mastectomy) followed by radiation therapy
Subtotal mastectomy followed by radiation therapy.
Doxorubicin/paclitaxel regimen followed by subtotal mastectomy

questions.solution:
This patient is found to have a breast mass on exam during a routine pre-employment evaluation. Diagnostic mammography shows microcalcifications and core biopsy is consistent with ER+/PR+/HER2- invasive ductal carcinoma. This patient with a 1.2 cm mass with an absence of clinically detectable axillary lymph nodes has a T1N0 lesion, making her stage IA and a candidate for breast-conserving surgery (BCS) with lumpectomy(partial mastectomy) and postoperative radiation therapy   

Choosing breast cancer treatment modalities depends on many factors, including tumor size, lymph node involvement, receptor expression, fitness for surgery, and patient preferences. Contraindications to BCS, include Inflammatory breast cancer, multicentric disease, diffuse malignant microcalcifications, history of prior therapeutic radiation therapy, pregnancy, persistently positive resection margin (postoperatively), and radiation sensitivity (e.g., Radiotherapy). Importantly, lymph node metastasis is not necessarily a contraindication to BCT but requires additional considerations.   

Treatment options for breast cancer should be discussed with the patient in a patient-centric fashion. Even though a partial mastectomy (lumpectomy) may be indicated, some patients may prefer a mastectomy for personal reasons. In addition, early engagement of social workers, therapists, and other specialists, such as oncologists and plastic surgeons is important.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lumpectomy (partial mastectomy) followed by radiation therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subtotal mastectomy followed by radiation therapy.:
Incorrect:  A subtotal mastectomy is indicated for patients with inflammatory breast cancer, multicentric disease, diffuse calcifications, prior radiation therapy, or an inability to clear positive margins after multiple re-excisions. Unless the patient prefers a mastectomy, a lumpectomy is the treatment of choice. 
❌ Doxorubicin/Paclitaxel regimen followed by lumpectomy:
Incorrect: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (e.g., doxorubicin/paclitaxel) followed by breast-conserving surgery best used to treat locally advanced breast cancer or triple-negative breast cancer (ER-/PR-/HER2-. This patient has a T1N0 lesion, making her stage IA making lumpectomy (Partial mastectomy) followed by radiation therapy the best treatment strategy. 
❌ Lumpectomy followed by Doxorubicin/Paclitaxel regimen:
Incorrect: As part of breast-conserving therapy, lumpectomy should be followed by breast irradiation, not chemotherapy, to reduce the risk of recurrence. Adjuvant chemotherapy is standard for patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), which this patient does not have, and either a tumor size >0.5 cm or pathologically involved lymph nodes (regardless of tumor size).
❌ Doxorubicin/paclitaxel regimen followed by subtotal mastectomy:
Incorrect: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (e.g., doxorubicin/paclitaxel) followed by breast-conserving surgery best matches patients with large tumors or locally advanced breast cancer. Additionally, the choice of the operation, either mastectomy or BCT, depends on the response to the neoadjuvant regimen and the baseline characteristics of the tumor before starting the neoadjuvant therapy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the left leg. The pain began about two hours ago and is non-radiating. Nothing has made the pain better or worse. He has never experienced this type of pain before. His past medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation for which he takes rivaroxaban and metoprolol. The patient lost his job and insurance recently, which has made affording his medications difficult. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 114/min and irregular, respiratory rate 14/min, and blood pressure 136/80. A focused vascular exam of the left leg reveals non-palpable distal pulses and absent arterial doppler signals but present venous doppler signals. The left foot and ankle demonstrate decreased strength, and there is decreased sensation to the ankle. CT angiography is obtained and shows an occluded left distal superficial femoral artery without runoff. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the left leg in the setting of an occluded distal superficial femoral artery (SFA) as diagnosed on CT angiogram (CTA). Given that the patient has not been able to afford medications for his atrial fibrillation, he likely had an embolus to the distal SFA. In the presence of motor and sensory deficits, this patient has an immediately threatened limb (Rutherford Class IIB). For most patients with an immediately threatened extremity, surgical revascularization with open embolectomy is the most appropriate initial treatment.        

For this patient, once an immediately threatened limb is suspected from history and exam, the patient should be started on IV heparin infusion immediately, and a CTA of the extremity should be ordered for surgical planning. An arterial occlusion causing an immediately threatened limb is a surgical emergency requiring revascularization, usually within six hours. The surgical team should be consulted for immediate revascularization.        

An open embolectomy is the surgical treatment of choice. One of the main advantages of an open embolectomy is that blood flow is generally restored very quickly. However, if comorbidities increase the risk for general anesthesia, a femoral cutdown and embolectomy can be performed under regional or local anesthesia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Femoral cutdown and embolectomy :
Incorrect: Open embolectomy, which quickly restores blood flow to the affected limb, is the treatment of choice for an immediately threatened limb. If this patient had comorbidities that prevented the use of general anesthesia, then a femoral cutdown with embolectomy could be considered. 
❌ Anticoagulation :
Incorrect: This patient requires systemic anticoagulation to prevent additional clot formation; however, anticoagulation will not dissolve the clot that is already present in the leg. This patient requires open embolectomy to remove the clot. 
✅ Open embolectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thrombolysis  :
Incorrect: Patients with an immediately threatened limb are generally not good candidates for thrombolysis. Although pharmacologic thrombolysis may successfully dissolve the embolus, the time required is usually too long for it to be an acceptable alternative to surgery with open embolectomy.  
❌ Four compartment fasciotomy  :
Incorrect: Depending upon the duration and severity of the ischemia, a fasciotomy may be required to prevent the development of compartment syndrome following reperfusion. However, fasciotomy does not treat acute limb ischemia, and open embolectomy to establish reperfusion is necessary.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the emergency department (ED) with generalized abdominal pain for the past week. She started noticing yellowing of the eyes two months ago and it has been progressively worsening. She has had an 11.3 kg (25 lb.) unintentional weight loss during the past two months. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), heart rate is 76/min, blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral scleral icterus, jaundice of the face and extremities, mild abdominal distention, mild diffuse abdominal tenderness, and ascites. Laboratory studies show an alpha-fetoprotein of 410 ng/mL. Abdominal and pelvic CT (computed tomography) with contrast shows a 4.5 cm solid hypodense mass that enhances arterial contrast phase with central washout on delayed contrast phase. Which of the following historical elements, if present, would be most consistent with the likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of generalized abdominal pain, jaundice, scleral icterus, unintended weight loss, and ascites is strongly suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma. Laboratory studies showing a markedly elevated alpha-fetoprotein of 410 ng/mL and CT findings of a 4.5 cm solid hypodense mass that enhances in arterial contrast phase with central washout on delayed contrast phase support the diagnosis. Chronic hepatitis B infection is a common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

HCC is the most common primary cancer of the liver and usually occurs in patients with chronic liver disease, particularly in patients with cirrhosis or chronic hepatitis B virus infection. Other risk factors for HCC include hepatitis C infection, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (i.e., NASH), environmental exposures (e.g., aflatoxin), and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Early diagnosis is crucial as treatment is dictated by the size of the lesion, its ability to be resected, and the underlying liver function. Treatments for hepatocellular carcinoma include surgical resection, systemic therapy, locoregional therapy (i.e., ablation), and liver transplantation.   

Option Analysis

❌ Recent travel to Mexico:
Incorrect: Recent travel to Mexico would be suggestive of an amebic liver abscess. Patients usually have a history of traveling to endemic areas, such as Mexico, within the past year and present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and diarrhea. This patient’s clinical presentation, markedly elevated alpha-fetoprotein, and CT findings are consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). 
❌ Recent cholecystitis:
Incorrect: A history of recent cholecystitis in the setting of right upper quadrant pain could be suggestive of a pyogenic liver abscess. Pyogenic liver abscesses occur due to bacterial seeding from the portal vein or the biliary tree. Patients typically present acutely with pain and fever. However, this patient’s history, physical exam, and CT findings are more consistent with hepatic malignancy.  
✅ Chronic hepatitis B infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral contraceptive pill use:
Incorrect: Oral contraceptive pill use can be associated with hepatic adenomas, which are benign tumors of the liver that appear as a well-encapsulated solid arterially enhancing hepatic masses on abdominal CT. This patient’s physical exam and CT findings are more consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).  
❌ History of colon cancer :
Incorrect: A history of colon cancer in a patient presenting with a liver mass is suggestive of metastatic disease to the liver. CT findings of several hypodense, target-like lesions would be more consistent with metastatic colon cancer to the liver. This patient’s CT findings are more characteristic of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for vomiting and fussiness. Two hours prior to presentation, the patient had an episode of vomiting, non-bloody, non-bilious emesis, and developed subsequent abdominal distension. He began crying and has been inconsolable, which is uncharacteristic for him. The parent states that the patient is otherwise healthy, up-to-date on vaccinations, and meeting developmental milestones. In the emergency department, temperature by rectum is 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate is 180/min, respiratory rate is 50/min and labored, blood pressure is 82/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an ill-appearing child. Bowel sounds are high-pitched. The abdomen is distended, tense, and tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant. There is a firm, tender mass in the right groin that is non-reducible with overlying erythema. Both testicles are palpable in the scrotum. Lab work is obtained and pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the right groin mass
Manual reduction of the groin mass

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department for evaluation of vomiting, inconsolable crying, and abdominal distension. On exam, the patient has findings consistent with a small bowel obstruction, incarcerated right inguinal hernia, and acute abdomen. Vital signs show tachypnea and hypoxia, placing the patient at risk for respiratory failure. Before further management, this patient requires stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. This patient who is hypoxic on room air should receive supplemental O2.

When a pediatric patient presents with findings suggestive of an acute abdomen, the first step in management is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if the patient is stable or unstable. Most patients with an acute abdomen are unstable, and airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized. Patients should have IV access established, IV fluid resuscitation with continuous monitoring of vital signs, and supplemental oxygen if necessary. Additionally, the patient should be made NPO (Nil Per Os) in anticipation of surgical intervention and a nasogastric tube may be placed for decompression. 

Manual reduction of an incarcerated hernia may be attempted at the bedside in patients who are stable and without signs of strangulation or acute abdomen. However, this patient should go directly for surgical repair once he is stabilized.   

Option Analysis

❌ Incision and drainage of the right groin mass  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings consistent with an acute abdomen secondary to small bowel obstruction from an incarcerated right inguinal hernia. The patient is tachypneic and unstable. Before definitive management, this patient requires stabilization. If this patient had an abscess, incision, and drainage would be the treatment of choice. However, the mass is firm and not fluctuant and boggy, which would be expected with an abscess.  
❌ Manual reduction of the groin mass :
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of an Incarcerated right inguinal hernia. In this patient who appears ill, with acute abdomen and signs of obstruction, manual reduction should not be attempted. Airways and breathing should be stabilized.  
✅ Supplemental oxygen :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Emergency surgical consultation  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with an acute abdomen and incarcerated right inguinal hernia. Unstable patients with an acute abdomen require ABCDE assessment with stabilization before any intervention including calling a consultation.  
❌ Outpatient ultrasonography  :
Incorrect: In a child with an inguinal hernia, especially those under two years of age and in unstable patients, urgent or emergency surgery is indicated. This patient should be stabilized and then go for surgery.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with pain and discharge from her left armpit. She states that for the past week, she has had pain when raising her left arm above her head. She noticed several raised areas of redness that were tender to touch. Yesterday, she had discharge from the left armpit while taking a shower. Today, she began feeling feverish. She has had four similar episodes in the past three years in her armpits and groin. Vital signs are unremarkable. Body mass index (BMI) is 37 kg/m2. Physical examination is significant for several areas of tender nodules, fluctuance, erythema, and induration in the left axilla. There is one area with purulence. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 24-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with an acute infection on top of a chronic disease of the left armpit. Given the history of chronic symptoms in the armpits and groin and physical examination findings of multiple tender erythematous nodules in the armpit with drainage, this patient can be diagnosed with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS). Imaging and laboratory studies are not necessary to make a diagnosis that can be made clinically.        

HS is a chronic condition where painful, inflamed nodules or abscesses form in the subcutaneous tissues of hairy areas or skin folds where there is constant rubbing. Patients usually report painful lumps around the axilla, groin, and inframammary areas. Risk factors include obesity and cigarette smoking. Examination typically shows multiple tender, erythematous nodules sometimes with visible sinus tracts and drainage.       

Treatment of HS consists of topical therapies, oral therapies, biologic therapies, surgery, and laser and light interventions. Disease severity, patient tolerance of specific agents, comorbidities, and treatment cost and availability guide treatment selection.       

Option Analysis

❌ KOH Testing :
Incorrect: A KOH test showing branching hyphae can confirm the diagnosis of a fungal infection. Fungal infections typically present with plaques and pruritus, which are absent in this patient.  
❌ Computed tomography  :
Incorrect: Computed tomography (CT) can be used to diagnose an abscess or a necrotizing soft tissue infection, but it is not required to make the diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa. Diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa can be made clinically. CT is used as part of operative planning to determine the presence of underlying abscesses or fistulous tracts.  
✅ No further testing is needed :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ELISA assay for Lyme :
Incorrect: An ELISA assay is used to detect Borrelia antibodies in patients with suspected Lyme disease. This patient’s presentation and findings are not consistent with Lyme disease and are more consistent with hidradenitis suppurativa.  
❌ Skin culture   :
Incorrect: A skin culture is typically avoided, even in patients with superficial skin infections, as they are easily contaminated. Instead, a culture of the deep wound pocket or purulence should be collected. However, skin culture is not needed to make the diagnosis of hidradenitis suppurativa, which can be made clinically.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of moderate postprandial discomfort. The patient previously experienced similar symptoms and at that time was diagnosed with a type II paraesophageal hernia. He states that he has not kept up with the lifestyle and dietary modifications that initially helped relieve the symptoms. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia that are well-controlled with lisinopril and atorvastatin. Lifestyle and dietary modifications are recommended again, and a low-dose H2-receptor antagonist is prescribed as needed. Four weeks later, the patient has not had relief from the reflux symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe an H2-receptor antagonist twice daily and reassess in two weeks
Continue low-dose H2 receptor agonist as needed for four more weeks and reassess

questions.solution:
This 65-year-old man presents to the clinic for symptoms consistent with acid reflux in the setting of a known type II paraesophageal/hiatal hernia. He is advised to re-start lifestyle and dietary modifications and prescribed an H2-receptor antagonist (H2RA) as needed for symptomatic management. However, after following this plan for four weeks, he continues to have refractory reflux. The most appropriate next step in management is to increase the frequency of the H2RA to daily and to reassess the patient in two weeks.        

 Management of hiatal hernias is like the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Initially, patients are educated and counseled on the importance of dietary and lifestyle modifications. These include interventions such as weight loss, elevation of the head at night, and elimination of acid reflux triggers (e.g., alcohol, fatty foods, etc.). If reflux symptoms persist, an H2RA can be used as needed. If after four weeks, symptoms persist, then the H2RA should be changed to daily, and the patient should be reassessed for treatment response after two weeks. If there is no adequate response, then a low-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) should be prescribed and titrated upward based on symptoms.       

Patients who have refractory reflux symptoms despite appropriate medical management, can be referred for surgical management. Surgical management involves laparoscopic hernia reduction and repair, along with fundoplication to re-establish the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and prevent recurrence of GERD.    

Option Analysis

❌ Refer for elective surgical management  :
Incorrect: Surgical management (with hiatal herniorrhaphy with or without fundoplication) should be considered when patients have symptoms that are refractory to medical management. This patient should first have the dosing of the H2RA changed from as needed to daily. 
❌ Prescribe low-dose proton pump inhibitor daily  :
Incorrect: Low-dose proton pump inhibitor should be considered only after a daily H2-receptor antagonist (H2RA) has been tried for two weeks without improvement of symptoms. This patient has been taking a low-dose of H2RA on an as-needed basis and should be switched to a daily H2RA before considering a proton pump inhibitor.  
✅ Prescribe an H2-receptor antagonist twice daily and reassess in two weeks :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Continue low-dose H2 receptor agonist as needed for four more weeks and reassess :
Incorrect: If patients fail to respond to H2RA as needed, for four weeks, they should be switched to daily H2 receptor agonists. 
❌ Emergent surgical management :

questions.text: An undomiciled adult man is found unconscious and brought to the emergency department by emergency services. Initial vital signs reveal a heart rate of 125 /min and a blood pressure of 77/45 mm Hg. Intravenous (IV) access is obtained, and a bolus of crystalloid fluid is started. Repeat blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. The patient is confused and unable to answer questions appropriately. Physical exam shows mucosal pallor, capillary refill > 3 seconds, and several surgical scars on the abdomen with an ileostomy without signs of infection. A foley catheter is inserted and drains 40 cc of dark yellow urine. A total body CT (Computed Tomography) scan reveals evidence of small bowel surgery. Which of the following would be a risk factor for short bowel syndrome in this patient?

choices.text: Prior resection of 75 cm of the small intestine with the terminal ileum intact
Prior resection with 180 cm of small bowel remaining

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of severe dehydration, abdominal scars and an ileostomy, and an unclear medical and surgical history. A CT scan reveals evidence of bowel surgery, and short bowel syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. Prior small bowel resection that left only 180 cm of small bowel remaining would be a risk factor for the development of short bowel syndrome in this patient.       

For adults, an anatomic definition of short bowel syndrome is a residual small bowel length < 200 cm, measured from the duodenojejunal flexure, with or without colon. The term "functional short bowel syndrome" is sometimes used to describe patients with a residual small bowel length > 200 cm but with impaired function due to factors such as the presence of underlying disease (e.g. Crohn disease), colon resection, or other causes of rapid intestinal transit. Insufficient bowel length or function results in malabsorption of water, electrolytes, and nutrients.       

Patients with short bowel syndrome can present with severe diarrhea or high stoma output if they have one. A high stoma output is defined as > 1.2 L per day. Additionally, they may have significant weight loss, decreased or absent urine output, lethargy, weakness, or altered mental status. Physical examination may reveal evidence of volume depletion, such as tachycardia, hypotension, dry mucous membranes, and decreased skin turgor.   

Option Analysis

❌ History of irritable bowel syndrome :
Incorrect: A history of irritable bowel syndrome and prior small bowel surgery would not be a risk factor for short bowel syndrome. However, a history of bowel resection and inflammatory bowel disease (i.e., Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis) would be a potential risk factor. 
❌ Prior resection of 75 cm of the small intestine with the terminal ileum intact :
Incorrect: Typical estimates of small bowel length in adults vary from 300-800 cm. The risk for short bowel syndrome increases when < 200 cm of small bowel remains after resection. Removal of 75 cm of small intestine would not be enough to reach this threshold. Additionally, since the terminal ileum is important for the absorption of nutrients, bile, and fluid, leaving it intact would help prevent short bowel syndrome. 
❌ Recent sphincteroplasty for Crohn disease :
Incorrect: There are several distinct types of sphincteroplasty, but all of them preserve the intestine. Even though there is likely malabsorption at the site of the sphincteroplasty, that alone without removal of the intestine is not enough to cause short bowel syndrome. 
❌ Consistent Ileostomy output <1200 mL  :
Incorrect: Patients with ileostomies need to be mindful of their daily output, as they can become dehydrated quickly. If the output is consistently greater than 1200-1300 mL per day and the patient is unable to decrease the output with antimotility agents, they will likely have short bowel syndrome. 
✅ Prior resection with 180 cm of small bowel remaining :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic to establish care. He has not seen a physician in five years. One year ago, he was hospitalized for an ischemic cerebrovascular accident (CVA) due to cerebral atherosclerotic disease. During that hospitalization he was also diagnosed with alcohol-induced cirrhosis. Current medication includes aspirin and atorvastatin. Since the CVA, the patient has not consumed alcohol. He drinks four cups of coffee per day and smokes one pack of cigarettes every three days. He was previously vaccinated against hepatitis B virus. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. The abdomen is distended and slightly firm with no fluid waves. Trace bipedal edema is present. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 63-year-old man presents to the clinic to establish care. He was diagnosed one year prior with alcohol-induced cirrhosis. Chronic liver disease from Cirrhosis is a significant risk factor for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). 

HCC is a primary tumor of the liver and most often develops in patients with chronic liver disease from cirrhosis. Patients with HCC can have variable symptoms. Some patients, especially those whose tumor is detected by surveillance ultrasound, can be asymptomatic. Other patients may have clinical symptoms related to cirrhosis and not the tumor itself (e.g., ascites, asterixis, hepatomegaly, jaundice, palmar erythema, spider angioma). Patients with advanced disease may have symptoms from extrahepatic masses in the lungs, intra-abdominal lymph nodes, bone, or adrenal glands. Patients with HCC will often have elevated transaminases (ALT, AST), INR (or prolonged prothrombin time) and total bilirubin on basic bloodwork.    

Option Analysis

✅ Cirrhosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Prior hepatitis B virus vaccination :
Incorrect: Chronic hepatitis B and C are risk factors for cirrhosis and thus also for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Since hepatitis B virus vaccination reduces the risk of hepatitis B virus infection and liver disease from infection, vaccination is associated with a lower risk of HCC. 
❌ Statin use:
Incorrect: Statins are not associated with a higher risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Some studies suggest they may lower the risk of developing HCC.  
❌ Aspirin use:
Incorrect: Aspirin is not associated with a higher risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Some studies suggest it may lower the risk of developing HCC.  
❌ High coffee intake:
Incorrect: Coffee is not associated with a higher risk of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Some studies suggest it may lower the risk of developing HCC.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the hepatology clinic for follow-up of previously diagnosed hepatocellular carcinoma. Past medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder and alcohol-induced cirrhosis. The patient has not had regular follow-up or routine surveillance imaging for years. Current medication includes furosemide, lactulose, and spironolactone. Vital signs are within normal limits. Since the last visit, the patient's weight has been down by 20 lbs. (9 kg). He has jaundice and appears chronically ill. Abdominal examination reveals a firm, distended, and non-tender abdomen with a fluid wave. Computed tomography (CT) imaging shows several large hepatic lesions and metastatic disease in multiple organs. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the hepatic lesions
Repeat ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein in three months

questions.solution:
This 68-year-old man presents to the hepatology clinic for follow-up of previously diagnosed metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The most appropriate management now is to discuss supportive and palliative care. Systemic chemotherapy or immunotherapy may be considered if the patient is interested and is able to tolerate it. 

In patients with HCC confined to the liver (HCC stage I-III), multiple treatment options exist including surgical resection, chemoembolization, systemic chemo- or immunotherapy, and liver transplantation. The specific indications for each of these depend upon the location and size of the lesion(s) and the patient’s medical comorbidities.  

For patients with metastatic disease (HCC stage IV) HCC, a discussion about palliative care is necessary. If patients with metastatic HCC are interested and have sufficient functional status, they may be able to undergo systemic chemo- or immunotherapy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Palliative care discussion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Liver transplantation:
Incorrect: Liver transplantation should be considered in patients with HCC and localized disease.     Patients with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) are not candidates for liver transplant.       
❌ Surgical resection of the hepatic lesions:
Incorrect: Surgical resection of hepatic lesions in patients with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma should be considered if patients have localized disease. However, patients with metastatic (HCC) are generally not candidates for surgical resection of lesions. 
❌ Chemoembolization of the hepatic lesions:
Incorrect: Chemoembolization of hepatic lesions in patients with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma should be considered if patients have localized disease. However, patients with metastatic (HCC) are generally not candidates for chemoembolization. 
❌ Repeat ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein in three months:
Incorrect: This patient has already confirmed metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Repeating ultrasound and serum studies is not necessary.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is transported by emergency medical services (EMS) to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was the restrained driver of a vehicle traveling approximately 60 miles per hour when she was struck on the passenger side by another vehicle traveling at a similar speed. She currently has abdominal pain. She has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 106/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On arrival, the patient can state her name and has normal breathing sounds. Bilaterally. Cardiac exam is within normal limits. The extremities feel cold and clammy. She has a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 15. Secondary survey reveals ecchymosis over the upper abdomen overlying the area where the seatbelt would lie. Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
This 37-year-old patient presents for evaluation of blunt abdominal trauma and has a positive seatbelt sign (i.e., bruising of the site where the seatbelt was lying following a motor vehicle collision). This finding is highly predictive of solid organ injury, which can result in hypotension and the finding of free fluid within the abdomen and pelvis on ultrasound. The most common area where free fluid is found on extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) in patients who have experienced blunt force abdominal trauma is within Morrison’s pouch (i.e., hepatorenal space).

The secondary survey for patients presenting with blunt and penetrating abdominal trauma involves a comprehensive head to toe physical examination to assess for traumatic injuries. This part of the exam includes performing adjunctive tests like trauma labs, including type and screen, pregnancy testing, complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic profile (CMP), lactate, urinalysis, urine tox screen and alcohol levels. Additionally, diagnostic tests such as eFAST and abdominal x-ray, should be performed and a CT of the abdomen and pelvis should be ordered in select cases.

The eFAST examination is an ultrasound examination (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) used in patients who have experienced trauma to assess for the presence of fluid within abdominal and chest cavities which would indicate hemothorax/pneumothorax). The examination is performed in several different anatomical areas, including the right upper quadrant, left upper quadrant, suprapubic area, subxiphoid, and lung windows.

Option Analysis

✅ Free fluid in Morrison’s pouch:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pericardial effusion:
Incorrect: A pericardial effusion is more likely to present in patients with direct blunt trauma to the chest rather than to the abdomen. Moreover, physical examination in patients with an acute pericardial effusion would be expected to reveal findings consistent with Beck’s triad (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distension), which are absent in this patient. 
❌ Absence of lung sliding:
Incorrect: absence of lung sliding suggests a pneumothorax, this patient has normal breath sounds bilaterally, whereas absent or diminished breath sounds on the affected side would be expected with pneumothorax following blunt chest trauma.
❌ Free fluid in the pelvis:
Incorrect: Free fluid in the pelvis is suggestive of a pelvic fracture. The most common area where free fluid is discovered on eFAST in patients following blunt force abdominal injury is within Morrison’s pouch (e.g., the hepatorenal space).
❌ Lung point sign:
Incorrect: A lung point sign suggests pneumothorax. This patient has normal breath sounds bilaterally, whereas absent or diminished breath sounds on the affected side would be expected with pneumothorax following blunt chest trauma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of a penetrating wound to the lower abdomen. The patient was stabbed by an assailant using a pocketknife. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. He has lower abdominal pain. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 126/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On arrival, the patient can state his name and has normal breathing sounds bilaterally. The  patient’s extremities feel warm. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 15. Secondary survey reveals a 1 cm penetrating, open wound on the left lateral side of the umbilicus. Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) and X-ray of the chest and abdomen are unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 26-year-old patient sustained penetrating trauma to the lower abdomen following a stabbing. A key component of treatment of patients with penetrating trauma is to assess the size and depth of the wound via local wound exploration prior to proceeding to further diagnostic studies or emergent exploratory laparotomy in the case of a deep penetrating injury.

Adjunctive workup for adult trauma patients with a blunt or penetrating abdominal injury is often dependent on the findings on initial workup or examination. For patients with penetrating trauma, the wound should first be explored before obtaining additional imaging or proceeding to surgery. If the base of the wound can clearly be seen, and the wound does not appear to violate the abdominal fascia, then, CT imaging should be performed to confirm the existence of a superficial abdominal injury. If there is any doubt in the depth of the wound or if the injury violates the abdominal wall fascia, this can indicate a deep penetrating injury, and the patient should be taken directly for exploratory laparotomy, which can be both diagnostic and therapeutic.

For patients with blunt abdominal trauma, and findings on efast or CT consistent with solid organ injury, mesenteric injury, or blunt aortic injury, the next step is to order a CTA to determine if there is a vascular injury within a solid organ.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Local wound exploration:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Repeat eFAST:
Incorrect: Repeating an eFAST would be indicated if there was a change in the status of the patient, and he became hemodynamically unstable. There is no indication for repeating this test in this patient.  
❌ CTA abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CTA abdomen and pelvis can be performed to confirm that the injury is superficial. Abdominal injury of local wound exploration shows no involvement of the abdominal wall fascia. 
❌ Emergent laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable with negative eFAST. The wound should be explored at the bedside to assess the depth of the wound before proceeding with further studies or emergent laparotomy.  
❌ Diagnostic peritoneal lavage:
Incorrect: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is an uncommon practice that was once the gold standard to detect hemoperitoneum. Before proceeding with further testing or surgery, the wound should be explored to assess the injury's depth.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation after a fall from the grandstands at a college football game. EMS is unsure of the cause of the fall but states a cervical collar was placed in the field. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 144/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Upon arrival at the ED, the patient appears confused but is speaking in full clear sentences and states he cannot move his legs. Pupils are 2-3 mm, equal round, and reactive bilaterally. The patient has bilateral breath sounds and 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. The patient has a GCS of 14 and is freely moving his upper extremities, but no movement is noted in the lower extremities. The patient is exposed, and warm blankets are applied. IV access is established. Which of the following findings is most likely to be noted in the secondary survey?

choices.text: Step off over the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
This patient presents for trauma evaluation after a fall from a significant height. The patient’s primary survey is significant for the patient’s inability to move the lower extremities bilaterally. Secondary survey, which involves a full head-to-toe examination and history would likely reveal a step-off over the lumbar spine.

Once the primary survey is performed, the physician should move on to the secondary survey, which involves a thorough history, physical examination, and additional workup to identify underlying traumatic injuries not obvious during the primary survey. In terms of history taking, the secondary survey should seek to fully characterize the mechanism of injury (e.g., the height of the fall, how the patient fell) allergies, current medications, past illness, pregnancy status, timing of the most recent oral intake, and other events related to the injury (e.g., recent substance use).

The physical examination should begin with examination of the cranium and proceed to the chest, abdomen, arms, and legs examining for any notable injuries. The patient should also be rolled to examine the spine and back while maintaining cervical spine precautions. Once complete, further imaging and diagnostics can be performed to better characterize the noted traumatic injuries.

Option Analysis

✅ Step off over the lumbar spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Maxillofacial instability:
Incorrect: This patient is speaking in clear, full sentences. Findings of maxillofacial stability are unlikely given his airway status.  
❌ Unstable pelvis :
Incorrect:  Unstable pelvic fractures often result in circulation instability (e.g., hypotension, delayed capillary refill) due to intrapelvic bleeding (sheering forces and tearing of pelvic vasculature). This patient is hemodynamically stable on the primary survey. 
❌ Chest wall deformity:
Incorrect: This patient has an intact breathing status with equal breath sounds bilaterally, making chest wall deformity and subsequent complications (e.g., pneumothorax) less likely.
❌ Bleeding deformity of the occiput:
Incorrect: When neurologic disability is present, intracranial trauma should always be considered. And deformity of the occiput should be looked for. Findings on the primary survey that would indicate Intracranial trauma with bleeding and brain injury would be obtundation and changes in pupillary examination. This patient does not exhibit these findings.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal and chest pain for three hours and two episodes of vomiting, the most recent one with hematemesis. The parents report that he is not able to swallow solids or liquids. Parents report that the child was playing in the playroom unsupervised when these symptoms began. There is no history of similar episodes and no history of diarrhea or fever. He has no surgical history, and family history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 98/59 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the child appears irritable, and there is mild abdominal tenderness with a soft and nondistended abdomen. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia .  Licensed under; CC BY 3.0

choices.text: Intubate and place on mechanical ventilation
Obtain intraosseous access for rapid fluid resuscitation

questions.solution:
The child presents with chest and abdominal pain, vomiting, and an episode of hematemesis following unsupervised play. Chest x-ray confirms the presence of a button battery in the esophagus, making esophagitis secondary to button battery ingestion the predicted cause of hematemesis and upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Emergent endoscopy is required for removal of the button battery.       

Ingestion of foreign bodies is common in children. Foreign bodies that can cause significant trauma to the GI tract include sharp objects and button batteries. Most button battery ingestions occur in children younger than 6 years and can result in esophageal mucosal damage, necrosis, and perforation, which can lead to upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Patients with button battery ingestion often present with acute GI symptoms such as vomiting, dysphagia, odynophagia, and they can drool and have irritability. Other symptoms include hematemesis, hemoptysis, melena, and abdominal pain. Physical exams may reveal epigastric tenderness.        

Chest x-ray should be performed to help make the diagnosis and localize the foreign body. If a button battery is identified and found to be in the esophagus, immediate endoscopic removal is necessary and should not be delayed to avoid complications such as perforation and necrosis. During endoscopy, the mucosa should be inspected for the extent, depth, and location of the injury.        

Option Analysis

❌ Intubate and place on mechanical ventilation :
Incorrect: Intubation and mechanical ventilation should be initiated in patients with foreign body aspiration and signs of respiratory distress, which are not noted in this patient. Rather, this patient has ingested a button battery, and an urgent endoscopy should be performed. 
❌ Perform gastric lavage :
Incorrect: Gastric lavage might be useful or better visualization of the upper gastrointestinal tract when an endoscopy is performed. This patient’s abdominal pain and hematemesis are secondary to button battery ingestion, and urgent endoscopy should be performed.  
✅ Perform urgent gastrointestinal endoscopy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain intraosseous access for rapid fluid resuscitation :
Incorrect: Intraosseous access is a helpful technique for providing rapid infusion of fluids for patients with signs of hemodynamic instability, particularly in the pediatric population. However, this patient is stable, and his abdominal pain and hematemesis are secondary to button battery ingestion; therefore, urgent endoscopy is required.  
❌ Transfuse packed red blood cells  :
Incorrect: Packed red blood cell transfusion may be needed in this patient with upper gastrointestinal bleeding if he had signs of hemorrhagic shock such as tachycardia and hypotension. These findings are absent in this patient, and he should have emergent endoscopy performed.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of a closed head injury. He was on a sled traveling downhill when he collided with a tree striking his forehead on the ground. He was not wearing a helmet and lost consciousness for about 30 seconds. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 100/75 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Upon arrival, a cervical collar is placed. The patient is speaking in clear full sentences but appears confused. There is a large hematoma over the forehead. The patient is moving all extremities spontaneously and localizes to pain and opens his eyes spontaneously. A full head-to-toe examination does not reveal any further injury or trauma. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Elevate the head of the bed
Obtain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
This 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a traumatic brain injury (TBI) following a sledding accident. A critical component of acute management for pediatric patients with TBI is to calculate a Glasgow coma scale (GCS). This score's results guide further management, including the need for advanced imaging or airway support (e.g. intubation).    

TBI refers to brain damage that results from an external mechanism, like a fall, motor vehicle accident, or non-accidental trauma. When a pediatric patient presents with a TBI, it is important to stabilize them urgently, assess the severity of the injury, and determine the need for imaging.        

Primary survey should be performed by assessing the airway, breathing, and circulation; and immobilization of the neck and spine should be performed. Additional supportive measures should include obtaining intravenous (IV) access, starting IV fluids, continuously monitoring vital signs, and providing supplemental oxygen if needed. Next, a Glasgow Coma Scale, or GCS should be calculated.        

This scale assesses the patient’s eye opening in addition to their motor and verbal responses, to determine their level of consciousness and need for imaging or additional airway support. In general, patients with a GCS of less than 8 should be considered for intubation (a helpful rhyme is “GCS of eight means you intubate!”). In addition, the GCS provides an objective measurement to assess the degree of brain injury. For children under two years of age, a modified Pediatric GCS can be used instead.  



Option Analysis

✅ Calculate Glasgow coma scale:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intubate the patient :
Incorrect: This patient, while confused, is currently protecting his airway and therefore does not need intubation. He should have a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) calculated before proceeding with further management. 
❌ Administer mannitol:
Incorrect: This patient does not have documented radiographic findings of intracranial hemorrhage warranting the administration of mannitol.  
❌ Elevate the head of the bed:
Incorrect: The head of the bed should be elevated to at least 30 degrees for patients with documented evidence of intracranial hemorrhage. This patient does not have documented radiographic findings of intracranial hemorrhage. 
❌ Obtain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Incorrect: A plain head computed tomography (CT) is typically pursued over MRI for pediatric head trauma patients due to the time-sensitive nature of possible life-threatening diagnoses; however, this patient should first have a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) calculated.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of vomiting and lethargy. The boy’s parent found the patient lying on ground vomiting beside the outdoor play set in their backyard, where he had been playing with his older siblings. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 55/min, respirations are 24/min and irregular, blood pressure is 112/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears lethargic.
