He is moving all extremities spontaneously and localizes to pain. He opens his eyes to verbal stimulation and utters nonsensical words. Which of the following additional clinical elements, if present, is most specifically associated with the severity of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This 3-year-old boy presents for evaluation of lethargy and vomiting in the setting of a presumed head injury and has several concerning findings for a serious traumatic brain injury (TBI) including bradycardia, Cheyne-stokes breathing, and widened pulse pressure (Cushing triad). A fall from four feet would be consistent with a mechanism of injury that is significant enough to cause this severe injury.   

Traumatic brain injury, or TBI, refers to brain damage that results from an external mechanism, like a fall, motor vehicle accident, or non-accidental trauma. When a pediatric patient presents with TBI, it is important to gather key historical elements including the mechanism of injury and perform a detailed neurologic examination.        

Patients with a severe TBI often present with a high-risk mechanism of injury, such as a fall from higher than three feet, head impact from a high-velocity object, or a motor vehicle accident. Additional concerning features include loss of consciousness, changes in mental status, and seizure-like activity. Physical examination should include a full neurologic examination and an assessment for signs of trauma, such as a skull defect, and indications of a basilar fracture, like raccoon eyes, or Battle sign. The need for further imaging can be determined using the PECARN criteria, which risk stratifies patients based on some of these findings.        

When evaluating mechanisms of injury in pediatric patients, it is important to note whether a proposed mechanism is developmentally appropriate given the patient’s age and developmental progress. Remember, physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Fall from four feet :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ History of recent ibuprofen use:
Incorrect: The use ibuprofen or other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can theoretically increase the risk of intracranial hemorrhage. However, its use combined with a simple fall from standing for this three-year-old would not likely result in a serious traumatic brain injury (TBI) like intracranial hemorrhage. A fall from a significant height is more consistent with this patient’s severe presentation, regardless of a history of NSAID use. 
❌ Blurry vision:
Incorrect: Blurry vision can be suggestive of mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) and may or may not be seen with serious traumatic brain injury. A fall from a significant height is more specifically associated with this patient’s severe TBI presentation.  
❌ History of a recent concussion:
Incorrect: A history of recent concussion can increase the risk of a worsening concussion with repeated head trauma. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI), not a concussion. A fall from a significant height is more strongly associated with severe TBI. 
❌ Frontal scalp hematoma:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). The presence of a scalp hematoma does not significantly correlate with the presence of an intracranial hemorrhage in patients greater than 2 years old. In contrast, a fall from a significant height is much more strongly associated with a severe traumatic brain injury.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his coach for evaluation of a closed head injury after being tackled by an opposing player at a football game. The patient’s coach reports that the patient lost consciousness for 1-2 seconds after sustaining a direct blow to the head. The coach says the patient was slurring his words and appeared confused and disoriented after the incident. The patient does not recall the incident, and he now feels dizzy. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 122/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. He has an intact neurologic examination aside from a positive Romberg sign. Fundoscopic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Monitoring followed by concussion discharge instructions
Computed tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without contrast

questions.solution:
This 15-year-old boy presents for evaluation of a closed head injury from a low-risk mechanism of injury without concerning findings for a serious traumatic brain injury (TBI). He also has a reassuring exam and can be diagnosed with a concussion, which does not require imaging. Pediatric patients with concussions should be monitored for any neurologic/clinical changes that would warrant imaging. After that, they can be discharged with instructions to rest from both physical and cognitive activities, including school, for at least 24 to 48 hours.        

A concussion can be diagnosed clinically; however, concussions can be associated with more serious brain injuries like hemorrhage or diffuse axonal injury (DAI). Determining the need for imaging in patients with concussions is based on identifying warning signs or features related to more severe injury. Serious brain injury is typically associated with a high-risk mechanism of injury, such as a fall from higher than three feet, head impact from a high-velocity object, or a motor vehicle accident. Concerning patient findings include loss of consciousness for more than five seconds, changes in mental status, and seizure-like activity. The Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network (PECARN) criteria risk stratifies patients based on some of these findings. Patients who meet all criteria do not need further imaging.       

Serious TBI can be diagnosed and differentiated based on computed tomography (CT) head imaging findings. Patients who have had a brain injury with the presence of symptoms or exam findings, but without meeting criteria for CT of the brain, can be diagnosed with a concussion. In this case, history usually reveals low-risk mechanisms of injury, such as a fall from a standing height or a sports-related injury. Patients may have brief loss of consciousness (less than five seconds), headache, dizziness, confusion, impaired memory, or blurred vision. Physical examination may demonstrate mild neurologic deficits, such as abnormal vision or impaired balance. These patients can be monitored, and if no new or worsening neurologic symptoms develop, they can be discharged home with concussion discharge instructions including rest from both physical and cognitive activities, including school, for at least 24 to 48 hours.   

Option Analysis

✅ Monitoring followed by concussion discharge instructions:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the brain without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient has clear clinical evidence of a concussion without red flag features that would suggest a more serious intracranial injury (e.g. subarachnoid hemorrhage). Management should include a brief period of neurologic monitoring followed by discharge with concussion precautions.  
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without contrast :
Incorrect: This patient has clear clinical evidence of a concussion without red flag features that would suggest a more serious intracranial injury (e.g. subarachnoid hemorrhage). Management should include a brief period of neurologic monitoring followed by discharge with concussion precautions. Additionally, if the patient requires imaging due to a change in clinical status during observation, the preferred imaging in the evaluation of traumatic brain injury is a head CT without contrast. 
❌ Admission for serial neurologic examinations:
Incorrect: Admission for serial neurologic examinations is inappropriate in this clinical scenario. This patient has clear clinical evidence of a concussion without red flag features that would suggest a more serious intracranial injury. If this patient had evidence of a more serious intracranial injury, head CT and admission would be warranted.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is not typically part of the evaluation of patients with traumatic brain injury.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after multiple episodes of large hematemesis over the past 30 minutes. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and cirrhosis. He was found confused and drowsy at home, and his family called emergency medical services. In the emergency department, he appears lethargic and moans in response to painful stimuli. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, heart rate is 125 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Physical examination reveals pallor, diaphoresis, spider angiomas, abdominal distention with a fluid wave, and melena on the rectal exam. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with massive hematemesis, hypotension, tachycardia, hypoxemia, and altered mental status in the context of known cirrhosis, suggestive of an upper gastrointestinal bleed likely from esophageal variceal bleeding. The patient’s altered mental status and active bleeding indicate an imminent risk for airway compromise from aspiration. The most immediate priority is securing the airway via endotracheal intubation to prevent respiratory failure.

Acute management of patients presenting with vomiting begins with assessing and stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC). In unstable patients such as those with massive hematemesis, IV access should be established, fluid resuscitation should be provided, and vital signs should be continuously monitored. If there is a risk of aspiration, such as in patients with altered mental status or ongoing hematemesis, endotracheal intubation should be performed. Once the patient is stabilized, a focused history and physical examination should be performed to identify potential causes, followed by appropriate diagnostic testing (e.g., labs, imaging).   

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide is prescribed as pharmacologic therapy for variceal bleeding; however, it would not be the first step in management. Airway protection must be addressed first.  
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergency endoscopy:
Incorrect: Endoscopy is the definitive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for variceal bleeding, but it cannot be performed safely in an unstable patient who is at risk for aspiration. Intubation must precede endoscopy in a patient like this one with altered mental status and active bleeding.
❌ Oxygen via nasal cannula:
Incorrect: Oxygen can improve hypoxemia temporarily; however, it is insufficient for airway protection in a patient with active hematemesis and altered mental status.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Imaging of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated. This clinical presentation strongly suggests variceal bleeding. Imaging would delay life-saving interventions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute-onset nausea and multiple episodes of non-bloody vomiting that began 4 hours ago. He reports associated severe, sharp, intermittent right-sided flank pain radiating into the right groin. He has not had a fever, diarrhea, or recent dietary changes. He describes a similar episode several years ago that resolved without intervention. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure 140/90 mmHg, heart rate 100 beats per minute, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, he appears uncomfortable and restless, frequently shifting positions. Physical examination reveals marked tenderness over the right costovertebral angle. The abdomen is soft, nondistented, and nontender, without abdominal rebound or guarding. Urinalysis shows hematuria. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with vomiting and right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin and is found to have costovertebral angle tenderness and microscopic hematuria. The most likely diagnosis is nephrolithiasis. The best next step in management is to obtain a non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis which is the gold standard for diagnosing kidney stones.

The workup for patients presenting with acute vomiting should begin with a focused history and physical examination to identify associated symptoms, such as abdominal pain, fever, and neurological deficits which can guide the evaluation and narrow down the differential diagnosis. Laboratory tests (including a complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), and urinalysis) are important for identifying dehydration, electrolyte derangements, infection, or urinary etiologies such as nephrolithiasis. Imaging studies are tailored to the suspected etiology; for example, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis can assess for gastrointestinal or urological conditions, such as bowel obstruction or nephrolithiasis, while pelvic ultrasound is preferred for obstetric and gynecological causes like ectopic pregnancy or ovarian torsion. Extra-abdominal causes, such as increased intracranial pressure, should be evaluated with a detailed neurological examination and imaging likely with a head CT.

Option Analysis

❌ Antiemetic medication and discharge home:
Incorrect: Prescribing an antiemetic and discharging home would be appropriate if the vomiting was mild and self-limiting and was clearly due to a benign and identified cause (e.g. viral gastroenteritis) without red-flag symptoms or complications. This patient has severe pain and findings consistent with nephrolithiasis.  
✅ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Ultrasound is less sensitive than CT for identifying ureteral stones, especially small or distal stones. Abdominal ultrasound can be used in patients with vomiting and abdominal pain when radiation exposure must be avoided, such as in pregnant patients, or when assessing for conditions like biliary disease, hydronephrosis, or free abdominal fluid.
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is not indicated in this scenario, as the patient's symptoms and findings point to a urinary system etiology such as nephrolithiasis rather than an upper gastrointestinal cause.
❌ Abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: Abdominal X-ray is helpful in evaluating acute vomiting when assessing for bowel obstruction or perforation, as it can reveal air-fluid levels, dilated bowel loops, or free air under the diaphragm. However, this patient with vomiting, severe flank pain, and hematuria most likely has nephrolithiasis. Abdominopelvic x-rays may be considered in nonpregnant patients when CT is not available.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) for evaluation after being assaulted. Paramedics report the patient was strangled by an assailant and was found unresponsive at the scene. A cervical collar was applied prior to arrival at the ED. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication daily. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 177/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 67% on room air. The patient appears cyanotic and responds to a sternal rub. There is a large ecchymosis around the left orbit and a large left scalp hematoma. There is also significant ecchymosis and swelling of the neck. Glasgow coma score (GCS) is 6, and pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Intravenous access is established, and supplemental oxygen is applied via non-rebreather. Rapid sequence intubation is attempted, but upon entering the airway, marked edema and bleeding is noted, and the vocal cords cannot be visualized. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the head and neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents following a traumatic neck injury with evidence of airway instability. Rapid sequence intubation is attempted, but the patient cannot be intubated orally. Therefore, the best next step in management is to perform an emergent cricothyrotomy to stabilize the airway prior to performing a CTA of the head and neck to evaluate for blunt cerebrovascular injury, which can be life-threatening.       

Blunt cerebrovascular injury, or BCVI, refers to damage to the carotid or vertebral arteries following blunt head or neck trauma. These injuries are often caused by motor vehicle collisions, falls, strangulation, or direct trauma to the neck. BCVI is divided into 5 grades based on the luminal narrowing of the vessels. BCVI has the potential to induce thrombus formation, vascular occlusion, and vascular wall hematomas, which can result in serious complications like a stroke.        

Acute management for all patients presenting with possible BCVI follows standard trauma protocols starting with an ABCDE assessment. Since most patients with BCVI present with associated neck injuries that compromise the airway, it is imperative to secure the airway as soon as possible and to anticipate a difficult airway. In addition to standard rapid sequence intubation, emergent cricothyrotomy may be necessary if the patient cannot be intubated.        

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced intimate partner violence, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope for Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources   

Option Analysis

✅ Cricothyrotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Percutaneous transtracheal jet ventilation:
Incorrect: Percutaneous transtracheal jet ventilation is an emergent airway strategy used in pediatric patients who require an alternative to cricothyrotomy. It is not the definitive airway management strategy for this adult patient.  
❌ Fiberoptic awake intubation:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of marked edema of the airway, and the vocal cords cannot be visualized. Fiberoptic awake intubation is unlikely to be successful.  
❌ Supraglottic device:
Incorrect: Supraglottic devices (e.g. laryngeal mask airway (LMA)) can be used as a temporizing measure for patients prior to definitive airway management. This patient has evidence of marked edema of the airway, and LMA is unlikely to be effective.  
❌ Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the head and neck:
Incorrect: CTA of the head and neck should be obtained for this patient to rule out blunt cerebrovascular injury, but definitive airway management is necessary first, given this patient's unstable airway.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after a fall that occurred while snowboarding. The patient was traveling at high speed without a helmet when he hit a rock. A cervical collar was placed before arrival. The patient has no significant past medical history, and he does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 166/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Upon primary survey, the patient is slurring his words but can report neck pain. Bilateral breath sounds are auscultated on pulmonary exam. There are 2+ pulses in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Glasgow coma score (GCS) is 15, and vertical nystagmus is noted in the pupils bilaterally. Intravenous access is established. On secondary survey, bruising and swelling are noted on the anterior face. There is reproducible tenderness to palpation of the cervical spine. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) imaging of the head and neck shows a left vertebral artery dissection. Which of the following best describes this blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) pattern?
questions.solution:
This patient has experienced a significant injury and presents with nystagmus and slurring of his words, which are indications of disruption of the posterior circulation (vertebrobasilar) vessels that supply the cerebellum. He is diagnosed with a vertebral artery dissection by CT angiography (CTA). Grading depends on the extent of the injury. Vertebral artery dissection is considered a grade II blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI).       

BCVI refers to damage to a carotid or vertebral artery following blunt head or neck trauma. BCVI can be divided into 5 grades based on the luminal narrowing of the vessels seen on CTA. BCVI has the potential to cause thrombus formation, vascular occlusion, or vascular wall hematomas, which can result in serious complications like a stroke. CTA imaging should be performed on patients with blunt neck trauma when there is high suspicion of BCVI based on history and physical examination or based on the Denver Screening Criteria in asymptomatic patients. Based on CTA findings, the BCVI can be graded according to the table above.   

Option Analysis

❌ Grade I:
Incorrect: A grade I blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) is diagnosed if CTA imaging shows vertebral or carotid artery injury with less than 25 percent luminal narrowing. These injuries are considered mild.  
✅ Grade II:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Grade III:
Incorrect: A grade III blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) is diagnosed if CTA imaging shows a pseudoaneurysm of the vertebral or carotid artery. This means that there is some damage to the arterial wall causing it to weaken and balloon.  
❌ Grade IV :
Incorrect: A grade IV blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) occurs when there is complete occlusion of the vertebral or carotid artery. This injury pattern poses an elevated risk of brain ischemia and stroke. 
❌ Grade V :
Incorrect: A grade V blunt cerebrovascular injury (BCVI) occurs when there is evidence of transection of the vertebral or carotid artery with contrast extravasation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of severe shortness of breath for the past few hours. Last night, he awoke gasping for air while lying flat in bed. He has had difficulty catching his breath this morning. At baseline, he can walk halfway down his driveway before stopping to catch his breath but has never experienced shortness of breath while at rest. He has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, and he had rheumatic fever as a child.  His current medications include glipizide and metformin. Temperature is 37.2ºC (99.0ºF), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 94/62 mmHg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. Cardiac auscultation reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm and a diastolic rumble with a loud S1. Crackles are heard at both lung bases bilaterally. There is 2+ pitting edema bilaterally up to the mid-tibia, and the skin is cool and clammy to the touch. Which of the following medications should be prescribed now?
questions.solution:
This 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with orthopnea and severe dyspnea and is found to be clammy and volume-overloaded on exam. These findings are consistent with decompensated heart failure with likely impending cardiogenic shock. Given the irregularly irregular rhythm (likely atrial fibrillation) and diastolic rumble with a loud S1 heart sound, this patient likely has severe mitral stenosis causing these findings. The most appropriate next step is to administer loop diuretics like bumetanide to remove fluid and relieve venous congestion. If his blood pressure fails to improve or he cannot tolerate diuresis, then inotropes should be started.   

Mitral stenosis refers to the narrowing of the mitral valve orifice (most commonly from calcifications, and occasionally from rheumatic heart disease) which leads to poor left ventricular diastolic filling and eventually decreased cardiac output. Patients with mitral stenosis may present with stable vital signs or they may be unstable, as seen in this patient.    

Patients who are unstable from mitral stenosis will generally present with severe decompensated heart failure which can progress to cardiogenic shock. Patients in cardiogenic shock have hypotension, cool and clammy skin, and evidence of volume-overload (“cold and wet”). The goal of treatment is to remove fluid and relieve venous congestion with intravenous loop diuretics. For patients in cardiogenic shock, inotropic support (e.g. milrinone) should be added to improve cardiac output. Patients with cardiogenic shock due to severe mitral stenosis should be emergently referred for valve repair or replacement.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bumetanide:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem has negative chronotropic effects and can be used for chronic mitral stenosis and rate control in atrial fibrillation. Though this patient probably has atrial fibrillation, the negative inotropic effects are a contraindication to starting this medication in this patient with decompensated heart failure.  
❌ Metolazone:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are often used with loop diuretics (e.g., bumetanide, furosemide, torsemide) to augment diuresis in patients with decompensated heart failure. However, they should not be used as monotherapy.  
❌ Chlorthalidone:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are often used with loop diuretics to augment diuresis in patients with decompensated heart failure. Chlorthalidone is more often used to treat hypertension than loop diuretics to augment diuresis and would not be used as monotherapy in this patient. 
❌ Apixaban:
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination and history of rheumatic fever are strongly suggestive of mitral stenosis which is frequently accompanied by atrial fibrillation (suggested by the irregularly irregular heart rhythm seen in this patient). This patient, however, should be stabilized before initiating anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with two days of worsening shortness of breath. At baseline, she can only walk up half a flight of stairs before stopping to catch her breath, but today she could only walk up two steps before having to stop. There is no associated chest pressure, lightheadedness, or dizziness. Past medical history is significant for recurrent rheumatic fever as an adolescent, as well as hypertension controlled well with amlodipine. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 109/68 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. A holosystolic blowing, high-pitched murmur is heard best at the left 5<sup>th</sup> intercostal space in the midclavicular line. There are faint bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation. There is moderate bilateral lower extremity edema. Chest radiograph shows mild pulmonary edema and trace bilateral pleural effusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 61-year-old woman with a history of recurrent rheumatic fever has developed worsening dyspnea and presents with signs of volume overload on physical exam and chest radiography. She also has a classic mitral regurgitation murmur – a holosystolic blowing, a high-pitched murmur best heard at the left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line. Mitral regurgitation the most likely diagnosis.

While mitral regurgitation may occur due to ischemic heart disease or endocarditis, it is also associated with rheumatic fever, as seen in this patient. Mitral regurgitation can cause a characteristic holosystolic blowing, high-pitched murmur best heard at the left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line. Patients with decompensated (or moderate/severe compensated) mitral regurgitation typically present with fatigue, dyspnea, and signs of volume overload. In severe decompensated mitral regurgitation, patients can present with cardiogenic shock.

Option Analysis

✅ Mitral regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aortic regurgitation:
Incorrect: While aortic regurgitation could potentially cause similar symptoms, the murmur of aortic regurgitation is diastolic. This patient’s history of rheumatic heart disease and systolic murmur suggest mitral regurgitation.
❌ Mitral valve prolapse:
Incorrect: This patient’s history of rheumatic fever supports a diagnosis of mitral regurgitation, which presents with a holosystolic murmur. Mitral valve prolapse usually causes a mid-systolic click with a late systolic murmur best heard at the apex.
❌ Aortic stenosis:
Incorrect: While aortic stenosis can cause a systolic murmur, this patient’s murmur is blowing and most prominent at the left 5th midclavicular line. The murmur heard in patients with aortic stenosis is classically a crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border.
❌ Tricuspid regurgitation:
Incorrect: Tricuspid regurgitation can occur in cases of pulmonary hypertension; however, the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is diastolic. This patient’s history and holosystolic murmur are more suggestive of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents for follow-up to the cardiology clinic after being referred for valvular disease found on echocardiogram. She recently established care with a primary care physician after not seeing a physician for twenty years. An echocardiogram was done after the patient stated she has been experiencing significant dyspnea on exertion. The echocardiogram revealed significantly elevated pulmonary artery pressures and right ventricular hypertrophy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the patient is well-appearing. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals a split S2. An in-office electrocardiogram is performed and shows signs of right ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following additional abnormal sounds is most likely to be heard on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: High-frequency decrescendo murmur at the left 2nd intercostal space, louder with inspiration
Blowing decrescendo early diastolic murmur at the right 2nd intercostal space, S3 heart sound
Blowing holosystolic high-pitched murmur at the left 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line
Holosystolic murmur at the left 4th intercostal space, louder with inspiration
High-pitched scratchy sound at the left lower sternal border

questions.solution:
This 48-year-old woman presents to the clinic with dyspnea on exertion, a split S2 heard on cardiac auscultation, and a recent transthoracic echocardiogram showing elevated pulmonary artery pressures and right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). This constellation of findings raises concern for pulmonic regurgitation, which can cause a high-frequency decrescendo murmur at the left 2nd intercostal space that is louder with inspiration.

Valvular insufficiency (regurgitation) refers to the state of a cardiac valve being “leaky” and causing forward blood flow to move backward through the valve into the previous cardiac chamber. All four cardiac valves can become insufficient and lead to various pathologies such as pulmonary hypertension, arrhythmias, or heart failure. Transthoracic echocardiogram is generally sufficient to make a diagnosis.

Each valvulopathy can cause a characteristic murmur as detailed in the table below:
   

Option Analysis

✅ High-frequency decrescendo murmur at the left 2nd intercostal space, louder with inspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blowing decrescendo early diastolic murmur at the right 2nd intercostal space, S3 heart sound:
Incorrect: This murmur could be heard in cases of aortic regurgitation. Patients may present with a history of syncope or angina or a remote history of infective endocarditis. However, this patient most likely has pulmonary regurgitation.
❌ Blowing holosystolic high-pitched murmur at the left 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line:
Incorrect: This murmur could be heard in cases of mitral regurgitation. Patients may have a history of recent myocardial infarction, infective endocarditis, or childhood rheumatic fever. However, this patient most likely has pulmonary regurgitation.
❌ Holosystolic murmur at the left 4th intercostal space, louder with inspiration:
Incorrect: This murmur could be heard in cases of tricuspid regurgitation. While this patient’s severe pulmonary hypertension could also lead to tricuspid regurgitation, the significant right ventricular hypertrophy is more consistent with pulmonic valve pathology.
❌ High-pitched scratchy sound at the left lower sternal border:
Incorrect: This sound is consistent with a pericardial friction rub, but this patient has no chest pain or historical features to suggest pericarditis. Instead, she most likely has pulmonary regurgitation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for follow-up of a recent echocardiogram. He has gradually developed chest discomfort and shortness of breath over the past few months. Stress testing with electrocardiogram did not show any inducible ischemic changes, so an echocardiogram was ordered. Transthoracic echocardiography performed last week showed moderate aortic regurgitation. The patient has a past medical history of chronic hyponatremia, gout, hypertension, major depressive disorder, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include allopurinol, amlodipine, citalopram, glipizide, and metformin. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 50/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 163/94 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a blowing decrescendo early diastolic murmur heard at the right 2<sup>nd</sup> intercostal space. Which of the following medications should be added to this patient’s treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
This 67-year-old man presents to the clinic to follow up on a recent echocardiogram which showed aortic regurgitation (AR). He is hypertensive and should be given afterload reduction in the form of antihypertensives. Losartan is indicated due to the concomitant diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. Additionally, losartan can be helpful for patients with gout due to its uricosuric effects, and it would not lead to hyponatremia.

Patients with valvular insufficiency (regurgitation) are treated with medications to help maximize heart function, and diuretics are often used to help reduce venous congestion and volume overload. Patients with AR especially need afterload reduction with certain antihypertensives (e.g., ACE-inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, hydralazine). Patients with moderate-to-severe disease should also discuss with a cardiologist if they need referral for surgical valve replacement.

Option Analysis

✅ Losartan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chlorthalidone:
Incorrect: While chlorthalidone is an effective antihypertensive agent, this patient’s chronic hyponatremia, gout, and diabetes mellitus make losartan a better choice.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: This patient requires afterload reduction given the aortic regurgitation. While beta-blockers can be used to treat hypertension, this patient is already bradycardic, so beta-blockers should be avoided.
❌ Atenolol:
Incorrect: This patient requires afterload reduction given the aortic regurgitation. While beta-blockers can be used to treat hypertension, this patient is already bradycardic, so these agents should be avoided.
❌ Sacubitril:
Incorrect: Sacubitril-valsartan is a combination medication used to treat patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor (blocks breakdown of natriuretic peptides) and is not used as monotherapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to recent weight gain. Over the past year, the patient has unintentionally gained 20 lbs. (9.1 kg) with no change in diet or physical activity. She has also noticed increased fatigue, depressed mood, and irritability. She also mentions memory difficulties and feeling “foggy” lately. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 154/85 mmHg. On physical examination, there is significant truncal obesity with apparent sarcopenia in the extremities. Violaceous striae are present on the abdomen. Muscle strength is 4/5 with hip flexion and extension bilaterally. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This 42-year-old woman presents with weight gain, fatigue, irritability, depressed mood, hypertension, truncal obesity, proximal muscle weakness, and violaceous striae. This constellation of findings is highly suggestive of hypercortisolism. The next step is to identify the source of cortisol excess, which may be exogenous, from an adrenal mass, or due to pituitary overproduction.         

Adrenal masses are often discovered incidentally on abdominal imaging but may also be suspected in patients with evidence of hormone excess, such as hypercortisolism, hyperaldosteronism, or pheochromocytoma. A benign-appearing adrenal mass without evidence of hormonal activity is commonly referred to as an incidentaloma. However, when symptoms are present, further hormonal evaluation should be guided by the specific clinical findings.        

Hypercortisolism can present with a range of characteristic signs and symptoms. Patients frequently report irritability, fatigue, and weight gain. They may also describe a depressed mood or memory impairment. On physical examination, truncal obesity with relatively thin or sarcopenic extremities is typical. Proximal muscle weakness is also common. Other findings include bruising, acne, hirsutism, violaceous (purplish red) abdominal striae, and the classic “buffalo hump” (prominent posterior neck fat pad). Once suspected, laboratory testing is used to confirm hypercortisolism and identify the underlying source, unless it is clearly exogenous.        

Option Analysis

✅ Cortisol-producing adrenal mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Aldosterone-producing adrenal mass:
Incorrect: Hyperaldosteronism can cause fatigue and hypertension. However, this patient’s irritability, depressed mood, truncal obesity, violaceous abdominal striae, and proximal muscle weakness are more suggestive of hypercortisolism. 
❌ Pheochromocytoma:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytomas are characterized by episodic headaches, palpitations, diaphoresis, and marked hypertension. The absence of these features and the presence of Cushingoid findings make a cortisol-producing adrenal mass more likely to occur. 
❌ Adrenal malignancy:
Incorrect: Non-functioning adrenal malignancies are often found incidentally and are not typically associated with systemic symptoms. Adrenocortical carcinoma is a rare but worthy cause of hypercortisolism and may present with rapidly progressive features. However, this patient’s indolent course over a year and absence of mass effect symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, fullness) make a benign cortisol-producing mass more likely. 
❌ Benign adrenal adenoma:
Incorrect: Non-functioning adrenal adenomas are often found incidentally and are not associated with systemic symptoms. This patient’s clinical features indicate hormone-active disease, making a non-functioning adenoma an unlikely cause.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for follow-up after an abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan incidentally revealed a 2 cm left adrenal mass. The patient reports feeling more tired over the last several months with occasional mild headaches. There are no associated symptoms of depression, palpitations, blurred vision, or weight loss. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 152/86 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 36 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is unremarkable. There are skin-colored striae on the abdomen and notable facial acne. Laboratory studies are displayed below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory Study     Result    
 Sodium     143 mEq/L    
 Potassium     2.9 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     29 mEq/L    
 Glucose     146 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This 23-year-old woman presents with an incidentally discovered adrenal mass and hypertension. Laboratory testing reveals low potassium and mildly elevated bicarbonate. This combination is highly suggestive of an aldosterone-producing adrenal mass.         

Adrenal masses are often discovered incidentally on abdominal imaging but may also be suspected in patients with evidence of hormone excess, such as hypercortisolism, hyperaldosteronism, or symptoms of a pheochromocytoma. When an adrenal mass appears benign and there is no biochemical evidence of hormone overproduction, it is referred to as an incidentaloma. However, patients with clinical symptoms should undergo targeted hormonal evaluation based on the presenting features.        

Hyperaldosteronism should be considered in any patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, as most secondary causes of hypertension are associated with normal or elevated potassium. When suspected, further evaluation should include measurement of serum aldosterone and renin levels. An aldosterone to renin ratio greater than 30 is highly suggestive of this disease. A sodium loading test can also be performed, as it suppresses aldosterone levels in healthy individuals but not in those with an aldosterone-producing adrenal mass.   

Option Analysis

✅ Aldosterone-producing adrenal mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cortisol-producing adrenal mass:
Incorrect: While some features such as fatigue, acne, hypertension, and hyperglycemia can be seen in hypercortisolism, the striae of Cushing syndrome are typically violaceous rather than skin colored. Additionally, the absence of other Cushingoid features along with the laboratory findings of hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, make an aldosterone-producing adrenal mass more likely. 
❌ Metanephrine-producing adrenal mass:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytomas typically cause episodic headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis, along with paroxysmal hypertension and tachycardia. This patient’s intermittent headaches and hypertension are mild compared to what is frequently seen in pheochromocytoma, and there is no evidence of sympathetic overactivity such as tachycardia or palpitations. 
❌ Benign adrenal adenoma:
Incorrect: Although an incidental adrenal lesion may represent a benign, non-functioning adenoma, the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a hormone-active adrenal mass. 
❌ Non-functioning adrenal malignancy:
Incorrect: Non-functioning adrenal malignancies are usually larger (≥4 cm), found incidentally, and are not typically associated with systemic symptoms. In contrast, this patient has clinical and laboratory findings consistent with hyperaldosteronism, making an aldosterone-producing adrenal mass more likely.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for follow-up. Recent computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen revealed an incidental adrenal mass. Subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a 5 cm mass with an irregular shape and borders, hypervascularity, and scattered calcifications. The patient otherwise feels well and has no symptoms. There is no significant past medical history, and no medications are taken. Temperature is 37.3ºC (99.1ºF), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears well. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen is soft, non-distended, and non-tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s adrenal lesion?
questions.solution:
This 58-year-old patient presents with an asymptomatic, incidentally discovered adrenal mass. The lesion’s size (5 cm), irregularity, hypervascularity, and calcifications are overly concerning for adrenal malignancy and warrant evaluation for surgical resection.        

Adrenal masses are often detected incidentally on abdominal imaging but may also be identified during evaluation for hormone-related conditions such as hypercortisolism, hyperaldosteronism, or pheochromocytoma. In the absence of hormonal activity and concerning imaging features, these lesions are typically referred to as incidentalomas. Patients with suggestive symptoms should undergo targeted hormonal testing based on their clinical presentation.        

Malignant adrenal masses can often be identified based on CT or MRI findings, particularly in the absence of biochemical evidence of hormone excess. Radiographic features concerning for malignancy include size ≥4 cm, irregular shape and/or borders, density ≥10 Hounsfield units, and high-risk features such as calcifications, hypervascularity, and necrosis. When these findings are present, referral for surgical evaluation is indicated.   

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical resection:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Phentolamine:
Incorrect: Phentolamine can be used to treat pheochromocytomas, particularly during the preoperative period. However, this patient has no signs or symptoms suggestive of catecholamine secretion, and the imaging findings are concerning for adrenal malignancy. 
❌ Adrenal vein sampling:
Incorrect: Adrenal vein sampling is used to lateralize aldosterone production in patients with biochemically confirmed primary hyperaldosteronism prior to surgical resection. This patient has no biochemical evidence of hormone excess, and the imaging characteristics of the adrenal mass are more suggestive of malignancy. 
❌ Repeat imaging in six months:
Incorrect: Surveillance is appropriate for small, radiographically benign lesions. However, the imaging features of this patient’s adrenal mass are highly suspicious for malignancy. Surveillance without intervention would not be appropriate. 
❌ Dexamethasone suppression test:
Incorrect: This test can be used to determine the cause of hypercortisolism, such as from a cortisol-producing adrenal mass. However, this patient does not have signs or symptoms of hypercortisolism, and the imaging findings are concerning for adrenal malignancy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with two days of fever and abdominal discomfort. The patient describes the pain as a dull ache beneath the left rib cage. The pain has been constant, without any specific exacerbating or alleviating factors. The patient recently returned from a two-week vacation on a sheep farm in South America. There is no significant past medical history, and the patient takes no medications. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or drugs. Temperature is 38.4ºC (101.1ºF), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued but otherwise in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is unremarkable. There is fullness and tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Scattered petechiae are present over the forearms and legs. No lymphadenopathy is noted. An abdominal ultrasound is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 42-year-old woman with recent travel to South America and exposure to sheep presents with fever and left upper quadrant abdominal discomfort. Of the answer choices available, an echinococcal cyst is most likely given the patient’s recent travel history.        

Splenic masses can occur as primary lesions or due to systemic disease. Patients frequently present with left upper quadrant abdominal tenderness or fullness. Additional findings include early satiety due to splenomegaly, and fever is relatively common. In certain cases, such as lymphoma, unintentional weight loss and/or night sweats can occur. Historical factors, such as trauma (splenic pseudocyst), intravenous drug use (splenic abscess), portal hypertension or pregnancy (splenic artery aneurysm), or other malignancy (splenic metastasis) may aid in prioritizing the differential diagnosis.        

On physical examination, left upper quadrant tenderness and fullness or a palpable abnormality are often present. Petechiae and ecchymoses may also be observed in some cases. Further imaging with abdominal ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) is often necessary to make a final diagnosis.   



Option Analysis

✅ Echinococcal cyst:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Splenic abscess:
Incorrect: A splenic abscess should be considered given this patient’s fever and left upper quadrant tenderness. However, splenic abscesses typically occur in the context of infections, such as infective endocarditis, hematogenous spread from other infected organs, or direct penetration from trauma. The lack of risk factors, including signs suggestive of endocarditis or a history of intravenous drug use, makes this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Splenic lymphoma:
Incorrect: Lymphoma should be considered given this patient’s fever and left upper quadrant tenderness. However, the patient’s recent travel to South America and exposure to sheep makes an infectious source more likely. Additionally, the absence of lymphadenopathy, weight loss, night sweats, or other typical signs of lymphoma make this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Splenic artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: Splenic artery aneurysms tend to occur in pregnant individuals or those with chronic medical conditions, such as severe atherosclerotic disease or portal hypertension. Aneurysms are typically asymptomatic until rupture, which would then be associated with signs of acute hemorrhage, such as hypotension, abdominal distention, and severe abdominal pain. 
❌ Splenic metastases:
Incorrect: Diffuse infiltration of the spleen with metastatic lesions could lead to fever and left upper quadrant tenderness. However, this patient has no significant history, symptoms, or signs pointing toward a primary tumor or suggesting malignancy.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for a routine health maintenance visit. The patient reports no current symptoms. Medical history is significant for seasonal allergies, and there is no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Temperature 37°C (98.6°F), pulse 72/min, respirations 16/min, blood pressure 118/76 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no palpable breast masses or lymphadenopathy. A routine breast cancer risk assessment is performed. Which of the following, if present, would most significantly increase this patient’s risk?

choices.text: Age at first birth of 24 years
Use of combined hormonal contraceptives for 15 years
Personal history of chest radiation at age 20

questions.solution:
This healthy biologically female patient presents for a routine health maintenance visit, which includes a breast cancer risk assessment. Of the options listed, a personal history of chest radiation at age 20 is the most significant factor increasing this individual’s risk for breast cancer. Radiation exposure during adolescence or early adulthood can cause DNA damage and cellular changes in breast tissue, markedly elevating the lifetime risk of breast malignancies. This risk factor is well-documented, particularly in patients treated for conditions like Hodgkin lymphoma, and requires careful screening and risk assessment.

When evaluating adults for breast cancer screening, key elements of the history and exam include assessing personal and family history of breast or ovarian cancers, previous biopsies, and exposure to radiation. Increasing age, obesity after menopause, early menarche, nulliparity, older age at first live birth, late menopause, personal use of hormone replacement therapy, dense breast tissue, known genetic mutations (e.g. BRCA mutations), personal history of breast disease, and Ashkenazi Jewish ethnicity are known risk factors for breast cancer.

Additionally, a thorough physical exam should assess for palpable masses, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy, which guide further diagnostic work-up and screening strategies.

Option Analysis

❌ Age at first birth of 24 years:
Incorrect: Older age at first birth can slightly increase the risk of breast cancer. A first birth at age 24 does not significantly impact this risk.
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity increases the risk of postmenopausal breast cancer due to higher estrogen levels but is generally considered a less significant risk factor than genetic mutations or a history of chest radiation.
❌ Menarche at age 16:
Incorrect: Late menarche (after age 13) is generally not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Early menarche (before age 12) is a more significant risk factor.
❌ Use of combined hormonal contraceptives for 15 years:
Incorrect: While long-term use of combined hormonal contraceptives can slightly increase breast cancer risk, this increase is generally less significant than genetic mutations or prior chest radiation exposure.
✅ Personal history of chest radiation at age 20:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for a routine health maintenance visit. The patient is asymptomatic and feels well overall. The medical history is unremarkable, with no prior surgeries or significant illnesses. She is not on any medication and has no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. The patient smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and consumes an average of 3 glasses of wine per week. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Head, neck, heart, lung, abdominal, and skin exams are normal. Based on age and risk factors, the Tyrer-Cuzick model estimates a lifetime breast cancer risk of 14%. The patient reports no breast symptoms but would like to initiate screening. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to screen this patient?
questions.solution:
Individuals are considered at moderate or average risk for breast cancer if their lifetime risk estimate is less than 20% based on validated screening tools such as the Tyrer-Cuzick model. For these individuals, routine screening with mammography typically begins at age 40.

Screening guidelines vary between professional organizations. In general, a risk assessment should be performed between ages 25 and 30 using a validated risk-prediction model (e.g., Gail model, Tyrer-Cuzick model). According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), clinical breast exams (CBE) may be offered, though other organizations no longer recommend their routine use. Abnormalities identified during CBE should be evaluated with imaging, typically ultrasound and mammography for individuals over 30. For individuals at average or moderate risk, screening mammography is recommended, starting at age 40 and continuing until age 75, or until life expectancy is less than 10 years.

Individuals at higher risk (i.e. lifetime risk greater than 20%) should be assessed for pathogenic mutations. Depending on clinical factors, it is often appropriate to begin annual screening at age 25 with MRI, mammography, and CBE.

Option Analysis

❌ Ultrasound:
Incorrect: Ultrasound is typically used for evaluating palpable breast abnormalities or inconclusive imaging findings, not as a routine screening tool for asymptomatic individuals at average risk.
✅ Mammogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: Breast MRI is generally reserved for individuals with higher risk, such as those with BRCA mutations or strong family histories of breast cancer. This patient’s risk estimate (<20%) does not warrant MRI screening.
❌ Clinical breast exam:
Incorrect: While clinical breast exams may be offered annually for individuals aged 40 and older, most professional societies no longer recommend them as a primary screening tool. Mammography has more supportive evidence for routine screening.
❌ Referral to a genetic counselor:
Incorrect: Referral to a genetic counselor is typically indicated for individuals with a significant family history or known genetic mutations. Since this patient has no relevant family history and a lifetime risk below 20%, genetic counseling is not necessary at this time.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the OB/GYN clinic reporting a gradually enlarging, moderately tender lump in the right breast that was first noticed two weeks ago. The patient is currently breastfeeding. There is no history of fever, skin changes, abnormal nipple discharge, or recent trauma. Medical history is unremarkable, and prenatal vitamins are the only medication. Family history is negative for breast or ovarian cancer. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure 116/68 mmHg. On palpation, the right breast has a well-circumscribed, mobile, tender, firm mass without overlying skin changes or nipple abnormalities. No axillary lymphadenopathy is noted. Laboratory results are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
In lactating patients presenting with a breast mass but without signs of mastitis (e.g., fever, tenderness, or nipple discharge), it is important to identify benign cysts or possible malignancies. Imaging is the appropriate next step to evaluate the mass. In patients under age 30, ultrasound alone is usually sufficient, but after age 30, mammography is  recommended in addition to ultrasound.    

The diagnostic evaluation of mastalgia begins with a focused history and physical examination, which may or may not reveal abnormalities on breast exam. A normal breast exam may suggest cyclical or noncyclical mastalgia or extramammary chest wall pain. An abnormal exam can be seen in conditions such as mastitis, gynecomastia, breast cancer, or benign breast masses. Imaging is generally indicated when a palpable breast mass is detected.   

Ultrasound can differentiate solid from cystic masses. Features suggestive of malignancy include irregular or indistinct margins, internal echoes, calcifications, and increased vascularity. Mammography findings such as asymmetric densities, spiculated lesions, or suspicious calcifications raise concern for malignancy. When imaging is suspicious, a core needle biopsy is necessary for definitive diagnosis.   



Option Analysis

✅ Ultrasound and mammogram :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound:
Incorrect: Ultrasound is useful for evaluating breast masses but should be combined with mammography in patients over age 30 to improve diagnostic accuracy, as ultrasound alone may miss subtle malignant features better characterized with both modalities. 
❌ Mammogram:
Incorrect: Mammography alone is less sensitive in lactating women due to increased breast density and milk production, which can obscure lesions. Therefore, ultrasound plus mammography provides a more comprehensive evaluation in this setting. 
❌ Culture and gram stain of breastmilk:
Incorrect: This patient has no nipple discharge and no signs of infection or abscess. Culture and gram stain are indicated when discharge is present or when mastitis or abscess is suspected. 
❌ Core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: Biopsy is indicated when imaging reveals suspicious features suggestive of malignancy or if the mass persists with concerning characteristics. In this case, imaging is the appropriate initial step, with biopsy reserved for imaging findings that warrant tissue diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OB/GYN clinic reporting diffuse, bilateral breast pain that consistently occurs in the week leading up to her menstrual period. The pain, described as dull and aching, has been ongoing for several months and worsens during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, improving after menstruation begins. The patient reports no palpable lumps, nipple changes, or skin abnormalities. The medical history is unremarkable, and no medications are taken. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/66 mmHg. Physical examination reveals no masses, skin changes, or nipple abnormalities. The pelvic exam is normal. No imaging or laboratory tests have been performed yet. Which of the following is indicated?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral, diffuse breast pain that correlates with the menstrual cycle (worsening during the luteal phase and improving after menses) and a normal physical exam; this presentation is highly suggestive of cyclic mastalgia, which can be diagnosed based on clinical history and physical examination alone, without the need for further imaging or tests.    

When formulating a differential diagnosis of breast pain, the clinician should begin with a focused history and exam. An abnormal breast exam may suggest conditions such as mastitis, breast cancer, or a benign breast mass, which often require further evaluation such as laboratory studies, cultures, and imaging with ultrasound and/or mammography.   

In contrast, a normal exam may be seen with cyclical or noncyclical mastalgia or extramammary chest wall pain. The history and physical examination are key in differentiating and diagnosing these conditions and are summarized in the table above.    



Option Analysis

❌ Ultrasound:
Incorrect: Ultrasound is unnecessary in this case because the patient's history and physical exam are consistent with benign cyclic mastalgia, which can be diagnosed clinically. Routine imaging is reserved for cases with abnormal findings, such as a mass or skin changes, or persistent, atypical symptoms. 
❌ Mammogram:
Incorrect: A mammogram is not indicated in the setting of a normal physical exam and a presentation that is typical of benign cyclic pain. Imaging is generally reserved for patients with focal findings (e.g. mass), risk factors (e.g. strong family history), or persistent abnormalities. 
❌ Ultrasound and mammogram:
Incorrect: This patient presents with bilateral, diffuse pain that correlates with the menstrual cycle and no physical abnormalities; this presentation is strongly suggestive of cyclic mastalgia for which combined imaging is unnecessary. 
❌ Core needle biopsy:
Incorrect: The patient's symptoms are consistent with benign cyclic mastalgia, which is linked to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle. A biopsy is typically used to evaluate abnormal findings such as a mass or suspicious lesions, which are not present in this case. 
✅ No additional testing is required.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents for evaluation of bloody bowel movements. Over the past five months, the patient has had recurrent episodes of bright red blood covering her stool and associated perianal itching. She has not experienced unintentional weight loss, decreased appetite, pain with defecation, or a change in stool caliber. The patient works as a truck driver, and her diet consists mainly of fast food. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg, and pulse is 90/min. The external anorectal examination is unremarkable. Endoscopy reveals the following findings at the anorectal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with painless hematochezia and perianal pruritus with a history of a low-fiber diet and prolonged sitting. Endoscopic examination reveals multiple purplish-red swollen lumps at the anorectal junction. Together, these findings are consistent with internal hemorrhoids.   

Hemorrhoids refer to varicose veins at the anorectum that form secondary to persistently elevated venous pressure in the hemorrhoidal plexus. Risk factors include prolonged or excessive straining, constipation, and increased age.  

Hemorrhoids can be classified as external (distal to the dentate line), internal (proximal to the dentate line), or combined (found on both sides of the dentate line).  

Patients with external hemorrhoids typically present with a history of a palpable external lump, anal pruritis, and perianal pain. Bleeding from external hemorrhoids is not typical. External hemorrhoids can be diagnosed with a digital rectal examination and may appear as tender, soft, swollen, or red lumps. Patients may develop non-tender skin tags from previous episodes of inflammation and thrombosis. In contrast patients with internal hemorrhoids present with painless bleeding with defecation and anal pruritis. Patients with internal hemorrhoids may present with prolapse of hemorrhoids out through the anus or they may not have any visible or palpable lumps. Anoscopy is typically required for the diagnosis of internal hemorrhoids.   

Option Analysis

❌ Colorectal cancer  :
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer can cause hematochezia, melena, unintentional weight loss, and changes in bowel habits (if the cancer is causing significant luminal narrowing). Colorectal cancer typically presents as a friable mass rather than multiple purplish-red swollen lumps.  
❌ Inflammatory bowel disease  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with multiple purplish-red swollen lumps in the anorectal region that are consistent with hemorrhoids. Inflammatory bowel disease presents with mucosal friability, erosion, and ulceration.   
❌ Perianal abscess:
Incorrect: Perianal abscesses are painful. This patient presents with painless hematochezia and perianal pruritus in the setting of multiple purplish-red swollen lumps identified on endoscopic examination. These findings are consistent with internal hemorrhoids.  
✅ Internal hemorrhoids  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Condyloma acuminatum  :
Incorrect: Condyloma acuminatum (also termed anogenital warts) is a skin infection that presents with cauliflower-like lesions over the genitalia and anus.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after family members noticed a new skin lesion. The patient has been nonverbal and mostly bed bound since suffering a right middle cerebral artery stroke two years ago. The patient’s daughter is his primary caregiver, and she states that she first noticed the lesion on the patient’s buttocks the day prior to admission. Additional past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and left hip fracture status-post-internal fixation. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 137/82 mmHg, and pulse is 90/min. Physical examination reveals an area of skin necrosis overlying the sacrum. Which of the following findings would lead to classifying the patient’s lesion as a stage III pressure ulcer?

choices.text: Shallow ulcer with partial erosion of the dermis
Full-thickness skin loss with exposure of subcutaneous fat
Full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying muscle
Lesion with internal debris and eschar where depth cannot be measured

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a new skin lesion over the sacrum that is concerning for a pressure-induced skin injury, also known as a pressure ulcer. Stage III pressure ulcers are characterized by full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying subcutaneous fat.   

Pressure ulcers are classified into four categories based on the depth of involvement, which is determined via physical examination.  

Stage I injuries present as intact skin with non-blanchable erythema and no necrosis. Stage II wounds have a shallow, open ulcer with partial thickness loss of the dermis. Stage III pressure injuries include full-thickness loss of skin and exposure to subcutaneous fat. Finally, stage IV injuries are characterized by full-thickness skin loss as well as exposure of the underlying muscle, tendon, or bone.  

Some pressure ulcers contain so much internal debris and eschars that their depth cannot be accurately assessed. These ulcers are considered unstageable. Surgical debridement should be performed to expose the wound bed and allow for better wound staging.  


Option Analysis

❌ Intact and erythematous skin   :
Incorrect: A stage I pressure ulcer is characterized by intact skin, nonblanchable erythema, and no necrosis. A stage III pressure ulcer is characterized by full-thickness skin loss with associated exposure to subcutaneous fat.  
❌ Shallow ulcer with partial erosion of the dermis  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a stage II pressure ulcer. A stage III pressure ulcer is characterized by full-thickness skin loss with associated exposure of subcutaneous fat.  
✅ Full-thickness skin loss with exposure of subcutaneous fat  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying muscle   :
Incorrect: A stage IV pressure ulcer is characterized by full thickness skin loss with exposure of underlying muscle, tendons, and bone.  
❌ Lesion with internal debris and eschar where depth cannot be measured  :
Incorrect: Some pressure ulcers contain so much internal debris and eschars that their depth cannot be characterized. In these cases, surgical debridement should be performed to expose the wound bed to allow for better wound staging.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is seen in the emergency department after being involved in a biking accident. The patient was riding over uneven terrain when he lost control of the bike and fell over the handlebars onto the ground. Past medical history is notable for hypercholesterolemia and a recently diagnosed deep vein thrombosis, for which he is currently taking apixaban. Upon arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 102/63 mmHg, pulse is 109/min, and hemoglobin is 10.3 g/dL. Physical examination reveals a large painful non-pulsatile mass in the right rectus abdominis muscle region with overlying ecchymoses. The mass remains unchanged in position when the patient contracts the abdominal muscles. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Obtain CT abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast
Call a consult for emergent angioembolization of the epigastric arteries

questions.solution:
This patient who is on anticoagulation was involved in a biking accident and presents with a painful non-pulsatile abdominal mass surrounded by ecchymoses which remains fixed with abdominal muscle contraction (positive Fothergill sign). These findings are consistent with a rectus sheath hematoma.  

A rectus sheath hematoma is an accumulation of blood within the sheath of the rectus abdominis muscle. Patients often experience sharp, persistent, and non-radiating pain. Because of the limited ability for tamponading in this area patients can lose a significant amount of blood.  

The first step in managing a patient with a suspected rectus sheath hematoma is to determine if the patient is unstable or stable. If the patient is unstable, the next step involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. It may be necessary to intubate the patient, establish intravenous access, and administer fluids before continuing the remainder of the assessment. Surgical consultation is required if the patient does not respond to these measures.  

In contrast, if the patient is stable, management should include obtaining a focused history and physical examination and ordering labs including a complete blood count (CBC) and coagulation studies (e.g., PT, INR, PTT). CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast can be performed to make the diagnosis and classify the hematoma. This should be followed by serial hemoglobin and hematocrit levels every four to six hours and serial exams to see if there is expansion of the hematoma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain CT abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast  :
Incorrect: This patient is hypotensive and tachycardic. Obtaining intravenous access and administering fluids should be performed before imaging.
✅ Administer intravenous fluid bolus   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Call a consult for emergent angioembolization of the epigastric arteries   :
Incorrect: This patient likely has a right rectus sheath hematoma which, because of inability to tamponade, is causing blood loss, hypotension, and tachycardia. The patient should first be stabilized with IV fluids and blood products, and vasopressors if necessary, before imagining and further interventions are performed.  
❌ Follow serial complete blood counts   :
Incorrect: This patient likely has a right rectus sheath hematoma with associated signs of hemodynamic instability. The first step is stabilizing the patient by obtaining intravenous access and administering fluids. Serial complete blood counts and serial examinations should be performed and the patient’s hemoglobin should be followed to determine if blood transfusions are necessary.  
❌ Transfuse fresh frozen plasma   :
Incorrect: This patient likely has a right rectus sheath hematoma with associated signs of hemodynamic instability. The first step is stabilizing the patient by obtaining intravenous access and administering fluids. If the patient’s condition fails to improve, reversal of anticoagulation and transfusion of blood products may be necessary.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia for the past day. The pain was initially felt around the patient’s belly button but is now primarily localized over the right lower abdomen. He has no significant medical history and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.4ºC (99.3ºF), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 101/73 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the right lower abdominal quadrant but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory results show leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen pelvis with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
This hemodynamically stable patient has symptoms that are concerning for acute appendicitis, including migratory right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia. Patients with suspected appendicitis should receive antiemetic therapy and analgesia for symptomatic management while a workup is performed to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

The first step in the acute management of appendicitis involves recognizing the unstable patient. Unstable patients with appendicitis typically develop sepsis and bowel perforation findings and appear ill with evidence of hemodynamic compromise. The first step in management of these unstable patients consists of stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Healthcare providers may need to intubate the patient, establish IV access, or administer fluids.

If the patient is stable, the next step is obtaining a focused history and physical examination, specifically noting any examination findings such as the Rovsing or psoas signs. Laboratory testing often demonstrates non-specific findings, including an elevated white blood cell count and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate). Analgesics such as morphine and antiemetics such as ondansetron should be administered for pain and nausea control.

A definitive diagnosis of acute appendicitis can be made via a CT of the abdomen and pelvis or in certain cases via ultrasound or MRI.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of morphine and ondansetron:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: This patient has abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia, but no definitive diagnosis has been made. Surgical consultation should be withheld until a definitive diagnosis is reached.  
❌ CT of the abdomen pelvis with intravenous contrast:
Incorrect: A CT of the abdomen pelvis with intravenous contrast is indicated to diagnose acute appendicitis definitively. However, treatment of this patient's symptoms should take precedence.  
❌ Administration of piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Administration of antibiotics should be withheld until a definitive diagnosis of acute appendicitis is obtained.  
❌ Oral fluid challenge:
Incorrect: Patients with a suspected acute abdomen (e.g. appendicitis, pancreatitis, diverticulitis, cholecystitis) should only eat or drink (NPO) after surgical pathology has been definitively excluded in case they need to go to surgery. This patient presents with suspected appendicitis and should be kept NPO until imaging results are obtained.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 5-week history of severe, sharp anal pain with defecation. The patient reports recurrent episodes of bright red blood on the toilet paper after wiping. She has not experienced diarrhea, decreased appetite, weight loss, or change in stool caliber. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and irritable bowel syndrome. Family history is significant for a sibling with Crohn disease. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 137/75 mmHg, and pulse is 74/min. Physical examination is remarkable for a tender superficial linear ulceration over the right lateral edge of the anal canal. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of the need for further studies in this patient?

choices.text: Lateral location of the linear ulceration

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 5-week history of severe anal pain related to defecation and hematochezia and a tender superficial linear ulceration on the right lateral edge of the anal canal. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of an atypical anal fissure.

Anal fissures are longitudinal tears in the skin below the dentate line, a region innervated by somatic nerves. They can be divided into typical and atypical fissures. Typical anal fissures are usually caused by local trauma from constipation, straining during defecation, vaginal delivery, prolonged diarrhea, or anal intercourse.
