Patients with typical fissures present with a history of severe anal pain during and after defecation that can persist for minutes to hours, along with hematochezia. Physical examination typically reveals a tender superficial linear ulceration located in the midline of the anal canal, either posteriorly (which is the most common location), anteriorly, or at both locations.

Atypical anal fissures are caused by an underlying secondary etiology such as Crohn disease and other granulomatous diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, sarcoidosis), malignancy, or communicable diseases (e.g., HIV infection, syphilis). A patient with an atypical anal fissure may also report the presence of chronic multiple recurring non-healing fissures, and symptoms associated with the secondary underlying etiology. On physical examination, deep and wide fissures, painless fissures, fissures located in areas other than the midline, and findings related to an underlying secondary etiology (e.g., perianal skin tags in Crohn disease) may all indicate the presence of an atypical fissure. These patients require further evaluation to evaluate for an underlying secondary cause.

Further evaluation consists of endoscopic evaluation with a sigmoidoscopy or a colonoscopy. Colonoscopy is recommended for patients who have risk factors for colon cancer (e.g., age > 50 years old, family history of colon cancer). All other patients can undergo a sigmoidoscopy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral location of the linear ulceration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Age > 50 years:
Incorrect: Although anal fissures mostly present in the pediatric and middle-aged populations, they can occur in any age group.  
❌ Severe pain:
Incorrect: Severe pain that lasts for minutes to hours after defecation is a common symptom of anal fissure and is not an indication for further assessment.  
❌ Hematochezia:
Incorrect: Hematochezia, characterized by the presence of bright red blood on the toilet paper after wiping or on the stool surface, is a common symptom of both typical and atypical anal fissures, and by itself is not an indication of the need for further studies.  
❌ 5-week duration of symptoms:
Incorrect: The duration of symptoms is an important factor when assessing the chronicity of the condition and the management approach, however it does not indicate a need for further studies.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is undergoing a preoperative evaluation for an appendectomy. The patient has type 1 diabetes mellitus and has never had any surgeries. The patient’s only prescribed medication is insulin. Temperature is 38.0 °C (100.4 °F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air.  Which of the following medical history elements, if present, may be a contraindication to isoflurane administration?
questions.solution:
Isoflurane is a volatile anesthetic used for the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. One of its most notable adverse reactions is malignant hyperthermia. Other medications which may trigger malignant hyperthermia include desflurane, sevoflurane, and succinylcholine.

Malignant hyperthermia is an anesthetic complication with a high mortality rate if not promptly treated. Certain anesthetics can trigger excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in genetically-sensitive individuals. As a result, continuous muscle contraction occurs, leading to hypermetabolism, elevated oxygen consumption, increased CO2 production, lactic acidosis, heat production, and cell destruction.

When evaluating patients before anesthesia induction, assessing their risk factors for complications, such as malignant hyperthermia, is important. A personal or family history of malignant hyperthermia is a contraindication to anesthetics known to trigger the condition. Remember, a negative personal or family history of malignant hyperthermia does not rule out the potential for it. When assessing preoperative patients it is important to be aware of their home and perioperative medication lists, as certain medications (e.g., beta-blockers, sedatives, neuromuscular blocking agents) may mask clinical manifestations of malignant hyperthermia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Recent elevated HgbA1c:
Incorrect: Poor glucose control is not a contraindication to isoflurane administration.  
❌ Over-the-counter medication use:
Incorrect: While assessing potential drug interactions is essential, over-the-counter medications are less likely to be a contraindication to isoflurane administration.  
✅ Family history of anesthetic reactions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Tobacco use is not a contraindication to isoflurane administration.  
❌ Recent insulin administration:
Incorrect: Tight perioperative glucose control is essential but is not a contraindication to isoflurane administration.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for 6 hours of severe generalized abdominal pain and subjective fever. The patient reports a 2-day history of constipation and left lower quadrant abdominal pain that has been increasing in severity. One year ago, he had an episode of constipation and left lower quadrant abdominal pain that was treated with oral antibiotics. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. BMI is 34 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 38.7 °C (102.6 °F), blood pressure is 90/52 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and room air oxygen saturation is 97%. Abdominal examination is significant for absent bowel sounds and severe diffuse tenderness with rigidity and guarding. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein and lactate levels. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent surgical consultation
Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast
Administer oral antibiotics and discharge home with a follow-up appointment in 2-3 days
Administer IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a six-hour history of fever and severe generalized abdominal pain associated with guarding and rigidity. The patient is hypotensive with an elevated lactate level. In combination, these findings are concerning for peritonitis and septic shock. Given the patient’s preceding two-day history of LLQ abdominal pain and constipation, the most likely diagnosis is acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation and subsequent peritonitis, which is a surgical emergency.
 

Acute diverticulitis is characterized by inflammation of a diverticulum, a small pouch protruding from the bowel wall, most commonly occurring in the sigmoid colon in Western societies. Acute diverticulitis can be classified as uncomplicated diverticulitis, which usually presents with LLQ abdominal pain, alteration in bowel habits, and possibly fever. In contrast,  complicated diverticulitis is acute diverticulitis complicated by abscess, perforation, obstruction, or fistula.

In acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation, the patient may develop subsequent peritonitis, a surgical emergency that may lead to hemodynamic instability and septic shock. Based on the severity of the perforation, emergent surgery may be necessary. The most appropriate initial step in managing a hemodynamically unstable patient with suspected acute diverticulitis with frank perforation and peritonitis is stabilization with IV fluids and obtaining an urgent/emergent surgical consultation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast:
Incorrect: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast would be appropriate for a hemodynamically stable patient with signs and symptoms of acute abdominal pathology. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization before evaluation with CT scan.  
❌ Administer oral antibiotics and discharge home with a follow-up appointment in 2-3 days:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics with follow-up appointment would be appropriate for a patient with confirmed uncomplicated acute diverticulitis who is hemodynamically stable and has high-risk features necessitating oral antibiotics (e.g., older than 70, immunosuppression, presence of multiple comorbidities). However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization and a surgical consult.  
❌ Obtain an abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: If abdominal CT is unavailable or contraindicated, abdominal ultrasound can be performed to diagnose acute diverticulitis in a hemodynamically stable patient. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization before further diagnostic evaluation.  
❌ Administer IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation:
Incorrect: Although administering IV antibiotics is an important part of managing complicated acute diverticulitis, admitting the patient to the hospital for observation would be inappropriate as the patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization and surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of worsening lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever reaching 38.9°C (102.0°F). The patient has had two episodes of diverticulitis in the past two years, which were treated with oral antibiotics. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 39.0 °C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 20/min. There is localized tenderness to palpation over the left lower quadrant. Serum white blood cell count is elevated. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast shows a 2.2-centimeter abscess around the sigmoid colon and multiple colonic inflamed diverticula with localized bowel wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for bowel rest, IV antibiotics, and supportive care
Discharge on oral antibiotics, pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic in three days
Perform CT-guided percutaneous drainage of the abscess and initiate IV antibiotics
Discharge on pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic after three days

questions.solution:
For most cases of uncomplicated diverticulitis, management is non-surgical, and patients can be treated as outpatients. Treatment includes pain management, bowel rest with a clear liquid diet, and follow-up evaluation two to three days after presentation. Oral antibiotics targeting gram-negative rods and anaerobes are indicated in high-risk patients (age 70+, pregnancy, comorbidities such as heart disease, diabetes mellitus, or immunosuppression). Frequently a beta-lactam or fluoroquinolone is given with metronidazole. If the patient does not respond to outpatient treatment, hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics is indicated.

For complicated diverticulitis, the management is specific to the type of complication. All patients with complicated diverticulitis should be admitted to the hospital and started on IV hydration and IV antibiotics. Bowel rest is indicated initially.

The management of acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess depends on the size of the abscess. An abscess that is 3 centimeters or less can be treated with IV antibiotics alone. Abscesses larger than 3 centimeters require percutaneous drainage in addition to IV antibiotics. A colectomy may be necessary if the patient does not clinically improve.
   

Acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation requires emergent laparotomy. Acute diverticulitis complicated by fistula formation may require surgery or prolonged bowel rest. Most patients with diverticulitis should have a follow-up colonoscopy six to eight weeks after the onset of acute diverticulitis to rule out any underlying malignancy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admit to the hospital for bowel rest, IV antibiotics, and supportive care:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge on oral antibiotics, pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic in three days:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics are indicated in uncomplicated acute diverticulitis in high-risk patients (age 70+, pregnancy, comorbidities such as heart disease, diabetes mellitus, immunosuppression). Given the findings of acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess on a CT scan, this patient requires hospitalization and IV antibiotics.  
❌ Perform CT-guided percutaneous drainage of the abscess and initiate IV antibiotics:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are indicated for this patient, CT-guided percutaneous drainage is not indicated for treating acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess that is 3 cm or less in size.  
❌ Schedule an urgent partial colectomy:
Incorrect: An urgent partial colectomy is indicated for managing acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation, diffuse peritonitis, and acute diverticulitis that fails non-operative treatment. It would be inappropriate to recommend this treatment before other more conservative strategies are tried.  
❌ Discharge on pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic after three days:
Incorrect: Given the findings of acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess on a CT scan, it would be inappropriate to discharge the patient from the hospital. This patient needs IV antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is evaluated on the floors for abdominal pain two days after admission to the hospital. The patient reports moderately intense crampy abdominal pain in the left lower quadrant, and several episodes of bloody diarrhea and tenesmus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 187/103 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination shows minimal diffuse abdominal tenderness that appears disproportionate to the patient’s symptom of moderate intensity crampy abdominal pain. The patient's laboratory findings are detailed below. Which of the following additional clinical or historical elements is most likely to be found?
 
Laboratory value   
Result
Lactate
7 mmol/L
Hemoglobin
12.0 g/dL
Hematocrit
37%
Leukocyte count
21,100/mm3
Platelet count
312,000/mm3

choices.text: Tenderness in the right lower quadrant when the left lower quadrant is palpated
Tenderness in the right upper quadrant with deep inspiration

questions.solution:
This patient presents with left lower quadrant abdominal pain, which is out of proportion to the physical exam findings, as well as leukocytosis and a significantly elevated lactic acid. Together, these findings are very concerning for ischemic colitis. Ischemic colitis is typically seen in older patients with underlying cardiovascular disease, and it is often preceded by an episode of hypoperfusion. Recent aortic surgery is a known risk factor for developing ischemic colitis, as intraoperative cross-clamping can impair intestinal blood flow.

Ischemic colitis refers to reduced intestinal blood flow, usually due to small vessel occlusion (e.g. from a thromboembolism) or hypoperfusion of the colon. Patients typically present with worsening cramping abdominal pain or more acute severe pain (with thromboembolism) that is typically out of proportion when compared with their abdominal exam. They may also develop tenesmus, bloody diarrhea, and hematochezia. Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, recent aortic surgery (due to cross-clamping), cardiovascular disease, and untreated atrial fibrillation (patients may suffer from thromboembolic events). Laboratory findings typically demonstrate a significantly elevated lactic acid and leukocytosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recent aortic abdominal aneurysm repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ingestion of uncooked poultry:
Incorrect: Ingestion of raw poultry is a risk factor for infectious colitis, such as from Salmonella. This patient's presentation is more consistent with ischemic colitis.  
❌ Tenderness in the right lower quadrant when the left lower quadrant is palpated:
Incorrect: This describes the Rovsing sign: a clinical finding identified in acute appendicitis, not ischemic colitis.  
❌ Tenderness in the right upper quadrant with deep inspiration:
Incorrect: Tenderness in the right upper quadrant with deep inspiration is referred to as the Murphy sign and is suggestive of acute cholecystitis.  
❌ Warfarin use:
Incorrect: Anticoagulation therapy is not an independent risk factor for the development of ischemic colitis. Anticoagulation use predisposes to the development of intra-abdominal hematoma and surgical bleeding.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to left lower quadrant abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. The pain began while the patient was sitting on the couch watching television. Medical history includes diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient is prescribed medications for these but does not take them regularly. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 220/103 mmHg, pulse is 108/min and respiratory rate is 20/min. Physical examination demonstrates only mild tenderness to palpation over the left lower quadrant. The patient is given intravenous fluids and piperacillin/tazobactam. CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates thickening and edema of the bowel wall. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with left lower quadrant pain out of proportion to the physical exam findings and imaging findings of thickening and edema of the bowel wall, suggesting uncomplicated ischemic colitis. Additional findings that may suggest uncomplicated ischemic colitis include thumbprinting and target sign (enhancement pattern of the bowel secondary to ischemia). Patients with uncomplicated ischemic colitis should undergo colonoscopy with biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

Ischemic colitis refers to reduced intestinal blood flow, usually due to small vessel occlusion (e.g. from a thromboembolism) or hypoperfusion of the colon. Patients typically present with worsening cramping abdominal pain, tenesmus, bloody diarrhea, and hematochezia. Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, a recent episode of hypoperfusion, recent aortic surgery (due to cross-clamping), and untreated atrial fibrillation (patients may suffer from thromboembolic events). Ischemic colitis typically involves the watershed areas of the colon which exist between the major vessels that supply the colon. These are at the splenic flexure and the rectosigmoid junction.

The key point in decision-making for patients with stable ischemic colitis involves the interpretation of CT abdominal imaging. Patients who demonstrate thickening and edema of bowel walls, thumbprinting (submucosal hemorrhage or edema resulting in focal mural thickening), target sign, or inconclusive findings due to ischemic colitis should undergo colonoscopy with biopsies to confirm the diagnosis. On the other hand, patients with CT findings demonstrating perforation, bowel infarction, gangrene, pneumatosis coli, or portal venous gas indicating infarction of the bowel should undergo emergent surgical consultation for laparotomy.

Patients with confirmed ischemic colitis should receive continued supportive care and monitoring for worsening symptoms. Patients with worsening symptoms should undergo surgical consultation for emergent laparotomy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy with biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: Emergent surgical consultation is indicated for patients with evidence of perforation, bowel infarction, gangrene, pneumatosis coli, or portal venous gas. These findings suggest complicated ischemic colitis. This patient’s CT imaging does not have any of these features.  
❌ Abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: Abdominal radiography is indicated for unstable patients to rule out suspected complicated ischemic colitis. For patients with more mild disease, abdominal radiography findings are typically not specific. This patient has already had abdominal imaging performed with signs that are concerning for ischemic colitis without complications, and colonoscopy with biopsies should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is not indicated in the management of acute ischemic colitis. This patient should have a colonoscopy to evaluate for fragile mucosa, erythema, erosions, or petechial hemorrhage that would signify ischemic colitis.  
❌ Flexible sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: This procedure is often indicated in the management of sigmoid volvulus. While ischemic colitis can occur at the rectosigmoid junction, this patient should have a colonoscopy to evaluate the entire colon for ischemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of uterine fibroids is admitted on post-op day 3 following a total abdominal hysterectomy. She has been experiencing subjective fevers and lower abdominal pain. She received routine anesthesia and required transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells for intraoperative blood loss. A urinary catheter was placed during the procedure and removed, however, due to difficulty voiding, the urinary catheter was replaced and remains in place. She has had two bowel movements since her procedure. She does not have chest pain, difficulty breathing, or a cough. Temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C), pulse is 102/minute, blood pressure is 136/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 18/minute, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, she has a normal cardio-pulmonary examination. On abdominal examination, the incision sites appear to be healing well without erythema or purulent drainage. She has normal bowel sounds and her abdomen is soft to palpation. There is suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Which of the following diagnostic studies is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a fever and lower abdominal pain 3 days after total abdominal hysterectomy in the acute postoperative period. She has an indwelling foley catheter. Her symptoms and physical examination finding of suprapubic tenderness suggest the presence of a urinary tract infection. Based on her history, physical exam findings, and the most likely source of infection she should have a CBC, complete metabolic panel, urinalysis, blood and urine cultures sent.

Urinalysis can confirm the diagnosis of a urinary tract infection with findings of nitrates, leukocyte esterase, high WBCs, and bacteriuria. In a patient suspected of having a UTI, a urine culture should also be obtained to ensure appropriate antibiotic selection.

A postoperative fever is defined as a systemic body temperature that is at or above 38°C or 100.4°F in the postoperative period. Fever workup in patients presenting with postoperative fever often includes the following tests: complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, urinalysis, chest radiography, and blood cultures. The specific workup should be tailored to the patient’s signs, symptoms, and physical exam findings. Knowing the details of the surgery (ie, prosthetic implant) and the postoperative day can also provide clues to the likely source of the fever.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urinalysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Troponin:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with lower abdominal pain and fever after a recent procedure. Troponin is a cardiac enzyme ordered in patients to work up cardiac ischemia. This patient is not experiencing chest pain.  
❌ Coombs test:
Incorrect: The Coombs test is a diagnostic test to check for antibodies against red blood cells. If a patient presents with fever in the immediate postoperative period and has history of blood transfusion, Coombs test should be ordered to evaluate for an acute transfusion reaction. This patient has an acute, not immediate post-op fever that occurred on POD 3.  
❌ Chest radiography:
Incorrect: Patients presenting with fever in the acute postoperative period may have respiratory causes such as atelectasis or pneumonia. This patient is not experiencing respiratory symptoms and has a normal pulmonary examination.  
❌ D-dimer:
Incorrect: Patients are at increased risk of developing venous thrombosis, such as pulmonary embolism after a procedure. This patient is not experiencing respiratory symptoms such as shortness of breath, or cough and has a normal oxygen saturation, which makes pulmonary embolism less likely.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of ovarian cancer is brought by ambulance to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and obstipation. The patient initially attributed her symptoms to her recent chemotherapy treatment; however, her abdomen has become progressively distended and tender to touch. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 72/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On examination, the patient appears somnolent, but arousable to painful stimuli. Her abdomen appears distended and has evidence of rebound tenderness with absent bowel sounds. What is the next best step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient’s abdominal pain, distention, nausea, vomiting, and obstipation suggest a small bowel obstruction (SBO). The development of fever, altered mental status, hemodynamic instability (tachycardia and hypotension), absent bowel sounds, and peritoneal signs (rebound tenderness) are concerning for bowel perforation and peritonitis. SBO occurs when a blockage in the small bowel prevents the passage of intraluminal contents (e.g., gas, chyme), which results in distention of the bowel proximal to the obstruction and subsequent complications such as bowel ischemia and perforation.

The first step in the evaluation and management of SBO is to perform an ABCDE assessment. If the patient is found to be unstable, measures to stabilize their airway, breathing, and circulation should be instituted. These measures include obtaining IV access, administering IV lactated ringer bolus, and monitoring vital signs (e.g., heart rate, blood pressure, oxygenation). If the patient is unable to protect their airway or has evidence of respiratory failure, intubation may be warranted.

Once stabilization measures are initiated, supportive care may be started, such as bowel rest, administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, continued fluids, and electrolyte replacement. Laboratory studies (e.g, CBC, CMP, lactate) and imaging (e.g., X-ray, CT) may also be ordered. If imaging confirms the diagnosis and presence of complicated SBO (e.g., perforation, ischemia), surgical consultation would be appropriate.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rapid sequence intubation:
Incorrect: Intubation would be appropriate if the patient were experiencing signs of respiratory failure. This patient has evidence of hypotension, which should be addressed first.  
❌ Nasogastric tube placement:
Incorrect: Nasogastric tube placement is an appropriate treatment option for small bowel obstruction. However, this patient is likely experiencing hemodynamic instability due to peritonitis from perforation and should be treated first with fluid resuscitation.  
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: An abdominal and pelvic CT is an appropriate choice for imaging in cases of complicated small bowel obstruction; however, this patient has evidence of hypotension, which should be addressed first.  
❌ Order abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: An abdominal X-ray for small bowel obstruction may be performed during the diagnostic workup. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable, which should be addressed first.  
✅ Administer lactated ringer bolus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a four-day history of worsening left lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and constipation. She has not had nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Past medical history is significant for uncomplicated acute diverticulitis, diagnosed and managed conservatively six weeks ago. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. On examination, the patient has tenderness in the left lower quadrant with guarding. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen reveals a 5 cm uniloculated, well-localized abscess in the left lower quadrant adjacent to a segment of inflamed diverticula. IV access is obtained, fluids are started, and blood cultures are taken. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start empiric antibiotics and consult interventional radiology for image-guided percutaneous drainage
Start empiric antibiotics and consult surgery for surgical drainage
Start empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of acute diverticulitis presents with LLQ abdominal pain, fever, elevated inflammatory markers, and a uniloculated, well-localized 5 cm abscess adjacent to inflamed diverticula on a CT scan. These findings are consistent with an intra-abdominal abscess without complicating features. The most appropriate next step in managing a hemodynamically stable patient with an accessible large intra-abdominal abscess without complicating features is to perform image-guided percutaneous drainage.

The initial treatment of an intra-abdominal abscess depends on several factors, including the patient's hemodynamic stability, the size and accessibility of the abscess for percutaneous drainage, and the presence or absence of complicating features on imaging.

Percutaneous drainage is recommended for managing accessible intra-abdominal abscesses 3 cm or larger without complicating features. In contrast, surgical drainage, including open or laparoscopic approaches, is typically used for treating abscesses with complicating features where percutaneous drainage is not feasible, contraindicated, or fails to resolve the abscess. An emergent laparotomy is indicated if the patient exhibits bowel perforation, anastomosis leak, ischemia, or hemodynamic instability.

Antibiotic therapy should be tailored based on the patient's clinical response and pathogens. Empiric antibiotics should target common intra-abdominal pathogens, such as gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic bacteria. They should be used alongside percutaneous or surgical drainage to eradicate infection. Rarely, if the abscess is smaller than three centimeters, treatment with IV antibiotics is possible.

Option Analysis

✅ Start empiric antibiotics and consult interventional radiology for image-guided percutaneous drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start empiric antibiotics and consult surgery for surgical drainage:
Incorrect: Surgical drainage is typically reserved for abscesses with complicating features (e.g., percutaneously inaccessible, poorly localized, multifocal, high-density fluid, multi-loculated) and abscesses not responding to other management. In this case, the abscess is well-localized, uniloculated, and accessible for percutaneous drainage, making it the preferred management approach.  
❌ Start empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation:
Incorrect: Although initiation of empiric antibiotics and hospital admission are essential components of managing this patient, they are not sufficient treatment of this abscess that is 5 centimeters. Image-guided percutaneous drainage is required to facilitate adequate drainage and resolution of the infection.  
❌ Consult surgery for emergent laparotomy:
Incorrect: Emergent laparotomy is reserved for patients with hemodynamic instability, diffuse peritonitis, or high suspicion of bowel perforation or anastomosis leak. In this patient, the abscess is well-localized and accessible for percutaneous drainage, making laparotomy unnecessary.  
❌ Perform serial abdominal examinations:
Incorrect: Serial abdominal exams alone do not appropriately manage a 5 cm, localized intra-abdominal abscess. Empiric antibiotics and image-guided percutaneous drainage are required to facilitate treatment, adequate drainage, and infection eradication.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left flank pain that woke the patient up abruptly from sleep. Also he saw blood in his urine with his first urination of the day. The patient has a past medical history of nephrolithiasis, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and a 20-pack-year smoking history. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and diaphoretic. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/66, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam reveals left costovertebral angle tenderness, and a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpated. Urinalysis shows hematuria. A bedside ultrasound shows an abdominal aortic aneurysm that is 3.5 cm in diameter as demonstrated below. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast demonstrates a 5 mm obstructing left kidney stone. Which of the following is the best management for the abdominal aneurysm finding?
 

From Radiopea

choices.text: Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds
Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair
Admit to the ICU for serial ultrasound examinations

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of acute onset left flank pain and hematuria and is found to have a left kidney stone on CT. He has an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Given that the aneurysm diameter is less than 5.5 cm, it is at low risk for rupture. The patient has an alternative etiology to explain his symptoms. Therefore he has an asymptomatic AAA that is less than 5.5 cm The best management is to follow him with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds.

An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is defined as aortic dilatation greater than 3 cm in diameter. Most AAAs are fusiform, which means they’re spindle-shaped and involve the entire circumference of the aortic wall. AAAs can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. While most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging studies, all AAAs are at risk for expansion and rupture.

Management of AAA is dependent on patient stability. Patients that are unstable, meaning those with evidence of hypotension, altered mental status, airway compromise, and rupture should have emergent surgical consultation for open or endovascular repair. Stable patients with evidence of a symptomatic AAA should receive surgical consultation for possible surgical or endovascular repair. Patients who are found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm incidentally that is ≤ 5.5 cm, should be monitored in the outpatient setting with serial abdominal ultrasounds.

Option Analysis

✅ Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair:
Incorrect:  This patient presents for evaluation of left flank pain and hematuria that is likely secondary to nephrolithiasis. The patient is incidentally found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm without evidence of rupture. Given the size of this aneurysm, the patient should be monitored as an outpatient with serial ultrasounds.  
❌ Administer esmolol:
Incorrect:  Esmolol is used in the treatment of aortic dissection. This patient has evidence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm that is incidentally found and is not likely contributing to this patient’s symptoms, therefore he does not need acute management for it.  
❌ Admit to the ICU for serial ultrasound examinations:
Incorrect: This patient presents for evaluation of left flank pain and hematuria, which is likely secondary to nephrolithiasis. The patient is incidentally found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm without evidence of rupture. Given the size of the aneurysm, he should be monitored as an outpatient with serial ultrasounds and does not need acute monitoring or treatment for it.  
❌ Administer sodium nitroprusside:
Incorrect: Sodium nitroprusside Is an alternative agent for impulse control in patients with aortic dissections. This patient has evidence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm that is incidentally noted, not ruptured, and 3.5 cm in diameter. It is not likely contributing to his current symptoms and does not need acute management.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient was found down by his wife this morning and was unable to be aroused. The wife reports that the patient had been complaining of upper abdominal pain for the past several days and also noted that his stool appeared darker. Past medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, peptic ulcer disease, hypertension, diabetes type 2, and a 10-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.8 ºC (100.0 ºF), pulse is 131/min, blood pressure is 101/77 mmHg and respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 78% on room air. On physical examination the patient is ill-appearing, with altered mental status, and cool and clammy extremities. He responds only to painful stimuli. The patient has abdominal distension, diffuse abdominal tenderness, rebound and guarding on abdominal exam. IV access has been obtained, supplemental oxygen has been provided, and intravenous fluids are being administered. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
Order abdominal ultrasound of the abdomen

questions.solution:
This critically ill patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of peritonitis which may be secondary to a perforated gastric ulcer. He has profound hypoxia and altered mental status making him unable to protect his airway. Given the unstable nature of this patient's airway the best next step in management is rapid sequence intubation.    

Any patient presenting with peritonitis with an acute abdomen should have pneumoperitoneum ruled out with upright chest radiograph or abdominal radiograph because the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, is considered a surgical emergency because it often indicates perforation in the gastrointestinal tract.    

Peritonitis refers to the inflammation of the peritoneum. It presents with a distended, rigid abdomen, with rebound, guarding, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. It may be seen with a perforated viscus. In addition to being caused by a significant intra-abdominal process like perforation, it can be seen with intra-abdominal bleeding, anastomotic leak, and gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Depending on the cause of peritonitis it can be classified as primary, secondary, and tertiary.    

The acute management of patients presenting with pneumoperitoneum and/or peritonitis involves the rapid assessment of the airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients with evidence of airway compromise, or significant vital sign derangements should receive the appropriate interventions prior to obtaining a further diagnostic evaluation. Stable patients should have a full history obtained and a thorough physical examination performed. Surgery should be called for an emergent consultation. 

Option Analysis

✅ Perform rapid sequence intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Order CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient has findings suggestive of peritonitis. He also has airway compromise because of inability to protect his airway. This patient should have his airway controlled with intubation and mechanical ventilation prior to proceeding with additional diagnostic imaging.
❌ Order abdominal ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of peritonitis and airway compromise. This patient should be intubated and started on mechanical ventilation prior to proceeding with additional diagnostic imaging.
❌ Administer vancomycin and zosyn:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics should be a component of therapy for this patient who presents with signs of peritonitis; however, airway management should take precedence.
❌ Apply bi-level positive airway pressure:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of altered mental status and airway compromise. This patient is unlikely to tolerate bi-level positive airway pressure due to his altered mental status and should be intubated.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of severe lower abdominal pain. The patient also reports fever and chills. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His BMI is 31 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in distress. Abdominal examination reveals distention. Which of the following additional findings would indicate the need for an emergent surgical consultation?

choices.text: Rebound tenderness, guarding, and rigidity of the abdomen

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, chills, and abdominal distention. The most concerning additional findings that would indicate the need for emergent surgical consultation are rebound tenderness, guarding, and rigidity on abdominal examination. These findings would indicate an acute abdomen and peritonitis which indicates a potential life-threatening cause of abdominal pain and warrants an emergent surgical consultation.

A focused history and physical examination are essential in the evaluation of an adult presenting with abdominal pain in order to rule out signs and symptoms of peritonitis and an acute abdomen. Obtaining information about the site, onset, duration, and character of the pain, as well as associated symptoms, exacerbating and relieving factors, and past medical and surgical history can provide valuable diagnostic clues.

A thorough physical examination should consist of inspection of the abdomen for distention, masses, or scars; auscultation of bowel sounds and bruits; palpation for tenderness, guarding, rigidity, and rebound tenderness; and percussion to assess for fluid or gas. Special examinations, such as assessing for CVA tenderness, Murphy's sign, Rovsing's sign, psoas sign, and obturator sign, may be helpful in determining the underlying pathology. In addition, a rectal examination looking for blood should be performed.

An acute abdomen is a surgical emergency that requires emergent surgical intervention since it can be caused by potentially life-threatening conditions. Some common causes of an acute abdomen include abdominal sepsis, ruptured aortic aneurysm, bowel ischemia and necrosis, ectopic pregnancy, perforated viscus, and acute appendicitis. Patients with an acute abdomen often present with signs of peritonitis such as severe pain, rebound tenderness, guarding, and rigidity. They may also report a history of abdominal/GI cancer, abdominal aortic aneurysm, or recent abdominal procedures such as EGD, colonoscopy, or abdominal surgery. Prompt surgical consultation and management are essential to minimize morbidity and mortality.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rebound tenderness, guarding, and rigidity of the abdomen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Absence of recent bowel movements:
Incorrect: Absence of recent bowel movements can be associated with various gastrointestinal disorders, such as bowel obstruction, or ileus. It does not warrant emergent surgical consultation without additional concerning findings on evaluation.  
❌ History of recent antibiotic use:
Incorrect: A history of recent antibiotic use may suggest a Clostridium difficile infection, which would present with profuse diarrhea and does not necessitate emergent surgical consultation if signs of acute abdomen are not present.  
❌ Bloody diarrhea:
Incorrect: Bloody diarrhea can result from various causes such as infectious colitis, inflammatory bowel disease, or ischemic colitis. Abdominal pain with a distended abdomen and bloody diarrhea in a stable patient without other features consistent with an acute abdomen would warrant further evaluation to determine if a surgical or gastrointestinal consult is needed.  
❌ Positive psoas sign:
Incorrect: A positive psoas sign is seen with acute appendicitis or other intra-abdominal inflammatory processes such as a psoas abscess. Emergent surgical consultation is not indicated in a stable patient unless other findings and imaging confirm appendicitis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents for evaluation of burn injuries. The patient was cooking in the kitchen when she accidentally spilled hot grease over her upper body. The patient has no other medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 127/53 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals partial-thickness burns to the chest, left arm, and lower left face. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit for intravenous fluids and pain/wound management

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of partial-thickness burns to the chest, arm, as well as lower face.  Based on these physical examination findings, the next best step in management is to admit the patient for intravenous fluids, wound management, and pain control.

Burns injuries caused by heat, friction, radiation, electricity, or chemical exposure can result in irreversible tissue destruction. Extensive tissue destruction, particularly burns larger than 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) can cause fluid loss and evidence of shock. Burns are classified based on the depth of injury into first-, second-, third-, and fourth-degree burns, as well as burns accompanied by smoke inhalation, or inhalation injuries.

Management of thermal burns depends on the type of burn and degree of injury present. First-degree or superficial burns can be managed with irrigation with cool tap water and soap as well as analgesia (e.g., aloe vera, over-the-counter analgesia).

Patients with second-degree or partial-thickness burns should be managed based on the location of injury and extent of burn per the rule of nines or another accepted method for determining TBSA. Patients with second-degree burns and TBSA greater than 10% as well as patients with burns to the face, hands, perineum, feet, or over joints should be admitted to the hospital for further management.

All patients with third-degree (full-thickness) burns and fourth-degree burns should also be admitted for further management.

Patients requiring admission should have basic labs obtained to screen for underlying metabolic abnormalities and receive fluid resuscitation as calculated using the Parkland formula (4 ml/kg * %total body surface area burn * weight). Patients with partial-thickness burns may need debridement and skin grafting. Patients with circumferential burns and evidence of compartment syndrome should be considered for escharotomy. Pain management and high protein nutrition should also be ordered for all patients with burns.   

Option Analysis

✅ Admit for intravenous fluids and pain/wound management:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admit for bronchoscopy:
Incorrect: Stable patients with history and physical exam findings consistent with inhalation injury should be admitted for bronchoscopy and further monitoring due to the high risk of airway compromise. This patient does not have evidence of inhalation injury.  
❌ Discharge with primary care follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharge with primary care follow-up would not be appropriate. This patient has evidence of partial thickness burns to a total body surface area greater than 10%, and she should be admitted to the hospital for further management.  
❌ Admit for hyperbaric therapy:
Incorrect: Hyperbaric therapy is indicated for patients with severe carbon monoxide injury. Hyperbaric therapy can also be used for complex wound healing. However, It is not indicated in the acute management of partial-thickness burns.  
❌ Escharotomy:
Incorrect: An escharotomy should be performed for patients presenting with circumferential full-thickness burns and evidence of ischemia. This patient has evidence of partial-thickness burns.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive crampy abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and decreased bowel movements. The patient had open abdominal surgery three years ago after a motor vehicle accident. Temperature is 36.8 °C (98.2 °F), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 130/86 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient’s abdomen is distended and a large midline scar is present. There is mild left-sided tenderness to palpation and diffuse tympany to percussion. An abdominal radiograph is ordered. Which of the following radiographic findings would indicate volvulus of the colon?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings are concerning for large bowel obstruction. In particular, adhesions from abdominal surgery and trauma are a potential risk factor for volvulus of the colon (which is more common than small bowel volvulus). Other more common risk factors for colonic volvulus include anatomic features (e.g. redundant colon) and colonic dysmotility.
 

Imaging is used to establish the diagnosis. Findings consistent with colonic volvulus on abdominal radiographs include the northern exposure sign (single dilated loop of large bowel extends above the level of the transverse colon) and coffee bean sign (massively dilated loop of the large bowel twisted around itself). X-ray images can also evaluate for concerning features such as perforation (e.g. pneumoperitoneum), impending perforation (e.g. cecum diameter > 12 cm), and ischemia/infarction (e.g. pneumatosis). An abdominal and pelvic CT may also be ordered to better evaluate the cause of large bowel obstruction. A whirl sign on CT (swirling pattern in the mesentery) is indicative of volvulus.

Bowel functioning is used to determine if a mechanical obstruction is complete or incomplete. If the patient is passing flatus, bowel function is normal and the patient likely has an incomplete mechanical obstruction. If they are not passing flatus, then the bowel is not functioning and a surgical consultation should be called.

When mechanical large bowel obstruction due to volvulus is identified, prompt surgical evaluation is necessary due to the potential for perforation and ischemia. This may lead to endoscopic decompression or surgery, depending on the location of the volvulus and the clinical picture.  

Option Analysis

✅ Coffee bean sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pneumoperitoneum:
Incorrect: Pneumoperitoneum (gas within the peritoneal cavity) would indicate a perforated viscus (e.g., severe complicated diverticulitis, gastric ulcer with perforation).  
❌ Apple core sign:
Incorrect: Apple core sign (constriction of the bowel lumen) may be seen on CT in cases of an annular colorectal carcinoma.  
❌ Multiple air-fluid levels:
Incorrect: Air-fluid levels (sharp demarcations between gas and fluid within the bowels) indicate that a bowel obstruction is present, but are not specific for volvulus.  
❌ Colonic “thumbprinting”:
Incorrect: Colonic “thumbprinting” (thickened colonic haustra appearing like thumbprints) is a sign of colitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain. Five days ago the patient underwent open partial colectomy with anastomosis to treat colonic adenocarcinoma. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and ulcerative colitis. At home, the patient has been experiencing nausea, vomiting, and subjective fevers. The patient is passing gas and had a bowel movement yesterday. Temperature is 38.9 °C (102.0 °F), pulse is 126/min, blood pressure is 95/65 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. The abdomen is distended and rigid with rebound, tenderness, and guarding. General surgery is consulted and laboratory studies are obtained and pending. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast is performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on abdominal imaging?

choices.text: Free intraabdominal air and fluid and extravasation of contrast around the anastomosis site
Transition point with proximal distended bowel loops and collapsed distal bowel
Intraabdominal fluid collection or phlegmon near the operative site
Increasing air under the diaphragm with serial imaging
Diffusely distended loops of bowel without a transition point

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of postoperative abdominal pain. He has evidence of peritonitis and an acute abdomen, and given the recent surgical history, this is most likely due to an anastomotic leak. This complication will appear on CT imaging as free intraabdominal air and fluid, and extravasation of contrast around the site of the anastomosis.

CT and ultrasound imaging can help differentiate between the many causes of postoperative abdominal pain. Superficial causes of postoperative abdominal pain include fascial dehiscence which will be seen on CT or ultrasound as separation of the fascial layers. Seromas or hematomas will be readily identifiable on ultrasonography, as will superficial surgical site infections. Patients may also present with deep organ space complications of abdominal surgery for which CT imaging is required. Patients with bowel obstruction will have a transition point with proximal distended bowel loops and collapsed distal bowel on CT imaging. Patients with a phlegmon or abscess will have an intraabdominal fluid collection near the operative site on CT imaging. Patients who have had laparoscopic surgery and have increasing air seen under the diaphragm with serial imaging, likely have pneumoperitoneum.

Option Analysis

✅ Free intraabdominal air and fluid and extravasation of contrast around the anastomosis site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transition point with proximal distended bowel loops and collapsed distal bowel:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of a closed-loop bowel obstruction which more commonly presents with absent bowel sounds and decreased bowel movements. This patient is passing gas.
❌ Intraabdominal fluid collection or phlegmon near the operative site:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of a deep surgical site infection which includes abscess formation. However, given this patient’s recent anastomosis and physical exam findings, he will more likely have imaging findings consistent with an anastomotic leak.
❌ Increasing air under the diaphragm with serial imaging:
Incorrect: Increasing air under the diaphragm is more commonly seen with pneumoperitoneum which is a complication of laparoscopic surgery. It typically is seen in the immediate postoperative period and not this far out from surgery.
❌ Diffusely distended loops of bowel without a transition point:
Incorrect: This finding is commonly seen in patients with postoperative ileus. These patients have obstipation and cannot tolerate oral intake after abdominal surgery. They typically have normal vital signs without fever and hypotension.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing a penetrating trauma. The patient was walking home last night when he was attacked from behind and stabbed. The patient is currently experiencing excruciating pain in the left flank. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 89/56 mmHg. Physical examination shows two stab wounds in the left flank with surrounding ecchymoses. Fresh blood is flowing out from the stab sites. Serum hemoglobin is 10.8 g/dL. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Obtain contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis
Measure coagulation parameters, including PT, PTT, and INR

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe left flank pain and hemodynamic instability after being stabbed in the left flank. These findings are concerning for a retroperitoneal hematoma that may have developed from the accumulation of blood in the retroperitoneal space.

When assessing a patient with signs and symptoms suggestive of a retroperitoneal hematoma, the first step is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if the patient is hemodynamically stable. If the patient is unstable, the next steps are to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. This may include establishing IV access, administering IV fluids, and potentially intubating the patient. In addition, blood typing and crossmatching should be performed in case there is need for blood transfusions.

After stabilization, a focused history and physical examination should be obtained. If the patient is conscious, they may report abdominal, flank, or back pain; dizziness; or syncope. They may have a history of blunt or penetrating trauma or a recent endovascular procedure. Physical examination may reveal tachycardia and hypotension as well as possible pallor and visible traumatic injuries.

If there is a high suspicion for retroperitoneal hematoma, a CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast should be obtained once the patient is stabilized. Imaging may sometimes show additional traumatic injuries, such as a pelvic fracture or kidney injury; but the key finding is a complex fluid collection in the retroperitoneal space.

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient was stabbed in the left flank and is now presenting with hemodynamic instability. The first step in management involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Afterward, a CT of the abdomen and pelvis can be obtained to evaluate for the underlying etiology.  
✅ Administer intravenous saline bolus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Measure coagulation parameters, including PT, PTT, and INR:
Incorrect: This patient was stabbed in the left flank and is now presenting with hemodynamic instability. The first step in management involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Afterward, coagulation parameters can be obtained, especially if the patient has a history of coagulopathy or is on any anticoagulants.  
❌ Perform emergent angioembolization:
Incorrect: Without imaging, it remains unclear if the underlying etiology can be successfully treated via embolization. For instance, if the stab wounds lead to transection of the renal artery or vein, then the condition would be better managed by emergent laparotomy (rather than angioembolization).  
❌ Evaluate for inguinal ecchymosis:
Incorrect: Inguinal ecchymosis can be seen in the setting of retroperitoneal hematoma. This physical examination finding is termed the Fox sign. This patient is hemodynamically unstable. The patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation should be first stabilized before examining for this physical examination sign.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right groin pain and a tender, non-reducible bulge. The bulge has been present for several years but has progressively increased in size over the past several weeks. He has not had any nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient appears diaphoretic and uncomfortable. Abdominal examination is significant for a non-reducible, tender, erythematous mass in the right groin above the inguinal ligament. Intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics are administered. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates leukocytosis and elevated lactate. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Abdominal CT scan with IV contrast
Admission to the critical care unit for observation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe right groin pain, a tender non-reducible hernia, and hemodynamic instability. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of a strangulated inguinal hernia and associated sepsis. In addition to medical stabilization, the best next step in management involves emergent surgical repair.

A strangulated inguinal hernia occurs when blood supply to the herniated bowel segment is compromised due to external pressure applied by the hernia sac and the surrounding tissue, leading to ischemia. Patients with strangulated inguinal hernias often present with a non-reducible tender erythematous bulge in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament. They may have signs of sepsis, hemodynamic instability, and possibly bowel obstruction. The management of a strangulated inguinal hernia includes prompt recognition, resuscitation with intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and immediate surgical correction. Timely surgical intervention is essential to prevent complications such as bowel perforation, peritonitis, and sepsis, which can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. There should be no attempt to reduce the hernia into the abdominal cavity, as the hernia may contain necrotic bowel tissue.  

Option Analysis

✅ Immediate surgical repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Manual reduction of the hernia:
Incorrect: Reducing a strangulated hernia can lead to peritonitis and sepsis and is therefore contraindicated.  
❌ Abdominal CT scan with IV contrast:
Incorrect: Although a CT scan can help confirm the diagnosis, it should not delay definitive surgical intervention for this patient with signs of strangulation.  
❌ Urgent surgical intervention within 48 hours:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings suggestive of a strangulated inguinal hernia requiring emergent surgical repair.  
❌ Admission to the critical care unit for observation:
Incorrect: Emergent surgical repair is necessary to address the underlying cause of the patient's condition and to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with right lower quadrant cramping abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 8 hours. She has been unable to pass gas or have a bowel movement for the past 24 hours. She has not had fevers, diarrhea, or blood in the stool. Past medical history is significant for an open appendectomy 30 years ago. BMI is 34 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 135/78 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination bowel sounds are high-pitched and hyperactive. Abdominal exam reveals a distended abdomen and a tender bulge in the right inguinal region that cannot be reduced. Abdominal x-ray reveals distended bowel loops with air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset cramping abdominal pain, vomiting, and distended bowel loops with air-fluid levels on abdominal imaging, suggestive of small bowel obstruction (SBO). The presence of a tender bulge in the right inguinal region that cannot be reduced on physical exam, suggests an incarcerated inguinal hernia as the cause of the SBO. When inguinal hernias become incarcerated the hernia contents (small or large bowel) become trapped in the hernia sac, where reduced venous and lymphatic flow leads to swelling of the incarcerated tissue.

Inguinal hernias occur when a portion of the intestine protrudes through a weakness or defect in the abdominal wall in the inguinal region. They can present in four ways: asymptomatic, symptomatic, incarcerated, or strangulated. Patients with an asymptomatic inguinal hernias typically present with an incidentally found reducible mass or lump in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament that may enlarge with increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during standing, coughing, or straining. These patients can be managed with watchful waiting. When patients develop discomfort or pain in the inguinal region, especially with activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, lifting heavy objects), they are classified as having a symptomatic inguinal hernia. These patients require elective surgical repair.

Patients with an incarcerated inguinal hernias present with non-reducible masses or bulges in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament in the absence of signs and symptoms related to bowel ischemia. These patients may develop small bowel obstruction and present with nausea, vomiting, and the absence of bowel movements. Management consists of urgent surgical repair to prevent bowel ischemia and necrosis.

A strangulated inguinal hernia is a surgical emergency associated with bowel ischemia and necrosis. Patients with a strangulated inguinal hernia typically present with a non-reducible, tender, and erythematous bulge in the groin superior to the inguinal ligament along with signs and symptoms of bowel ischemia including pain, fever, and possibly small bowel obstruction. These patients should be treated immediately with IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, NG tube for decompression, and emergent surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Incarcerated inguinal hernia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adhesions from previous abdominal surgery:
Incorrect: Although adhesions from previous surgeries can lead to bowel obstruction, the presence of a tender bulge that cannot be reduced in the groin makes an incarcerated inguinal hernia complicated by small bowel obstruction more likely.  
❌ Volvulus:
Incorrect: A volvulus may present with obstructive symptoms and typically appears as a dilated, inverted, U-shaped loop of the colon on abdominal imaging. The presence of a tender bulge in the right inguinal region makes an incarcerated inguinal hernia a more likely cause of this patient’s presentation.  
❌ Groin hematoma:
Incorrect: Although a groin hematoma may appear as swelling in the inguinal area on physical examination, it rarely causes small bowel obstruction and is usually associated with a history of trauma, or anticoagulation use.  
❌ Small bowel stricture:
Incorrect: A small bowel stricture could cause bowel obstruction; however, it is usually associated with a history of Crohn’s disease. The patient's history of right lower quadrant discomfort and the presence of a bulge in the inguinal region are more suggestive of an incarcerated inguinal hernia complicated by SBO.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for the abrupt onset of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. There is a delay in getting a bed in the emergency department, so the patient is first sent to the radiology department for a right upper quadrant ultrasound. Complete blood count and a comprehensive metabolic panel are drawn after returning from ultrasound, and the patient is subsequently brought back to a room for history and physical examination. The right upper quadrant ultrasound report returns showing a common bile duct with thickened walls and measuring 11 mm. The presence of which of the following findings would indicate the need for an emergent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography?
questions.solution:
This patient with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and a dilated and thickened common bile duct (CBD) seen on ultrasound likely has choledocholithiasis (a stone in the CBD) which can present with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, pruritus, pale stool, and dark urine. Patients with choledocholithiasis need endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) to extract the stone. They should then undergo cholecystectomy to prevent further episodes of choledocholithiasis. If left untreated, choledocholithiasis can cause acute cholangitis or acute biliary pancreatitis.
 

Choledocholithiasis can lead to  acute (ascending) cholangitis which is an infection within the biliary ducts. It is life-threatening and can be fatal if patients do not receive antibiotics, IV fluids and emergent ERCP for stone extraction. Significant leukocytosis and fever are signs of acute cholangitis and indicate the need for gastroenterology consultation for emergent ERCP.  

Option Analysis

❌ Pruritus:
Incorrect: Hyperbilirubinemia can cause pruritus as bilirubin deposits in the skin and irritates the skin. Pruritus is indicative of hyperbilirubinemia, but is not an indication for emergent ERCP.  
✅ Fever:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Jaundice:
Incorrect: Jaundice in patients with suspected gallbladder or biliary ductal pathology is not unexpected, and is not an indication for emergent ERCP.  
❌ Pale stool:
Incorrect: Biliary obstruction impairs excretion of bilirubin (and related pigments) into the intestines, leading instead to absorption into the blood and excretion in the urine. This leads to pale stools and dark urine. These findings indicate biliary pathology, but they are not indications for emergent ERCP.  
❌ Dark urine:
Incorrect: Biliary obstruction impairs excretion of bilirubin (and related pigments) into the intestines, leading instead to absorption into the blood and excretion in the urine. This leads to pale stools and dark urine. These findings indicate biliary pathology, but are not indications for emergent ERCP.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated due to pain in the right lower extremity 2 hours after undergoing a right femoral artery embolectomy. The patient reports moderate pain in the anterior aspect of the right lower extremity with tingling. Past medical history is significant for new-onset atrial fibrillation, and hypertension. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 140/89 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On examination, the right lower extremity appears moderately swollen but not tense. The dorsalis pedis pulse is strong. Sensory and motor examinations of the lower limb are unremarkable. Passive stretching causes mild pain in the leg. Laboratory evaluation shows potassium of 5.1 mEq/L and CPK of 600 U/L/. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Compartment pressure measurement of the right lower extremity
Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) angiography of the right extremity

questions.solution:
This patient presents with moderate pain, tingling and swelling, without sensory or motor deficits, and with mild pain with passive stretching. She has a normal potassium level and a mildly elevated CPK level. These findings suggest a possible diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome. Considering the patient's recent history of a right femoral artery embolectomy, the most probable underlying cause is ischemia-reperfusion syndrome which is associated with increased interstitial edema and intracellular swelling that can lead to a rise in intracompartmental pressure and ACS.

In the absence of more suggestive findings such as pain that is out of proportion to physical examination, significant pain with passive stretching of the muscles in the compartment, and a tense “wood-like” compartment, with potential motor and sensory deficits, the findings are inconclusive for ACS, and compartment pressure measurements are needed to confirm the diagnosis. This test involves inserting a needle or catheter into the affected compartment to measure the pressure. A pressure measurement ≥ 30 mmHg, or a delta pressure (diastolic blood pressure minus compartment pressure) ≤ 30 mmHg is diagnostic for ACS and is an indication of emergent surgical fasciotomy.
 

Patients who are suspected of having ACS, but whose compartment pressure does not meet diagnostic criteria, should undergo hourly monitoring with serial extremity and compartment exams. If the physical examination and symptoms show consistent improvement, acute compartment syndrome can be ruled out. However, if exam findings or symptoms worsen, compartment pressure measurements should be repeated.

In cases where the patient presents with classical physical examination findings that indicate compartment syndrome such as pain out of proportion to physical findings, significant swelling, a tense “wood-like” muscle compartment, significant pain with passive stretching, and motor/sensory deficits that progress over a few hours, a clinical diagnosis of acutecompartment syndrome can be made and emergent surgical fasciotomy is indicated.  

Option Analysis

✅ Compartment pressure measurement of the right lower extremity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity:
Incorrect: Although unilateral lower extremity swelling and a history of afib may indicate DVT and the need for doppler ultrasound, the clinical findings and history of right femoral artery embolization are more suggestive of a diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome from ischemia-reperfusion syndrome.  
❌ Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) angiography of the right extremity:
Incorrect: Contrast-enhanced CT angiography can evaluate vascular patency and anatomy, helping to exclude other potential causes of limb pain, such as arterial thrombosis. However, this patient’s clinical presentation in the setting of a recent embolectomy is more suggestive of a diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome from ischemia-reperfusion syndrome.  
❌ Surgical consultation for repeat embolectomy:
Incorrect: Repeat embolectomy could be considered if the patient's symptoms were due to re-occlusion of the femoral artery. However, the clinical presentation and findings are more suggestive of acute compartment syndrome from ischemia-reperfusion syndrome.  
❌ Surgical consultation for emergent fasciotomy:
Incorrect: This patient lacks the classical findings of acute compartment syndrome such as significant pain with passive stretching of the muscles, and a tense “wood-like” extremity with motor/sensory deficits. The CPK is elevated, but not significantly. Therefore, the diagnosis should first be confirmed using compartment pressure measurements before proceeding with surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a one-week history of intermittent right groin pain that worsens with coughing and standing. The patient denies nausea, vomiting, and changes in bowel movements. The patient has a history of hypertension. She has had four vaginal deliveries and currently leads a sedentary lifestyle. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft and nontender with a small, non-tender, reducible mass in the right groin located inferior to the inguinal ligament. BMI is 31 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 134/84 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Which of the following historical elements is most associated with increasing this patient’s risk for developing the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with intermittent right groin pain that worsens with coughing and standing along with physical exam findings of a small, non-tender, reducible mass in the right groin, located inferior to the inguinal ligament. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of a symptomatic reducible femoral hernia. Being a biological female is a risk factor for the development of femoral hernias.

A femoral hernia is the protrusion of abdominal contents, such as preperitoneal fat, omentum, or bowel, through a defect in the lower abdominal wall, passing through the femoral canal, and eventually exiting through the femoral ring. They are relatively rare, comprising <10% of all groin hernias. Biological females are more likely to develop femoral hernias due to a larger distance between the pubic tubercle and internal ring as well as a wider rectus abdominis muscle. Other risk factors in both males and females include age-related atrophy of the pectineus muscle and widening of the femoral ring either due to injury or age.
 

A femoral hernia typically presents as a non-pulsatile bulge or mass in the groin region inferior to the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle. It generally becomes more prominent with activities that increase the intra-abdominal pressure (e.g. Valsalva maneuver, coughing, straining). In some cases, the mass may be reducible, meaning that it can be pushed back into the abdomen with gentle pressure. However, if it becomes incarcerated (nonreducible) or strangulated (ischemic), it may present as a tender, irreducible mass with signs of ischemia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Female sex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: This patient has a symptomatic femoral hernia. Obesity is not a risk factor for the development of femoral hernias, and in fact, an inverse relationship has been observed between the incidence of femoral hernias and BMI.
❌ Sedentary lifestyle:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings consistent with a symptomatic femoral hernia. A sedentary lifestyle is not a risk factor for the development of femoral hernias.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings consistent with a symptomatic femoral hernia. Hypertension is not a risk factor for the development of femoral hernias.  
❌ Multiple deliveries:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings consistent with a symptomatic femoral hernia. Multiple deliveries is not associated with an increased risk for the development of femoral hernias.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was an unrestrained passenger and required prolonged extrication. On arrival, he appears anxious, gasping for air, and unable to speak in full sentences. Temperature is 36.7 °C (98°F), blood pressure is 98/72 mmHg, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 87% on 15L non-rebreather. Examination reveals a swollen, tender anterior neck. Lung auscultation is significant for decreased bilateral air entry. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Continue high-flow oxygen via a non-rebreather mask

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of respiratory distress along with findings of a swollen, tender anterior neck and decreased bilateral breath sounds consistent with the diagnosis of trauma-induced airway obstruction, likely from an expanding hematoma.
