questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Past medical history is notable for symptomatic gallstones, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. His home medications include clonidine, atorvastatin, and multivitamins. The patient has a history of an opioid overdose in his early 30s which was reversed with naloxone. Home medications are discontinued preoperatively. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 139/75 mmHg on the morning of surgery. The surgery is uncomplicated, and blood loss is minimal. Two days later, the patient’s blood pressure was 172/88 mmHg, and pulse was 95/min. The patient endorses a moderate headache. He is alert and oriented. Strength and sensation are normal in all extremities. The skin is moist and warm. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient developed hypertension and tachycardia after abruptly discontinued clonidine therapy. He most likely has rebound hypertension. The condition arises when clonidine or another α2-receptor agonist is suddenly stopped, resulting in rebound sympathetic nervous system activity.

Patients undergoing clonidine withdrawal may also experience headaches, tremors, abdominal pain, and sweating. Treatment involves restarting the patient on the discontinued medication and gradually tapering the dose over several days.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Administer lorazepam:
Incorrect: Lorazepam is used to treat acute alcohol withdrawal. Patients can develop seizures and alcoholic hallucinosis 12-48 hours and delirium tremens 48-96 hours after their last drink. This patient has been in the hospital for at least 48 hours but has not exhibited the symptoms mentioned above and does not have a significant alcohol use history. As a result, alcohol withdrawal is unlikely to cause the patient hypertension and headaches.  
❌ Initiate methadone therapy:
Incorrect: Acute opioid withdrawal can cause symptoms ranging from sweating to diarrhea. However, most patients undergoing opioid withdrawal have blood pressures and heart rates close to their baseline values. Significant hypertension and tachycardia manifest in only a minority of patients.  
✅ Reinstitute clonidine therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order non-contrast head CT:
Incorrect: Hypertension can lead to rupture of the intracranial vessels, resulting in a hemorrhagic stroke. However, this patient has no focal neurological deficits (e.g. extremity weakness) or meningeal signs (e.g., photophobia, neck stiffness).  
❌ Obtain serum creatinine kinase levels:
Incorrect: Malignant hyperthermia can occur after administering volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine. The condition would manifest while the patient was in surgery, instead of two days later. Moreover, malignant hyperthermia would cause muscle rigidity, whereas no such finding was noted on this patient’s physical examination.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain to the emergency department. The symptoms developed five hours and have progressively worsened. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 139/77 mmHg, and pulse is 98/min. Physical examination reveals rebound tenderness with guarding in the right lower quadrant. She undergoes a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis and is found to have acute perforated appendicitis. The patient is provided with fentanyl for analgesia before being transported to the operating room. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor partial agonist
κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor antagonist or partial agonist

questions.solution:
The opioid receptor agonists list is exhaustive, but commonly administered medications include fentanyl, morphine, hydromorphone, and hydrocodone. Unlike partial agonists and mixed opiate agonists/antagonists, full agonists are used purely for analgesic effects.    

In contrast, partial agonists like buprenorphine carry analgesic properties but are also used for maintenance therapy to prevent relapse in patients with a history of opioid use disorder. Mixed opiate agonists/antagonists are primarily used to treat severe pain but have less respiratory depression when compared to full opiate agonists.    

Recalling which medications fall under each class is an essential concept for Step 1 and Step 2.  



Option Analysis

✅ μ-opioid receptor agonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ μ-opioid receptor partial agonism:
Incorrect: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist of the μ-opioid receptor. This medication is used to prevent relapse in patients with chronic opioid use disorder.   
❌ μ-opioid receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the effects of naloxone, a full μ-opioid receptor antagonist. This medication is used to reverse acute opioid intoxication.   
❌ κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor partial agonist:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of butorphanol. In contrast, fentanyl works by acting as a full μ-opioid receptor agonist.  
❌ κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor antagonist or partial agonist  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of pentazocine. In contrast, this patient was administered fentanyl, which works by acting as a full μ-opioid receptor agonist.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is currently being evaluated in the post-operative suite following a radical prostatectomy for localized prostate cancer. Prior to the surgery, two doses of a depolarizing paralytic were administered in the operating room. The procedure itself was uncomplicated; however, the patient is now experiencing diffuse myalgias. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates well-appearing surgical incisions that are nontender to palpation. Administration of which of the following medications during induction of paralysis could have prevented the aforementioned symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Myalgias are a common postoperative symptom following intubation and administration of depolarizing neuromuscular blockers such as succinylcholine. This discomfort is often due to repeat dosing with a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, which results in prolonged fasciculations during phase I of depolarization. To mitigate these effects, a small dose of a nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker such as vecuronium may be administered.    

The effects of depolarizing neuromuscular blockers are divided into two phases: phase I and phase II. During phase I, also known as the prolonged depolarization phase, acetylcholine binds to and exerts a strong agonistic effect on the motor end-plate to cause depolarization. It is during this depolarization phase that muscle fasciculations occur. Administration of a cholinesterase inhibitor during this phase helps reduce the initial fasciculations and mitigate postoperative myalgias.  

The depolarization goes on until the nicotinic receptors become desensitized and the end-plate is allowed to repolarize. This is known as phase II, or the repolarization and desensitization phase. Muscle fasciculations cease to occur during phase II.    

During phase II, administration of cholinesterase inhibitors such as neostigmine will increase synaptic acetylcholine levels and reverse the blockade. In contrast, administration of a cholinesterase inhibitor during phase I will have no effect, as the motor end-plate is unable to repolarize for a subsequent action potential.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vecuronium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ketamine:
Incorrect: Ketamine functions as an NMDA receptor antagonist. The medication would be of little clinical benefit in reducing this patient’s myalgias, which are likely a byproduct of intraoperative fasciculations.  
❌ Baclofen:
Incorrect: Baclofen is an antispasmodic agent and is not used in the prevention of myalgias secondary due to paralytic-induced fasciculations.  
❌ Dantrolene:
Incorrect: Dantrolene is a ryanodine receptor antagonist. The medication is used to treat malignant hyperthermia, not myalgias secondary to paralytic-induced fasciculations.  
❌ Midazolam:
Incorrect: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that helps facilitate GABAA channel opening. This medication will not prevent fasciculations during phase I depolarization following administration of succinylcholine.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department to evaluate headache, nausea, and back pain for two days. He does not have chest pain, hematuria, diarrhea, or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, and atrial fibrillation. Current medications include metformin, ibuprofen, and warfarin. Family history is essential for lung cancer in the patient’s father. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.33°C (99.2°F),  pulse is 120/minute and irregularly irregular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates discoloration of the left flank. INR is 3.5. An abdominal CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
Back pain combined with abdominal CT scan findings of an isodense collection in the right peritoneum suggests a retroperitoneal hematoma secondary to internal bleeding while on chronic warfarin therapy.    

Risk factors for hemorrhage in patients on warfarin therapy include advanced age ≥65 years, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, alcoholism, concomitant antiplatelet agent use (e.g., aspirin and clopidogrel), and supratherapeutic INR ≥3. Retroperitoneal hematoma formation can occur even at therapeutic INR levels.  Other adverse events associated with warfarin therapy include:  

  •  Skin necrosis, mediated by the rapid reduction of protein C levels on the first days of therapy. Individuals with protein C deficiency are at increased risk. 
  •  Teratogenicity during pregnancy 
  •  Cholesterol embolization 

Option Analysis

❌ Renal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Renal cell carcinoma presents with a triad of hematuria, back pain, and an abdominal mass. An abdominal CT scan usually shows contrast enhancement of a lesion in the renal parenchyma (unlike an isodense collection in the retroperitoneum as seen in this patient).   
❌ Vertebral fracture:
Incorrect: Vertebral fractures can cause back pain and may occur in osteoporotic patients with minimal trauma. The CT scan of this patient, however, shows normal vertebrae. Moreover, a flank hematoma is indicative of an underlying hemorrhage, not a fracture.  
✅ Chronic warfarin therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intestinal ischemia:
Incorrect: Intestinal ischemia usually presents with abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. CT will usually show bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, and mesenteric thrombosis, which are absent in this patient.  
❌ Psoas abscess:
Incorrect: A psoas abscess lies in the iliopsoas muscle compartment. It usually presents with back or flank pain, fever, inguinal mass, limp, anorexia, and weight loss. CT shows an abscess containing gas in the psoas muscle (absent in this patient). Flank ecchymosis is atypical.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision, stabilized, and admitted for further evaluation and pain control. His initial physical examination demonstrated diffuse contusions and multiple lacerations of the face. Throughout his hospital stay, the patient refuses advanced imaging and is discharged home after two days. Subsequently, the patient returns to the emergency department five days later with continuous rhinorrhea. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear rhinorrhea from the right nostril as well as anosmia of the right nostril with the left nostril occluded. Sensation of smell via the left nostril is intact. This patient’s presentation results from injury to which of the following cranial structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with loss of smell (anosmia) and clear rhinorrhea following head trauma suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid leak and olfactory nerve injury, secondary to the fracture of the cribriform plate.   

The olfactory nerve transmits olfactory impulses from the olfactory epithelium of the nose to the brain. The central processes of the olfactory nerve make up the numerous nerves which pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. In severe head injuries, the olfactory bulbs may be torn away from the olfactory nerves. Olfactory nerve fibers may be torn as they pass through a fractured cribriform plate. If the nerve bundles on one side sever, a complete loss of smell will occur on that side; consequently, anosmia may be a clue to a fracture of the cranial base and cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea (leakage of the fluid through the nose).  

Option Analysis

❌ Skull base:
Incorrect: Basilar skull fractures can damage CN VIII within the internal acoustic meatus, leading to symptoms of sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and horizontal nystagmus.  
✅ Cribriform plate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Superior orbital fissure :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) passes through the superior orbital fissure. Fractures at this location result in an abducens nerve palsy and loss of lateral gaze on the left.   
❌ Jugular foramen:
Incorrect: The jugular foramen is the site of exit for cranial nerves IX, X, and XI; however, these nerves are involved in swallowing, visceral organ function, and trapezius elevation rather than smell.  
❌ Inferior orbital rim:
Incorrect: Fracture of the inferior orbital rim or maxillary fracture can result in the injury to the maxillary nerve (cranial nerve V2), which normally carries the sensory innervation of the left cheek.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the primary care office for an annual check-up. He was hospitalized four months ago for appendicitis which was managed with laparoscopic surgery.  He recovered well and has no complaints today. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. On exam, he is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Healed surgical scars are noted on the skin of the abdomen without erythema or drainage. A 2 cm non-tender, non-mobile bulge is seen and palpated at the right lower quadrant surgical scar. The bulge becomes more prominent with the Valsalva maneuver and reduces spontaneously with relaxation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents without symptoms but is incidentally found to have a non-tender, reducible bulge at the site of a prior surgical incision. These findings are consistent with an asymptomatic incisional hernia.  His history of smoking may have contributed to poor wound healing after surgery, leading to a defect in the abdominal wall.

When abdominal contents protrude through a defect in the anterior wall, it is referred to as a ventral hernia.  Hernias are considered incisional when the defect is associated with a prior surgical site.  Risk factors for developing a hernia following surgery include smoking, inadequate nutrition, obesity, and immunosuppression. These factors can lead to impaired wound healing.  Defects that are not caused by surgery are usually the result of high intra-abdominal pressure such as repetitive heavy lifting, trauma, repeated weight loss with subsequent weight gain, pregnancy, constipation, or severe coughing.

Physical examination of a patient with a ventral or incisional hernia will show a bulge in the abdominal wall which increases with Valsalva maneuvers.  It may be possible to hear bowel sounds when auscultating over the mass.  Tenderness may or may not be present.  If the hernia becomes incarcerated, the area will become tender to palpation, and erythema of the skin may occur.  In strangulated hernias, the skin can become dusky or erythematous, with severe tenderness of the mass, and signs of bowel obstruction or sepsis may be present.

Option Analysis

✅ Incisional hernia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diastasis recti:
Incorrect:  Diastasis recti refers to the separation of the rectus muscles at the midline and is a distinct entity from an abdominal wall hernia.  This patient has classic findings of an asymptomatic incisional hernia in the right lower abdomen.  
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: A rectus sheath hematoma is caused by arterial bleeding usually secondary to trauma and leads to abdominal pain and a tender mass in the abdominal wall.  This patient does not have pain, tenderness, or a history of trauma.  
❌ Skin abscess:
Incorrect:  Wound infection is a possible complication after surgery, however, this patient had surgery four months ago and does not have pain or redness of the skin which makes abscess less likely.  
❌ Lipoma:
Incorrect:  A lipoma refers to a fatty tumor that may present as a painful or asymptomatic mass in the abdominal wall.  A lipoma would not increase in size with Valsalva maneuvers and it is often mobile below the skin's surface. This patient’s mass lies in close proximity to a surgical scar and changes on Valsalva; therefore it is consistent with an incisional hernia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a painful lump over her lower abdomen. She delivered her third child by cesarean section one year ago and has noted a lump near the edge of her surgical scar that becomes painful whenever she lifts her son or exercises. She has no pain at rest and does not have nausea or vomiting.  Bowel movements have been regular. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. The abdomen is non-tender with normal bowel sounds and a normal skin exam. A 4 cm soft bulge appears in the suprapubic region with Valsalva maneuver and reduces with relaxation.  Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: Referral to the emergency department for a CT of the abdomen and pelvis
Reassurance and counseling on watchful waiting
Referral to the emergency department for surgical consultation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an abdominal bulge at the site of a previous surgical incision that appears and becomes painful with lifting or straining. These findings are consistent with a symptomatic incisional hernia. She should be referred for elective surgical repair.  The diagnosis can be made clinically when a soft bulge in the affected area of the abdomen protrudes with Valsalva maneuver and then reduces with relaxation or manual reduction.  Imaging is not necessary when the history and physical examination support the diagnosis. CT can be considered if the diagnosis is unclear.

Ventral hernias, including incisional hernias, occur when a defect in the abdominal wall allows abdominal contents to protrude outward through the opening.  Asymptomatic hernias do not cause pain and are often found incidentally when a patient increases their intra-abdominal pressure such as with the Valsalva maneuver.  Small, asymptomatic hernias do not require additional workup and patients can be counseled on watchful waiting or elective repair.  Symptomatic ventral hernias cause discomfort, which is often worse with lifting or straining, but the bulge can be easily reduced. These patients should be referred for outpatient surgical consultation for repair.

A hernia is referred to as incarcerated when visible or palpable abdominal contents become trapped in the defect.  An incarcerated hernia can be diagnosed at the bedside when the hernia cannot be reduced and patients may need urgent surgery.  A hernia is referred to as strangulated when the blood supply to an incarcerated hernia has become compromised leading to ischemia and bowel necrosis.  The classic signs of a strangulated hernia include severe pain, skin changes overlying a tender abdominal bulge, and signs of bowel obstruction and sepsis. Strangulated hernias require emergent surgical evaluation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Outpatient surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Outpatient ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of a symptomatic incisional hernia can be made clinically and does not require imaging. The patient should be scheduled for surgical consultation.  
❌ Referral to the emergency department for a CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of a symptomatic incisional hernia can be made clinically and does not require emergent imaging.  Computed tomography may be utilized in cases of diagnostic uncertainty.  
❌ Reassurance and counseling on watchful waiting:
Incorrect: Small, asymptomatic hernias may not require further workup or intervention in select patients; however, this patient has a symptomatic hernia and should undergo repair to prevent complications.  
❌ Referral to the emergency department for surgical consultation:
Incorrect: Surgical consultation in the emergency department is appropriate when there is an acutely incarcerated hernia or strangulated hernia.  This patient’s reducible hernia does not require emergent evaluation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a finger laceration. The patient was cutting tomatoes in the kitchen when the knife slipped and he sustained a laceration to his left middle finger.  The patient is subsequently injected with a medication on the palmar aspect of his left hand just proximal to the left middle finger. After several minutes the patient reports absence of pain, but can still sense pressure. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication utilized in this procedure?

choices.text: Non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels
Inhibition of release of acetylcholine from presynaptic motor neurons

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a finger laceration and subsequently has a digital block performed with administration of a local anesthetic. The mechanism of action of these medications involves non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels to block neuronal transmission of pain signals.  

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. These medications are most effective in rapidly firing, small diameter, highly myelinated neurons, which comprise the majority of pain associated fibers. Thus local anesthetics are exceptionally effective agents for nerve blocks, minor skin procedures, or prior to placement of indwelling catheters.  

Option Analysis

✅ Non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ NMDA receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: NMDA receptor antagonism describes the mechanism of action of ketamine, a dissociative analgesic. This medication is commonly used for procedural sedation, not local anesthesia.   
❌ Acetylcholine receptor agonist :
Incorrect: Depolarizing nerve agents such as succinylcholine function by selectively binding acetylcholine, and inducing prolonged depolarization, preventing muscle contraction. These medications are frequently utilized as paralytic agents during rapid sequence intubation, not for local analgesia.   
❌ Acetylcholine receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking medications such as rocuronium work by competitively binding the acetylcholine receptor, preventing muscle contraction. Like depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, these medications are not used for local analgesia.   
❌ Inhibition of release of acetylcholine from presynaptic motor neurons:
Incorrect: This stem describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, the agent found in the medication botox, used to achieve long-term muscle paralysis. This medication is not used for local analgesia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care office due to pain in her right breast, fatigue, and chills. She is four weeks postpartum and currently breastfeeding. Her baby has had difficulty latching on and she often has to use a breast pump to express milk. She has not had recent trauma to her chest and she smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. She has no family history of breast cancer. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. Chapparoned exam reveals a 4.5 cm area of erythema over the inferior portion of the right breast with associated tenderness, warmth, induration, and fluctuance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who is lactating presents with symptoms of breast pain and chills and fatigue. Physical exam shows skin tenderness, warmth, erythema, induration, fluctuance, and fever consistent with a breast abscess. A breast abscess occurs when a bacterial infection within the breast tissue forms a purulent fluid collection.  Breastfeeding significantly increases the risk of developing a breast abscess, and the immediate postpartum period is the most common time for this to occur.

In addition to breastfeeding, other risk factors for a breast abscess include smoking as seen in this patient, malignancy, recent surgery, nipple piercings, tattoos, and immunosuppression (diabetes and HIV).  Breast abscesses and inflammatory breast cancer can have similar presentations, therefore additional workup should always be considered for patients with a suspected abscess who are not lactating and for patients who do not respond to initial management with antibiotics and incision and drainage if warranted.

Tenderness, erythema, warmth, and edema of the breast are common findings with a breast abscess. Purulent discharge may be noted from the surrounding skin or nipple. Induration and fluctuance indicate the presence of a fluid collection. When suspected, ultrasound should be obtained, as failure to diagnose can result in surrounding tissue destruction and potentially sepsis. Infarction and necrosis of the skin may occur with advanced infections. Fever and systemic symptoms are often present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Breast abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Galactocele:
Incorrect: A galactocele refers to a milk-filled cyst within the breast which typically presents as a painless or mildly painful lump without overlying skin changes. Fluid from a galactocele is typically sterile. This patient has findings consistent with an acute bacterial infection including erythema, warmth, induration, and fever.  
❌ Plugged duct:
Incorrect: A plugged duct occurs when milk does not drain properly, causing tenderness and a palpable lump or cord over the affected area without overlying skin changes. This patient has findings consistent with an acute bacterial skin infection including erythema, warmth, induration, and fever.  
❌ Hematoma:
Incorrect: A cutaneous hematoma refers to a collection of blood under the skin usually caused by trauma. This patient is currently lactating, does not report recent trauma, and has signs and systemic symptoms making breast abscess the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Inflammatory breast cancer:
Incorrect: Inflammatory breast cancer can present similarly to a breast abscess and the two may be clinically indistinguishable at initial presentation. However, a breast abscess is more likely in a lactating patient under the age of 30 who has no family history of breast cancer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of five days of breast pain. She recently had her nipples pierced and has noticed foul-smelling drainage from the right nipple. She reports redness and swelling of the right breast that started yesterday. She has not had a fever or chills. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. Chapparoned examination of the right breast reveals a 4 cm area of tenderness, erythema, and warmth surrounding the areola with associated induration and fullness of the tissue inferiorly. Crusted purulent material is adherent to the nipple ring.  No fluctuance or skin necrosis is present. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the breast and administration of cephalexin
Urgent mammography and administration of intravenous vancomycin
Punch biopsy and administration of oral cephalexin
Removal of the nipple ring and administer topical mupirocin

questions.solution:
This patient presents with unilateral breast tenderness, erythema, warmth, induration, and fullness suggestive of a breast abscess, likely secondary to an infected nipple piercing. When a breast abscess is suspected an ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the size. Empiric antibiotics should be started. In patients without signs and symptoms of systemic toxicity, oral antibiotics like cephalexin can be administered.

Untreated breast abscesses can result in significant tissue destruction and associated morbidity. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging to confirm the presence of fluid when a breast abscess is suspected and to determine the best method of drainage based on the size of the fluid collection. Additional imaging or biopsy may be necessary to rule out inflammatory breast cancer, which can present similarly in patients without an identifiable cause of the breast abscess and for those who don't respond to initial therapy.

Empiric antibiotic therapy is indicated and should not be delayed due to pending imaging.  Initial coverage should target Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species, with consideration for MRSA coverage. Antibiotics should be tailored based on results of the fluid culture. Route of antibiotic administration is guided by the severity of the presenting illness. Oral antibiotics including dicloxacillin, cephalexin, and clindamycin are appropriate initial empiric antibiotics for stable patients without signs of systemic toxicity. Pain management with non-opioid analgesics should be offered as needed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ultrasound of the breast and administration of cephalexin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urgent mammography and administration of intravenous vancomycin:
Incorrect: Workup for breast cancer with mammography should be considered for patients who fail to respond to initial management for a suspected breast abscess or for patients who have no clear cause of the breast abscess. When indicated, mammography should be performed after a course of antibiotics. For this patient with a known source of infection and no signs of systemic toxicity, outpatient antibiotics and incision and drainage are the best initial step in management.  
❌ Punch biopsy and administration of oral cephalexin:
Incorrect: Workup for inflammatory breast cancer should be considered in patients with a likely breast abscess who fail to respond to initial antibiotics and incision and drainage if warranted and for patients without a clear cause of the breast abscess. This patient has a clear source of infection and has not yet been treated, therefore, she should be treated with oral antibiotics and an ultrasound should be performed.  
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: Surgical consultation may be necessary for drainage of a breast abscess. This patient should first have imaging to determine if a breast abscess is present and should be treated with empiric antibiotics and incision and drainage if warranted.  
❌ Removal of the nipple ring and administer topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical antibiotics are not sufficient treatment for breast abscesses.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for routine examination. He is in his usual state of health. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia and takes hydrochlorothiazide, rosuvastatin, and aspirin. He exercises regularly and follows a Mediterranean diet. He does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks 1 glass of red wine daily. His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. Temperature is 36.4 °C (97.5 °F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 123/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. BMI is 23 kg/m2. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Carotid artery upstroke is normal. Abdominal examination is normal. Fasting cholesterol levels are obtained and are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Total cholesterol
158 mg/dL  
LDL
90 mg/dL
HDL
46 mg/dL
Triglycerides
110 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has 3 risk factors that place him at high-risk for carotid artery disease: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and family history of atherosclerosis before the age of 60 years. Therefore, he should be referred for a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.

Society guidelines for screening asymptomatic patients for carotid artery disease differ. Screening recommendations discussed here are based on guidelines from the American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines. Screening for carotid artery disease in asymptomatic patients is based on personal and family history, and patients who are at high risk for carotid artery disease should undergo a carotid artery duplex ultrasound. Patients who have a history of atherosclerotic disease, (peripheral arterial disease or coronary artery disease), are considered high-risk for carotid artery stenosis. In addition, patients who have 2 or more of the following are also at high-risk for carotid artery stenosis: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, tobacco use, family history of atherosclerosis diagnosed before age 60, and a family history of ischemic stroke.  

Option Analysis

✅ Refer for carotid duplex ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increase rosuvastatin dose:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholesterol levels are at target and rosuvastatin does not need to be increased. However, this patient is at high risk for carotid artery disease and should have a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.  
❌ Add lisinopril:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is at target levels and additional medication, such as lisinopril, is not necessary. However, this patient is at high risk for carotid artery disease and should have a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.  
❌ Refer for cardiac stress test:
Incorrect: A cardiac stress test is not recommended for asymptomatic patients. However, this patient is at high risk for carotid artery disease and should have a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.  
❌ Order a calcium CT score:
Incorrect: A calcium CT score is not necessary for this patient since it is used to identify patients who should be treated with statin therapy, and this patient is already on rosuvastatin.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office with concerns about her stroke risk because her older sister had a stroke last month. She feels well without neurologic or cardiac symptoms. She had coronary artery bypass grafting after a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. She takes lovastatin and aspirin. She exercises regularly. She does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Temperature is 36.4 °C (97.5 °F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. Carotid artery upstroke is normal bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal examination is normal. Cholesterol levels are at target. There is no peripheral edema. Carotid duplex ultrasound shows 60% stenosis of the right carotid artery with no ulcerations. There is no stenosis in the left carotid artery. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has 60% stenosis of the right carotid artery without ulcerations, and therefore she should be monitored with annual carotid duplex examinations to determine if there is disease progression.

All patients with carotid artery stenosis should be counseled about lifestyle changes including a healthy diet, smoking cessation, weight reduction, and regular exercise. They should be started on intensive medical therapy with statins, antiplatelet agents like aspirin, and medication for high blood pressure and glycemic control if necessary.

Patients with carotid artery stenosis <50% should be offered annual carotid artery duplex ultrasound if they have multiple risk factors. All patients with stenosis 50-69%, should be monitored with annual carotid artery duplex ultrasound. Patients who have carotid stenosis >70% and those who have worrisome features on the ultrasound, such as plaque ulcerations, should be referred for surgical treatment for revascularization which can include stenting and endarterectomy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Annual carotid duplex examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Add antihypertensive medication:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is at target level and an antihypertensive does not need to be added.  
❌ Endarterectomy:
Incorrect: Endarterectomy is not recommended unless stenosis of >70% or worrisome features such as plaque ulcerations are seen on carotid duplex exam.  
❌ Increase lovastatin:
Incorrect: The lovastatin dose should be based on the patient’s cholesterol levels which are currently at target.  
❌ Carotid stenting:
Incorrect: Carotid stenting is not recommended unless stenosis of >70% or worrisome features such as plaque ulcerations are seen on carotid duplex exam.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe retrosternal chest pain and difficulty swallowing. The pain began abruptly two hours ago after he swallowed a tough piece of steak. He describes the pain as severe, sharp, retrosternal, and worse with swallowing. He has no fever, chills, or shortness of breath. He has a history of diabetes, for which he takes metformin, and hypertension, for which he takes atenolol. He has a history of Zenker diverticulum. He underwent thoracic surgery for a lung nodule five years ago. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals a distended neck with crepitus over the chest with palpation. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the biggest risk factor for this patient’s underlying condition?
 

Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe retrosternal chest pain and difficulty swallowing after swallowing a tough piece of steak. On physical exam, he has crepitus, and the chest X-ray shows pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema suggestive of an esophageal perforation. In this patient, the presence of a Zenker diverticulum likely significantly increased his risk of esophageal perforation. A Zenker diverticulum refers to an outpouching at the junction of the hypopharynx and esophagus that can trap food and bacteria and lead to inflammation, making the esophagus more vulnerable to perforation.

Esophageal perforation can result from iatrogenic, traumatic (i.e. fish bone), or spontaneous causes. Patients with esophageal perforation typically present with sudden, severe chest pain localized behind the sternum, between the shoulder blades, or in the abdomen. The pain typically is exacerbated by swallowing and is associated with dysphagia and odynophagia. Physical examination may reveal crepitus, which is a sign of subcutaneous emphysema, and Hamman's sign, which is characterized by a crunching or popping sound synchronized with the heartbeat. As the condition progresses, mediastinitis, sepsis, and shock may develop.

Option Analysis

✅ Zenker diverticulum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of diabetes:
Incorrect: Having diabetes does not increase the risk of esophageal perforation.  
❌ History of hypertension:
Incorrect: Having hypertension does not increase the risk of esophageal perforation.  
❌ Metformin use:
Incorrect: Metformin use does not increase the risk of esophageal perforation.  
❌ Thoracic surgery:
Incorrect: Prior thoracic surgery may cause adhesions or changes in anatomy but will not directly increase the risk of esophageal perforation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the emergency department two hours after undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and esophageal dilatation, which was successful. She experienced sudden onset chest discomfort that began after she got home, which has now worsened. She describes the pain as sharp and retrosternal. Her past medical history includes GERD, esophageal stricture, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Chest auscultation is clear bilaterally with evidence of crepitus noted over the left anterior chest wall extending up to the neck. Abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. An electrocardiogram (EKG) shows sinus tachycardia without ST-segment or T-wave changes. Contrast esophagram shows a small limited leak. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and surgical consult

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of severe retrosternal chest pain after an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and esophageal dilatation. She has signs of subcutaneous emphysema, which is highly suggestive of esophageal perforation. Contrast esophagram confirms the diagnosis of a small contained leak from an esophageal perforation. Small contained leaks can be treated conservatively with IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI), and surgical consult for potential intervention.

Iatrogenic esophageal perforation following procedures is the most common cause of esophageal perforation, and it is associated with a high mortality rate. Chest X-ray can provide indirect evidence of an esophageal perforation (e.g. pneumomediastinum, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, or pleural effusions), but it cannot provide a definitive diagnosis. Contrast esohagram is used to diagnose an esophageal perforation. It can show extravasation of the contrast material, confirming the diagnosis and indicating the location of the perforation and extent of the leak. CT may also be used to make the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Barium swallow study:
Incorrect: Barium should not be used in patients with suspected esophageal perforations because of the risk of barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum. This patient does not need further diagnostic studies.  
❌ Esophageal resection:
Incorrect: A conservative approach can be used to treat patients with esophageal perforations that result in small contained leaks. This includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI), and surgical consult for possible intervention.  
❌ Fundoplication:
Incorrect: A conservative approach can be used to treat patients with esophageal perforations that result in small contained leaks. This includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitors (PPI), and surgical consult for possible intervention.  
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Incorrect: This patient does not need further diagnostic studies.  
✅ IV broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and surgical consult:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to her dermatologist because she is concerned about her risk of developing melanoma since her mother passed away from metastatic melanoma at the age of 75. The patient is on hormone replacement therapy for perimenopausal symptoms. She enjoys outdoor activities and spends several hours outside gardening a few times per week. Her diet consists of dairy, seafood, and red meat. She smokes a half-pack of cigarettes daily and consumes 1-2 alcoholic beverages daily. Vitals are within normal limits. The dermatologist identifies several atypical moles on skin examination. Which of the following is the most effective method for her to reduce her risk of developing melanoma?

choices.text: Avoid sun exposure during peak hours

questions.solution:
Skin cancer is one of the most common cancers in the United States. The incidence of melanoma is increasing. The most effective methods for preventing melanoma include decreasing exposure to UV rays from sunlight by limiting time outdoors during peak hours, wearing sun-protective clothing, and using broad-spectrum waterproof sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher.  Also, patients should avoid artificial UV rays like those used in tanning beds.    

People who are over 50 years of age are at increased risk of developing melanoma; as are people who are sun-sensitive (ie., red or blonde hair, light eye color, light skin pigmentation, freckling). Other risk factors include a nevi count greater than 50 with or without large, atypical nevi. Additionally, personal or family history of skin cancer, immunosuppression, and treatment with chronic immunosuppressive therapies increase the risk of melanoma. Lastly, there is an increased risk of melanomas in patients with certain genetic disorders, such as xeroderma pigmentosum or albinism.  

Patients who are at increased risk for developing melanoma should be counseled about preventative measures, self-examination, and regular dermatologic evaluation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Avoid sun exposure during peak hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Quit cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: Although skin changes may be related to smoking, smoking has not been found to be an independent risk factor for the development of melanoma.
❌ Reduce alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: There has not been a conclusive study linking increased alcohol consumption with the development of melanoma. 
❌ Consume more vegetables:
Incorrect: Studies addressing the role of dietary factors (eg, antioxidants, retinoids, vitamin C, and vitamin E) have not shown a consistent impact of diet on the incidence of melanoma.
❌ Stop hormonal therapy:
Incorrect: There has been conflicting evidence on whether or not hormonal therapy increases the risk of developing melanoma in women. Sun exposure is a more significant risk factor that can be mitigated to reduce the risk of developing melanoma.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care office to review results of an abnormal breast MRI. The patient has been undergoing yearly screening magnetic resonance imaging of the breasts due to a lifetime risk of breast cancer of > 20% with a family history of breast cancer in the patient’s mother at age 45. The MRI showed an enhancing mass within an enlarged duct in the right breast. The patient feels well and has no symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable and the patient’s only medication is an oral contraceptive pill. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Chaperoned physical exam shows no palpable breast masses in either breast. Core biopsy of the mass is performed and shows an intraductal papilloma without atypia. Which of the following additional exam findings would be most consistent with this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has an intraductal papilloma, which is typically benign and forms in the lining of a milk duct. Clear or bloody nipple drainage is commonly seen with breast papillomas. Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor for intraductal papilloma formation.    

A breast papilloma may present as a solitary lesion, which is often posterior to the nipple, or as multiple papillomas, which are typically more peripheral. When five or more papillomas are present within a localized segment of breast tissue, the condition is referred to as papillomatosis, which is more likely to be found bilaterally and has a higher risk of malignancy.    

Nipple discharge is a characteristic finding with breast papillomas and may be bloody or clear. When nipple discharge is present, the patient may note spontaneous drainage. The discharge can be elicited on examination through gentle clockwise pressure applied around the nipple. Occasionally a mass may be palpated, particularly if there are multiple papillomas present. Patients may also be asymptomatic without associated exam findings, and the papilloma is detected incidentally during routine breast imaging. Breast papillomas are typically benign but may contain atypical or malignant cells; therefore, a tissue biopsy should always be performed when a papilloma is suspected, with or without symptoms.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bloody nipple drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Peau d’orange of the breast:
Incorrect: Peau d’orange is a term used to describe the skin of the breast when there is edema with dimpling that resembles the peel of an orange. Peau d’orange is highly suggestive of inflammatory breast cancer. This patient has an intraductal papilloma that is benign and would not cause peau d’orange
❌ Axillary lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Axillary lymphadenopathy is associated with breast pathology, such as mastitis, breast abscess, or breast cancers. If an intraductal papilloma contains malignant cells it may cause axillary lymphadenopathy. This patient’s intraductal papilloma without atypia is benign and would not cause axillary adenopathy.
❌ Striae of the breast:
Incorrect: Striae of the breast may occur for a number of reasons including rapid distention of the breasts during pregnancy or weight gain, thinning of the skin, or with conditions such as Cushing syndrome. An intraductal papilloma would not cause a significant change in the size or skin integrity of the breast and, therefore, would not cause striae.
❌ Tenderness of the breast:
Incorrect: Tenderness of the breast may be caused by a variety of benign and malignant conditions. Intraductal papillomas can occasionally cause mild pain or tenderness but are usually painless and are more commonly associated with nipple discharge.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the office with anal pain and malodorous drainage from the area for the past 2 days. The pain is worse with prolonged sitting and defecation. The patient has a history of a prior procedure to drain a perianal abscess. She has Crohn disease and takes infliximab. Temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg, and respirations are 15/min. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Anal examination reveals an indurated, erythematous region in the perianal area with an external opening and drainage. Anoscopy shows another erythematous opening inside the anus. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test to order at this time?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the pelvis
Computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient with Crohn disease has anal pain, malodorous drainage, and 2 erythematous openings (one external to the anus and another observed with anoscopy inside the anus). These features are concerning for a perianal fistula, and an MRI of the pelvis should be obtained to confirm this diagnosis and to determine whether the fistula is simple or complex in order to guide management.

A perianal fistula can develop between the anal canal and the perianal area after a perianal abscess drains (spontaneously or surgically). The fistula is lined with inflammatory tissue and is maintained by persistent crypt blockage.

Patients with a perianal fistula typically present with intermittent perianal pain that worsens with sitting, activity, or defecation. This can be associated with intermittent, malodorous drainage and pruritus. Physical examination can reveal an excoriated, indurated external tract opening, a non-healing abscess, or chronic purulent drainage. Digital rectal examination may reveal a palpable internal opening or deep abscess. Laboratory studies may reveal leukocytosis.

Patients who are suspected of having a perianal fistula should undergo anoscopy or sigmoidoscopy to identify an internal opening in the anus or rectum. If one is identified, an MRI of the pelvis or endosonography should be obtained. MRI is the most sensitive and specific modality for identifying and classifying fistulas as simple or complex, which will determine management.

A fistula is defined as simple when the tract is intersphincteric, or low transsphincteric (crossing < 30% of the external anal sphincter). Complex fistulas can be diagnosed when MRI or endosonography demonstrates external sphincter involvement greater than or equal to 30%; a fistula that is proximal to the dentate line, or the presence of a multiple-tract fistula.  The presence of recurrent fistulas or anal incontinence can also be used to classify a fistula as complex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging of the pelvis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: While this patient has a perianal condition that needs to be further evaluated, MRI of the pelvis will provide more detail than a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.  
❌ Culture of the drainage:
Incorrect: Culturing the drainage will be helpful for tailoring antibiotics; however, a pelvic MRI should be performed as the next step to confirm the diagnosis, determine the complexity of the fistula, and guide the next steps in management.  
❌ Sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: Since an internal opening was seen during anoscopy, sigmoidoscopy is not necessary and would not add any additional information.  
❌ Barium enema:
Incorrect: A barium enema does not show the surrounding tissue involvement of a perianal fistula. MRI of the pelvis should be used to confirm the diagnosis of a perianal fistula and provide information to determine further management.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with concerns about a pigmented lesion on his left upper arm. He mentions that he first noticed the lesion about 6 months ago, but in the past two months, it appears to have grown and darkened in color. He works as a construction worker and often spends prolonged periods outdoors without sun protection. Past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Skin examination reveals a 1.5 cm asymmetric lesion with an irregular border and with a number of variable colors. An excisional biopsy of the lesion reveals atypical melanocytes with hyperchromatic nuclei with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm, without ulceration, along with inadequate margins. There is no evidence of regional lymphadenopathy on examination. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Wide local excision with 1 cm margin and follow-up in 6 months
CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
Sentinel lymph node ultrasound and biopsy
Wide local excision with 2 cm margin and adjuvant immunotherapy

questions.solution:
This patient's biopsy reveals melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm without ulceration indicating early-stage melanoma. The Breslow thickness, which measures the depth of invasion of the melanoma, is an essential prognostic factor. For melanomas with a Breslow thickness of ≤0.8 mm and inadequate margins, the recommended treatment is to remove the rest of the lesion with wide local excision (WLE) with a margin of 0.5 to 1 cm, along with continued surveillance every six months.

For melanomas ≤0.8 mm without ulceration, wide local excision is the primary intervention, with margins dictated by lesion thickness. Post-excision, biannual then annual surveillance is standard. However, for melanomas >0.8 mm or for those with ulceration, TNM staging is indicated to assess for metastasis using modalities like CT and PET scans. In the absence of distant metastases, treatment involves wide local excision, possibly paired with sentinel lymph node biopsy. If positive, a complete lymphadenectomy is indicated and immunotherapy may be provided. For metastatic disease, BRAF V600 mutation testing may be performed to guide the potential use of immunotherapy. In patients with extensive metastatic stage 4 melanoma treatment involves palliative care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Wide local excision with 1 cm margin and follow-up in 6 months:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis:
Incorrect: While metastatic workup is important in high-risk melanomas, in a patient with a Breslow thickness < or equal to 0.8 mm and no ulceration, the chance of distant metastasis is minimal, therefore it is not indicated.  
❌ BRAF V600 status test:
Incorrect: This mutation is seen in about half of melanomas and denotes susceptibility to BRAF inhibitors. During the initial management of a low-risk melanoma with a Breslow thickness <0.8 mm, this test is not required. It should be done for metastatic cases to make decisions regarding targeted therapies.  
❌ Sentinel lymph node ultrasound and biopsy:
Incorrect: While sentinel lymph node biopsy can be valuable in evaluating the potential spread of melanoma to regional lymph nodes, it is indicated primarily for melanomas with a Breslow thickness of >0.8 mm or for those with ulceration. In this patient with a Breslow thickness of 0.7 mm and no ulceration, wide local excision without sentinel lymph node biopsies is the appropriate treatment.  
❌ Wide local excision with 2 cm margin and adjuvant immunotherapy:
Incorrect: For a melanoma with Breslow thickness ≤0.8 mm and inadequate margins, the recommended treatment is to remove the rest of the lesion with wide local excision with a margin of 0.5 to 1 cm. A 2 cm margin is not necessary. Adjuvant immunotherapy is recommended for patients with metastatic or locoregional disease who meet criteria. For this patient surgical excision alone may be curable.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an accident that occurred while riding an all-terrain vehicle. He was traveling on a wooded path at 20 mph when he hit a rock and was thrown from the vehicle. He has severe pelvic pain and gross hematuria. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 146/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He appears in distress but is awake, alert, and oriented. There are ecchymoses across the anterior pelvis and laxity with pelvic stability testing. Suprapubic tenderness is noted. There is no blood at the urethral meatus.  FAST scan is negative for free fluid. A CT in the portal venous phase shows a pelvic ring fracture with bony fragments extending into the extraperitoneal space. There is no visible contrast extravasation from the bladder. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s gross hematuria in the setting of a pelvic fracture is highly suspicious for a bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the best way to detect a bladder injury, as a standard CT does not concentrate enough contrast in the urine to adequately evaluate the integrity of the bladder.    

Patients with pelvic injury and gross hematuria should have dedicated imaging to evaluate for bladder and urethral injury. A standard CT is often performed initially as part of trauma management; however, a retrograde cystogram is needed to definitively characterize a bladder injury and a retrograde urethrogram is needed to diagnose a urethral injury. These studies involve direct injection of contrast dye into the bladder or urethra, followed by X-ray, fluoroscopy, or CT.  Extravasation of dye into the perivesical space is diagnostic for an extraperitoneal bladder injury, which occurs below the peritoneal reflection; whereas dye detected within the peritoneal cavity indicates an intraperitoneal bladder injury, usually at the bladder dome. Injury of the urethra can be diagnosed when contrast dye is seen outside of the urethral tract.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retrograde cystography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MRI of the pelvis:
Incorrect: An MRI of the pelvis may be needed for surgical planning but is not part of the initial workup for a patient with a suspected bladder or urethral injury.
❌ Cystoscopy:
Incorrect: Cystoscopy may be helpful for surgical planning regarding urethral or bladder injury repair but is not a part of the initial diagnostic workup. Retrograde cystography serves as the best way to assess the location and extent of a bladder injury in the emergency setting.
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: Exploratory laparotomy may be necessary when imaging fails to diagnose the location of a bladder injury or when bleeding or signs of instability require urgent attention. 
❌ CTA of the pelvis:
Incorrect: Angiography and embolization may be necessary for unstable patients with active bleeding from a pelvic fracture.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pelvic and abdominal pain after falling from a 10-foot ladder. He had been painting his house and needed to urinate but ignored the urge in order to finish his work. He has had gross hematuria since the fall but has no other injuries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 148/90 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, he is awake, alert, and oriented. The abdomen appears distended with diffuse tenderness and guarding with palpation. There is no blood at the urethral meatus and the prostate is in normal position. The pelvis is stable without laxity or crepitus. Free fluid in the abdomen is noted on Focused Assessment With Sonography in Trauma (FAST) and CT cystogram confirms contrast extravasation from the bladder into the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the best plan for definitive management?

choices.text: Antibiotics and delayed surgical repair with reconstruction

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall for evaluation of abdominal pain, distention, guarding, and gross hematuria suggestive of a bladder injury. Contrast extravasation into the peritoneal cavity on CT cystogram is diagnostic for an intraperitoneal bladder injury, which should be treated with antibiotics and prompt surgical repair in this stable patient. The patient’s full bladder at the time of trauma likely contributed to the rupture.    

An intraperitoneal bladder injury involves disruption at the dome of the bladder, which communicates directly with the peritoneal cavity. Leakage of urine into the peritoneum can lead to acute renal failure and sepsis. Early recognition and prompt surgical management are necessary.    

When a bladder injury occurs below the peritoneal reflection, it is referred to as extraperitoneal and urine will leak into the perivesical space. Simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries can be managed conservatively with catheter drainage and antibiotics. The catheter should be placed suprapubically if a concurrent urethral injury is suspected, as the insertion of a transurethral catheter can worsen the injury.    

Complex extraperitoneal bladder injuries should be managed surgically and include injuries located at the bladder neck, injuries that involve fragments of bone or damage to the rectum or vagina, and injuries that fail to respond to a trial of catheter drainage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Antibiotics and immediate surgical repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antibiotics and suprapubic catheter placement:
Incorrect: Simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries can be managed with antibiotics and urethral catheter drainage; however, this patient has an intraperitoneal rupture which must be repaired surgically.
❌ Transurethral catheter and bed rest:
Incorrect: Urethral catheter drainage can be used to manage simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries; however, this patient has an intraperitoneal rupture which must be repaired surgically.
❌ Antibiotics and delayed surgical repair with reconstruction:
Incorrect: Delayed surgical repair may be needed for a patient with an intraperitoneal bladder rupture who is too unstable to undergo surgery. This patient is hemodynamically stable, therefore he should have immediate surgical repair.
❌ Suprapubic catheter and cystoscopy:
Incorrect:  Urethral catheter drainage can be used to manage simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries; however, this patient has signs of an intraperitoneal rupture which must be repaired surgically. Cystoscopy is not required for the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance with a three-day history of obstipation and severe abdominal pain that is occasionally crampy. His partner states he was admitted for sigmoid volvulus several weeks ago and was treated with endoscopic decompression, but the patient declined subsequent sigmoid colectomy. He has a history of hypertension that is well-controlled with enalapril. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.3°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 82/42mmHg. The patient appears obtunded and is minimally interactive on examination. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia. Abdominal examination shows a distended tympanic abdomen with diffuse rebound tenderness with guarding and hyperactive bowel sounds. No obstructing masses are detected on the digital rectal exam. Which of the following findings would most likely be associated with this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Obstruction of the common bile duct
Cobblestone appearance of mucosa seen on colonoscopy

questions.solution:
This patient previously presented with sigmoid volvulus which was treated with endoscopic decompression several weeks ago. He was offered definitive treatment with a sigmoid colectomy at the time but refused. He now presents with abdominal pain and obstipation with physical exam findings of tachycardia, hypotension, and a distended tympanitic abdomen with rebound tenderness. He most likely has a recurrence of sigmoid volvulus complicated by sepsis and signs of peritonitis. Leukocytosis and an elevated lactate level would be expected.

Colonic volvulus occurs from an air-filled loop of the colon that twists around its mesentery which may result in large bowel obstruction. Symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea, distended abdomen, and constipation or obstipation. Imaging findings will vary depending on what portion of the bowel is affected (cecum or sigmoid). In cases of cecal volvulus, a closed loop of the bowel will be seen in the left upper quadrant with only one air-fluid level. In sigmoid volvulus, a coffee bean sign may be seen in the right upper quadrant along with multiple air-fluid levels. In severe cases where peritonitis or perforation is suspected, altered mental status, tachycardia, and hypotension may be seen, indicating septic shock. Laboratory studies will show leukocytosis, electrolyte abnormalities, and elevated lactate levels.

Because of the twisted segment of the bowel, abdominal distention occurs. Auscultation of the abdomen typically reveals hyperactive bowel sounds and patients will have rebound tenderness with guarding if ischemia or peritonitis are present. In stable patients presenting with sigmoid volvulus, acute management via endoscopic decompression is the initial recommended treatment. Since the rate of recurrence is so high after an initial episode, definitive treatment consists of elective surgical resection (sigmoid colectomy) of the affected bowel.  For unstable patients with complications emergent exploratory laparotomy and colonic resection are required.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Leukocytosis and elevated lactate level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obstruction of the common bile duct:
Incorrect: Gallstones can become lodged in the common bile duct resulting in hyperbilirubinemia and cholecystitis. Patients with cholecystitis typically present with right upper quadrant pain (+/- radiation to the shoulder or back). This patient with diffuse abdominal tenderness and a recently detorsed sigmoid volvulus most likely has a recurrence complicated by sepsis.  
❌ Elevated amylase and lipase:
Incorrect: Elevated amylase and lipase levels are suggestive of acute pancreatitis which presents with mid-epigastric pain radiating to the back, jaundice, fever or chills, and tachycardia. This patient with diffuse abdominal tenderness and a recently detorsed sigmoid volvulus most likely has a recurrence complicated by sepsis.  
❌ Cobblestone appearance of mucosa seen on colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Crohn’s disease can have a cobblestone appearance of the gastrointestinal tract on endoscopy or colonoscopy. This patient with diffuse abdominal tenderness and a recently detorsed sigmoid volvulus most likely has a recurrence complicated by sepsis.  
❌ Tenesmus:
Incorrect: Tenesmus refers to the feeling or sensation of incomplete evacuation after a bowel movement and is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease. This patient with diffuse abdominal tenderness and a recently detorsed sigmoid volvulus most likely has a recurrence complicated by sepsis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-week history of pain and swelling in her right breast with purulent discharge from the right nipple. She has had three similar episodes in the past year; each was less severe, resolved partially with antibiotics, and did not involve nipple discharge. She completed breastfeeding her youngest child two years ago. She has not had recent trauma to the breast, nipple piercings, or systemic symptoms. There is no family history of breast cancer. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), heart rate is 80/min, blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 17/min. On examination, there is erythema and induration in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast with a tender mass. There is no fluctuance. A small, draining sinus tract is noted in the affected area, with purulent discharge. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of recurrent breast pain, erythema, induration with a palpable mass, and a draining sinus tract with purulent discharge despite previous antibiotics suggests granulomatous mastitis.     

Granulomatous mastitis is a benign chronic inflammatory condition that typically presents in women of childbearing age. Clinically, it is characterized by unilateral breast pain, swelling, and a palpable mass or masses that can be mistaken for malignancy. Unlike typical mastitis, which is acute and often associated with lactation, granulomatous mastitis can recur sporadically with episodes varying in severity. Patients often report fluctuating, localized symptoms, with episodes of exacerbation and partial resolution. Over time, the condition may progress to form sinus tracts, leading to purulent discharge from the nipple or skin overlying the breast.    

Unlike acute infectious mastitis or recurrent mastitis that can be seen in lactating and nonlactating women, granulomatous mastitis is not generally associated with systemic symptoms like fever or malaise unless it is associated with a secondary infection. While it can occur in women who have previously breastfed, it is not limited to the postpartum period and can arise years after lactation has ceased. Its presentation can be variable, sometimes mimicking breast cancer, especially inflammatory breast cancer, which necessitates evaluation with imaging with ultrasound and core needle biopsy to distinguish between the two. Biopsy will show non-necrotizing granulomatous lesions. Treatment typically involves watchful waiting as it can self-resolve,  antibiotics if superinfection occurs, and occasionally, corticosteroids  

Option Analysis

✅ Granulomatous mastitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Galactocele:
Incorrect: A galactocele (milk retention cyst) is a benign cyst in the breast caused by an obstructed milk duct. Galactoceles occur almost exclusively in lactating women. Patients with galactoceles present with non-tender soft cystic masses without associated systemic signs and symptoms.
❌ Fat necrosis of the breast:
Incorrect: Fat necrosis typically presents as a painless mass in the breast, often following trauma or surgery. It would not cause recurrent, painful episodes with purulent discharge and a sinus tract. These findings are typical of granulomatous mastitis.
❌ Acute non-puerperal mastitis:
Incorrect: Acute non-puerperal mastitis usually arises from a bacterial infection, presenting with localized pain, redness, and swelling. However, the recurrent nature of this patient's episodes, especially with incomplete resolution on antibiotics, is more suggestive of a chronic granulomatous process.
❌ Mammary ductal ectasia:
Incorrect: Mammary ductal ectasia typically occurs in perimenopausal women and presents with nipple discharge of various colors including green or black, sometimes with a palpable mass. The recurrent, painful episodes with sinus tract formation experienced by this patient are consistent with granulomatous mastitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for lower abdominal pain and distension, and difficulty urinating. Two days prior he had knee replacement surgery. After the surgery, a foley catheter was placed and left for two days due to difficulty voiding. He was able to void without the foley catheter prior to discharge. The patient states that he usually wakes up 4 or 5 times during the night to urinate but has not been able to pass urine for over 24 hours since returning home. Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with lisinopril and metformin. Temperature is 37.2°C (100.2°F), heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness and distension. There is questionable right costovertebral angle tenderness. Digital rectal exam is significant for a boggy enlarged prostate. Laboratory evaluation is significant for a serum creatinine of 2.9 mg/dL, increased from a baseline of 0.9 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen of 45 mg/dL. White blood count is slightly elevated and urinalysis shows leukocytes and trace blood and is negative nitrates and leukocyte esterase. A foley catheter is placed with minimal urine output. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Abdominopelvic CT scan with IV contrast

questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute kidney injury and evidence of urinary obstruction and a possible urinary tract infection complicated by pyelonephritis. In order to determine if the cause of this patient’s acute kidney injury is from an intrinsic renal or a postrenal cause, renal ultrasound should be performed next.

This patient has a distended tender lower abdomen and an enlarged prostate indicating that he may have urinary obstruction from prostatic hypertrophy causing AKI. However he also has a low-grade fever, mild right costovertebral angle tenderness, and leukocytes in the urine suggesting a UTI, and that he may have complications of a UTI causing AKI. The next best step for determining if the cause of his acute kidney injury is due to intrarenal or postrenal cause is renal ultrasound. It can rule out complications of urinary tract infections, like pyelonephritis and kidney abscess; and it can determine if hydronephrosis is present indicating significant urinary obstruction. Renal ultrasound should be performed to guide the next steps in diagnosis and management.  

Option Analysis

✅ Renal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation:
Incorrect: Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation is indicated for prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) due to volume depletion. This patient has no history of blood loss from the surgery and is normotensive.  
❌ Bladder scan:
Incorrect: Bladder scan can be used to determine the level of urinary obstruction, however, renal ultrasound should be performed first in this patient to help determine if the AKI is from intrinsic renal or post-renal causes.  
❌ Abdominopelvic CT scan with IV contrast:
Incorrect: An abdominopelvic CT scan may be helpful for determining if there is pyelonephritis, hydronephrosis, or other complications of infection or urinary obstruction; however because of acute kidney injury, contrast should not be used. Renal ultrasound is a better choice to assess for an intrinsic renal or postrenal cause of AKI.  
❌ Emergent hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is reserved for patients with acute kidney injury and severe hyperkalemia, acidosis, uremia, volume overload unresponsive to diuretics, or certain intoxicants. This patient should be further evaluated for intrinsic vs post renal causes of AKI with a renal ultrasound.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic after noticing a breast mass on self-breast examination. The patient is a Navy Seal officer and recently returned from a 1-week rescue operation. Her last mammogram was 4 months ago and was normal. Past medical history is significant for hypertension treated with amlodipine/valsartan. Upon return from active duty, the military clinic recommended regular doses of acetaminophen to treat her pain from muscle contusions. The patient’s family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s aunt, diagnosed at the age of 76. The patient has regular menstruation. Temperature is 36.9 °C (98.42 °F), heart rate is 60 bpm, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. Breast examination reveals a mildly tender 1.5 cm irregular-shaped firm breast mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast that is fixed to the dermis. There is overlying greenish-brownish discoloration of the skin. There is no nipple discharge. The right breast shows no abnormality. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given the patient's recent normal mammography findings, history suggestive of trauma, and localized breast ecchymosis (greenish-brown discoloration); fat necrosis of the breast is the most likely diagnosis.    

Fat necrosis is a benign breast lesion that can develop after breast trauma. Trauma associated with fat necrosis may be related to direct, blunt trauma or surgical interventions such as injection of native or foreign substances such as silicone, breast reconstruction, and breast reduction surgery. Traumatic fat necrosis is generally associated with localized skin ecchymosis (greenish-brown discoloration).  

In most cases, fat necrosis can be diagnosed clinically or radiographically. However, in some cases differentiating between fat necrosis and malignant breast masses can be challenging, and core needle biopsy may be necessary to exclude breast cancer.
