Incorrect: Male infants, not female infants, are at an increased risk of developing pyloric stenosis.  
❌ Breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Bottle-feeding, not breastfeeding, is associated with an increased risk of pyloric stenosis. This patient has been exclusively breastfed since birth.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after his roommate found him pale and diaphoretic in his room. The patient states that he uses intravenous (IV) drugs regularly. Three days ago, he began having a low-grade fever, and over the ensuing days, he began having low back pain. Today he felt too weak to get out of bed. He has no significant past medical or surgical history. Temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), heart rate is 124/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, blood pressure is 88/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears ill. Physical exam reveals dry mucous membranes. There is focal tenderness to palpation at L5 and S1 with loss of sensation in the saddle area. Labs are drawn, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, and blood cultures. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient with recent IV drug use who presents with fever, acute low back pain, and focal pain over the spine with saddle anesthesia, likely has a spinal epidural abscess (SEA). His hypotension is concerning for sepsis caused by the abscess. While the imaging modality of choice for a SEA is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine with and without contrast, unstable patients require resuscitation with intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics before proceeding to imaging and treatment.

Epidural abscess is a rare suppurative infection of the central nervous system. SEA can be caused by direct inoculation during a spinal procedure, contiguous spread from a local infection, or a secondary complication of any condition that results in bacteremia. The leading causative agent is Staphylococcus aureus. Risk factors for SEA include intravenous drug use, diabetes, chronic indwelling venous catheters, concurrent infection, recent spinal procedures, and immunosuppression.

The initial manifestations of SEA are often nonspecific and include fever and malaise. The classical diagnostic triad consists of fever, back pain, and neurologic deficits; however, only a small proportion of patients have all three components at presentation. The treatment of choice in SEA is surgical drainage and tailored antibiotic therapy when possible, however, medical management alone is appropriate for some patients based on acuity and other risk factors. In an unstable patient with a suspected diagnosis of SEA, the goal is to stabilize the patient with immediate IV fluids and to give antibiotics after the collection of blood cultures.   

Option Analysis

❌ Spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without contrast:
Incorrect: In patients with a presumed spinal epidural abscess, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with gadolinium contrast is the diagnostic modality of choice. However, this patient is unstable and requires resuscitation before moving forward with imaging.
❌ Surgery consultation:
Incorrect: A surgery consultation for eventual operative decompression and drainage is the definitive management in most patients with spinal epidural abscess. However, this patient needs to be stabilized before any further management.
✅ Intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Image-guided biopsy and culture:
Incorrect: Image-guided biopsy and culture may be appropriate for patients with spinal epidural abscesses and mild symptoms, without neurologic deficits, or for those who are unable to tolerate surgery or are unlikely to benefit from it due to severity. This patient has a focal neurologic deficit and signs of systemic infection. Initial resuscitation and imaging are necessary before a final management decision can be made.
❌ Thoracic and Lumbar X-rays:
Incorrect: Plain radiographs of the spine may reveal changes of osteomyelitis or discitis, but are rarely diagnostic for spinal epidural abscesses, making magnetic resonance imaging a better choice when suspicion of spinal infection is high. However, this patient requires stabilization before any diagnostic imaging can be considered.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with back pain and fever. About four days ago, the patient began feeling tenderness in his mid-back. He had been moving heavy boxes and thought he strained a muscle. He developed a fever this morning, which prompted him to come to the emergency department. Past medical history is notable for degenerative spine disease and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.4oC (101.2°F) pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 142/82 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Exam is notable for midline thoracic tenderness on palpation. Neurological exam is nonfocal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine shows decreased signal intensity in the vertebral bodies of T2 and T3 and loss of endplate definition on T1-weighted images. Initial blood cultures come back positive for gram-positive cocci in both bottles. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Heat packs and rest for 2-4 weeks

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with acute back pain and fever in the setting of diabetes and degenerative spine disease. MRI findings are consistent with vertebral osteomyelitis in T2 and T3. Given positive blood cultures of an organism that is most likely Staphylococcus Aureus (S. Aureus), this patient should begin empiric treatment of vertebral osteomyelitis with intravenous antibiotics.

In a patient with MRI findings consistent with vertebral osteomyelitis and blood cultures consistent with a common pathogen for osteomyelitis, such as S. Aureus, a presumptive diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis can be made. The clinician should next determine whether there are signs or findings of focal neurological deficit, epidural abscess, or cord compression. If there are not, and the patient does not have signs of sepsis, then they can be treated empirically with intravenous antibiotics. Patients with clinical findings and imaging findings concerning vertebral osteomyelitis but with negative blood cultures should have an image-guided culture and biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

If, however, the patient has signs of focal neurological deficit, cord compression, or MRI findings of epidural abscess, proceeding directly to surgery is the most appropriate next step in management.

Option Analysis

❌ Operative decompression and drainage:
Incorrect: In patients with cord compression, focal neurological deficits, or findings of an epidural abscess, the next step should be operative decompression and drainage. However, this patient does not have any of these signs or MRI findings, therefore, initial management with antibiotics is reasonable.
❌ Computed tomography-guided biopsy and culture:
Incorrect: This answer choice is appropriate if vertebral osteomyelitis is suspected and blood cultures are negative, or in patients with sepsis who are stable enough to proceed with image-guided biopsy. In this case, with positive blood cultures with a likely infecting organism for vertebral osteomyelitis and corresponding advanced imaging findings, the diagnosis can be presumed, and antibiotic treatment should be started.
✅ Empiric intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Discharge with oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: Patients with a presumptive diagnosis of vertebral osteomyelitis should have intravenous antibiotics, given their shorter onset of action and better bioavailability. Once the patient shows improvement in symptoms patients can be transitioned to oral antibiotics in preparation for discharge.
❌ Heat packs and rest for 2-4 weeks:
Incorrect: Patients with a paraspinal muscle strain should alternate between heat and ice to the affected area and should rest as needed. This patient most likely has vertebral osteomyelitis and conservative care would not be sufficient management; intravenous antibiotics are indicated.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) 18 hours after a stab wound to the right anterior chest. On initial presentation, the patient is hemodynamically unstable with absent breath sounds on the right, resulting in chest tube placement that returns 1700 mL of blood within 10 minutes. Given his instability in the trauma bay, a massive transfusion protocol is initiated. He receives 11 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC), 8 units platelets, and 10 units of plasma. He is subsequently taken to the operating room where a distal right subclavian artery injury is identified and repaired. On post-operative evaluation, temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 95/67mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98%. The patient has blood oozing from all IV sites and the wound site. Which of the following sets of laboratory values is consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Normal Platelet; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen
Decreased Platelets; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen
Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; Decreased Fibrinogen
Normal Platelets; Normal PT; Prolonged aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen
Normal Platelet; Prolonged PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen

questions.solution:
This trauma patient is recovering in the ICU after repair of a large vessel injury and a massive transfusion protocol. He received a balanced 1:1:1 transfusion of packed RBCs, platelets, and plasma. Shortly thereafter, he experienced bleeding from multiple wounds and IV sites, which is consistent with consumptive coagulopathy following trauma and massive transfusion protocol. Associated lab values would include decreased platelet count, prolonged PT and aPTT, and a decreased fibrinogen level.         

The cause of coagulopathy following massive transfusion in trauma patients is multifactorial. In trauma patients, tissue trauma, shock, tissue anoxia, and hypothermia contribute to the development of disseminated intravascular coagulation and microvascular bleeding. Additionally, massive transfusion can lead to the consumption of clotting factors. The result is that consumption of platelets and coagulation factors along with significant fibrinolysis can lead to impaired coagulation and bleeding.         

Treatment for coagulopathy following trauma and massive transfusion includes the maintenance of adequate tissue perfusion, the correction of hypothermia and anemia, and the use of antifibrinolytics and other hemostatic blood products. The anti-fibrinolytic agent tranexamic has been shown to improve mortality rates in trauma patients who are bleeding.   

Option Analysis

❌ Normal Platelet; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen:
Incorrect: This patient presents with consumptive coagulopathy secondary to trauma and massive transfusion protocol resulting in abnormal blood oozing from wound and IV sites. This causes abnormalities including Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; and Decreased Fibrinogen. 
❌ Decreased Platelets; Normal PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen :
Incorrect: In patients with isolated thrombocytopenia, platelet numbers decrease, but clotting times and fibrinogen remain unchanged. This can occur in several conditions, including immune thrombocytopenia, liver disease, and bone marrow disorders. This patient with likely consumptive coagulopathy secondary to trauma and massive transfusion protocol would be expected to have Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; and Decreased Fibrinogen. 
✅ Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; Decreased Fibrinogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Normal Platelets; Normal PT; Prolonged aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen :
Incorrect: Isolated prolonged aPTT occurs with Hemophilia A or B (Factor VIII or IX deficiency). Consumptive coagulopathy after trauma and massive transfusion is more likely in this patient and would present with Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; Decreased Fibrinogen  
❌ Normal Platelet; Prolonged PT; Normal aPTT; Normal Fibrinogen :
Incorrect: Isolated prolonged PT can be caused by Factor VII deficiency. This rare condition is typically discovered during an outpatient workup done for prolonged bleeding. This patient likely has consumptive coagulopathy secondary to trauma and a massive transfusion protocol would be expected to have Decreased Platelets; Prolonged PT; Prolonged aPTT; and Decreased Fibrinogen.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to the surgery office for evaluation of a new skin lesion. The patient first noticed the lesion on his right arm about two weeks ago. There is no associated pain or pruritus. He worked as a lifeguard growing up and never wore sunscreen. His medical history includes hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a prior basal cell carcinoma of the scalp which was removed two years ago. A full body skin exam is performed, and the right arm lesion is biopsied. The biopsy shows dysplastic keratinocytes involving the full thickness of the epidermis that penetrate the epidermal basement membrane to involve the dermis. Which of the following would most likely be seen on physical exam given the biopsy findings?

choices.text: Indurated, hyperkeratotic plaque with a 2mm area of ulceration
Large ulcer with granulation tissue at the base

questions.solution:
Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma: Image courtesy of Wikimedia Commons       

This patient presents to the office with an asymptomatic lesion on the right arm in the setting of a significant history of sun exposure. Biopsy results show dysplastic keratinocytes penetrating the basement membrane, which indicates that the lesion is invasive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). cSCC lesions are typically indurated or firm hyperkeratotic papules, plaques, or nodules, with or without ulceration.         

Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma is the second most common form of skin cancer after basal cell carcinoma. cSCC can develop on any cutaneous surface including the head, neck, trunk, extremities, oral mucosa, periungual skin, and anogenital areas. In individuals with lightly pigmented skin cSCC most commonly arises in sites frequently exposed to the sun. Non-sun-exposed areas represent the most common location for cSCC in individuals with darkly pigmented skin. cSCC can also develop in areas of chronic scarring or burns. The most important risk factors for developing cSCC include ultraviolet light exposure, chronic immunosuppression, and a history of actinic keratosis.        

Patients with presumed cSCC should have a full body skin exam followed by a dermatoscopy of suspicious lesions. A lymph node exam should be performed at the lymph node basins of any suspicious lesion as well.    

Option Analysis

❌ Pigmented lesion with irregular borders :
Incorrect: This describes a melanoma. While the patient has risk factors for melanoma, the pathology results indicate cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Pathology for melanoma varies but typically involves atypical melanocytes spreading radially and/or penetrating the basement membrane.   
❌ Well-circumscribed pearly papule :
Incorrect: This describes a basal cell carcinoma. Pathology for basal cell carcinoma usually contains irregular basaloid cells.  
✅ Indurated, hyperkeratotic plaque with a 2mm area of ulceration :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tan papule that appears “stuck on” :
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with seborrheic keratosis. Commonly described as “stuck on” lesions, they are a non-cancerous growth of keratinocytes.  
❌ Large ulcer with granulation tissue at the base  :
Incorrect: This describes a venous or arterial ulcer, both of which are usually found in the distal extremities of patients with peripheral vascular disease. This patient does not have a history of peripheral arterial disease and pathology is consistent with cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of a new lesion on his right hand. The lesion is within a prior scar from a ganglion cyst removed 15 years ago. Past medical history is significant for liver transplantation as a baby for biliary atresia and current medications include chronic immunosuppressants. On physical exam, the right-hand lesion is approximately 2 cm at its widest point and is a firm, irregular plaque with no areas of ulceration. Dermatoscopy shows several structureless areas. A punch biopsy is performed in the office and the subsequent pathology report confirms a mucin-producing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. The patient returns to the office for a discussion of treatment options. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the office with a 2 cm plaque on the right hand located in a chronic scar. Dermatoscopy indicates cellular atypia and biopsy shows that the lesion is a mucin-producing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). Given these findings and the patient’s chronic immunosuppression, this lesion is at high risk for recurrence and requires surgical management.         

Surgical excision is the preferred treatment for lesions that have features that place them at high and very high risk for recurrence. Excisions can include standard excision with wide 1 cm margins, Mohs micrographic surgery, and excision with adjuvant external beam radiotherapy. For patients with high or very high risk of recurrence who are not surgical candidates, treatment options include primary radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy (e.g. anti-PD-1 antibodies), radiation therapy, and oral retinoids.        
A table outlining features that place lesions at high risk and very high risk for recurrence is shown below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) therapy :
Incorrect: In patients who have high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, surgery is preferred. However, if surgery is contraindicated, anti-PD-1 antibodies have shown efficacy in the treatment of locally advanced and metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in phase 1/2 trials.  
❌ Radiation therapy  :
Incorrect: The use of radiation therapy as primary therapy is typically reserved for older patients who are not surgical candidates because of comorbidities and for those who are not willing to undergo surgery. 
✅ Surgical excision :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chemotherapy :
Incorrect: Conventional chemotherapy can be used in patients who are not surgical candidates. Surgery is the preferred treatment in this young patient with no contraindications to surgery. 
❌ Hand amputation   :
Incorrect: Amputation is not an appropriate treatment for cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Other bone or soft tissue tumors however may require amputation as a last resort.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent for intermittent, severe crampy abdominal pain for the past four hours. She also had two episodes of vomiting. On arrival at the ED, her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 22/min. Physical examination reveals no abdominal tenderness, rebound, or guarding. Abdominal ultrasound shows a target sign in the right lower quadrant, consistent with ileocolic intussusception. While the team is preparing for non-operative reduction, the patient suddenly becomes lethargic with abdominal tenderness in all four quadrants and rebound and guarding. Repeat vital signs show temperature of 36°C (96.8°F) heart rate of 135/min, blood pressure of 83/41 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 32/min. Intravenous access is established, and infusion of crystalloid fluid is started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 3-year-old patient initially presented in stable condition with intussusception. Shortly after, she became tachycardic, hypotensive, and tachypneic with signs of peritonitis. Unstable patients with signs and symptoms of intestinal perforation require urgent operative management with diagnostic laparoscopy.         

Patients with intussusception who are undergoing operative management require adequate intravenous fluid resuscitation and prophylactic intravenous antibiotics covering enteric flora before skin incision. Patients presenting with clinically significant nausea and emesis may require nasogastric tube decompression until the bowel obstruction is resolved by definitive surgical intervention. Operative management of childhood intussusception by pediatric surgeons uses a minimally invasive approach via laparoscopy in most cases. Laparoscopy allows for accurate diagnosis, reduction of intussusception and, if necessary, bowel resection and anastomosis.    

Option Analysis

❌ Peritoneal drain :
Incorrect: This patient is now unstable most likely from a perforation secondary to intussusception, prompting the need for urgent operative management. A peritoneal drain is an alternative to exploratory laparotomy for neonates or children with complications from necrotizing enterocolitis, not intussusception. 
❌ Open laparotomy :
Incorrect: An open laparotomy is an appropriate option for patients with complications secondary to intussusception. However, a minimally invasive approach via laparoscopy is usually attempted first, before converting to an open approach.  
✅ Diagnostic laparoscopy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nasogastric decompression  :
Incorrect: Nasogastric decompression is an adjunct treatment in patients with intussusception if there is evidence of clinically significant nausea and emesis. However, this patient has only vomited twice, both episodes of which were at home.  
❌ Hydrostatic enema  :
Incorrect: Hydrostatic enema is an appropriate treatment to attempt first in stable patients with intussusception. This patient is now unstable most likely from an intestinal perforation. As such, urgent operative management is now warranted.
